The gzip package (at least in debian) comes with all sorts of goodies:
/bin/zdiff
/bin/zgrep
/bin/zforce
/bin/zless
/bin/zmore
/bin/znew
/bin/zcat
/bin/zcmp
/bin/zegrep
/bin/zfgrep

Which operate on compressed, gzip'd, or uncompressed/ungzip'd files.

On Tue, 2006-02-28 at 23:00 -0800, Paul Mullen wrote:
> Neither did I, but I just now attempted to open a few gzip'd text
> files with vim and it worked just fine. You learn something new every
> day!  Previously I used to "gunzip -c happyfuncompressedfile.gz |
> less",
> which would accomplish something similar.

OK, I think it's a DNS problem, but maybe it's something else. In 
any event, I can't figure out the answer.

On my Ubuntu-64 Breezy laptop I use Sylpheed for e-mail. I have it 
set to leave e-mail on the servers because I want to use my 
desktop at home as the place to archive messages. It happily 
checks the servers for my three e-mail accounts whenever I tell it 
to. I can also send e-mail just fine -- except when I am at PSU. 
That's the problem that I can't figure out. Why should it send and 
receive just fine at home, but at PSU it can only receive? 
Everything else works just fine at PSU -- Firefox, etc. When I try to 
send an e-mail the little dialog box just sits there and says 
"connecting to <servername>," but it never connects. It would sit 
there for half an hour if I let it. The program is not hung -- I can tell it 
to stop trying and just tell it to "send later." That puts the e-mails in 
its queue. When I get home I just click on "send all" and it 
promptly sends the messages that it couldn't send from PSU. And 
this happens exactly the same with all three accounts.

I can use Firefox to log into my Comcast account and send the e-
mail with the browser. Or I can send an e-mail from my pdx.edu 
account, also with Firefox. It just seems strange that Sylpheed 
can't send, when everything else has no problem going out. Does 
pub.net discriminate against Sylpheed? And since Sylpheed can 
send without any problem from home, obviously I must have the 
account and passwords set right.

This is probably one of those dumb things that will make me slap 
myself on the forehead as soon as I figure it out. But right now it 
makes no sense at all. Does anyone have any idea why this is 
happening?

From pm at nellump.ath.cx  Wed Mar  1 09:47:54 2006
From: pm at nellump.ath.cx (Paul Mullen)
Date: Wed, 1 Mar 2006 09:47:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Dumb DNS Question?
In-Reply-To: <4405635F.23298.29750AF7@localhost>
References: <4405635F.23298.29750AF7@localhost>
Message-ID: <20060301174754.GA12597@nellump.ath.cx>

On Wed, Mar 01, 2006 at 09:03:27AM -0800, John Jordan wrote:
> I can also send e-mail just fine -- except when I am at PSU. 
> That's the problem that I can't figure out. Why should it send and 
> receive just fine at home, but at PSU it can only receive? 

Is Sylpheed configured to send outgoing e-mails to a Comast SMTP
server? Can it be configured to send through a PSU SMTP server
instead (or better, a different SMTP server for each account it's set
up for).

Comcast probably has their SMTP servers set up to not accept (without
authentication, at least) incoming connections from IP addresses
outside of a Comcast-controlled network. In other words, when you're
connected to your home network, the Comcast SMTP servers sees you
connecting from the IP address associated with your cable modem. When
you're connected via PSU's PubNet, the Comcast SMTP server sees a
"foreign" IP address, and either ignores your connection request
entirely, or waits for some form of authentication. IIRC, back in the
old days POP3 auth was used as a method of authenticating a host
attempting to connect to the SMTP server. Odd, but I guess it worked.

You might want to check with Comcast to see what they have to say
about sending mail through their servers when you're not connected to
their network.

> Does pub.net discriminate against Sylpheed?

That could be it, too. Have you tried reading your e-mail with emacs
or 'mail'?


--
Paul

business account for a domain that I own, hosted at pairNetworks.

From charlie at schluting.com  Wed Mar  1 11:31:25 2006
From: charlie at schluting.com (Charlie Schluting)
Date: Wed, 01 Mar 2006 11:31:25 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Dumb DNS Question? (port 25 filtering)
In-Reply-To: <440581F6.25006.29EC8748@localhost>
References: <440575A5.17003.29BC6C47@localhost>
	<440581F6.25006.29EC8748@localhost>
Message-ID: <4405F68D.8000500@schluting.com>

John Jordan wrote:
> 
> But there is one additional question that just occurred to me. At 
> the point where I am trying to send e-mail I am already logged in. I 
> mean, I had to log in with my student ID and password or NoCat 
> wouldn't let me in, right? So evidently I'll have to log in again? How 
> does that solve the problem with spammers, etc.?

You authenticated to nocat to get network access.
Now, any other resource you want will require authentication too.

Basically what I'm saying is that you have to comfigure your email 
client to either send via PSU (then we'd have logs saying who spammed) 
or you can use "submission" ports for non-PSU servers that mail servers 
don't accept mail on (except from it's own users). So, if spammers can't 
connect to port 25 of e.g. yahoo.com, they can't send email. This is 
harder to explain than I thought :)

So, to "fix" your problem, you how two choices:
Configure your email client to send email (SMTP server in the config) 
using port 587 with authentication. Thunderbird actually has a "TLS" 
option, which provides encryption and authentication. You'll be able to 
specify either server in the config, and it should work from both places 
(IF comcast supports this).

Or, you can configure two SMTP servers and use the comcast one when 
you're at home, the PSU one when you're at PSU.

I would suggest sending all email through PSU. (i.e. change your setup 
so that you use PSU's SMTP server, port 587, with TLS)
You can still send email "From:" whatever you want.. so your comcast 
account will still function the same. It just gets relayed through PSU 
instead of comcast. Does that make sense?
See: http://www.uss.pdx.edu/bin/article.php?article=343700
And there's more documentation about email services there too.

-Charlie

side story:  When working retail I had a custmer come in who owned a court
reporting business.  All of her employees typed 120wpm+.  She only bought
Northgate keyboards. Not because of the sturdiness, there were a couple of other
options for that.  Northgate was the only manufacturer who made keycaps that had
the letters go through the whole key, rather than just being a this plastic (or
whatever) layer on top.

I asked her the same question.  None of her employees needed the printed keycaps,
why did she insist on the only keyboard that wouldn't wear out?

She just liked the orderly look.

   I found a place that prints the characters on the underside of the plastic
label. That should slow down the rate I go through these things.

   If anyone's interested, the keyboard is an Adesso ACK-595 mini, black with
white labels. It's just about the size of a notebook keyboard, and the only
strange placement is the tilde -- it's immediately to the left of the space
bar. But, it leaves me plenty of room on my desk, has a great feel, ... but
just keeps spelling words incorrectly! I like it. Those who prefer GUIS and
use the mouse more than the keyboard probably will never notice the
difference.

On 3/1/06, Galen Seitz <galens at seitzassoc.com> wrote:
> I have a similar machine, and I was about to complain about poor 2D
> performance, but I discovered something else.  When I use less to page
> backwards through a file, the character redraw is very slow.  My discovery
> is that the slowness is apparently due to gnome terminal(version 2.7.3).
> When I page backwards using xterm, the redraw is very fast.

This is a known consequence of running a gnome-terminal, there are at
least a couple projects (Darcs, is one, iirc.) that recommend not
using gnome terminals to do the compilation because it puts such a
tight bottleneck on the output, and can *greatly* increase the time
needed to build the project.

By some miracle, the folks that schedule Penguicon and Linuxfest have
not scheduled on top of each other this year, so rich/idle folks can
go to both!

Penguicon is a Detroit MI area combination of science fiction and Linux
convention.  Three days of frolic and hacking.  I attended Penguicon 1
in 2003, and had a good time.  At the pre-con Geeks With Guns activity,
I watched Eric Raymond teach Guest-Of-Honor Terry Pratchett how to
shoot a pistol.  Late nights spent yacking about software and alternate
universes (but I repeat myself) with midwest notables from both fan groups.

Penguicon 4 will be in Livonia, Michigan (About 20 mi west of Detroit)
on April 21-23 2006.  Website: http://www.penguicon.org   There is no
firm programming schedule yet, though there are many ideas on the wiki.

LinuxFestNW is scheduled for the next weekend, on Saturday April 29
at Bellingham Technical College .  http://www.linuxfestnorthwest.org .
They have less information about this year's event on their website,
but the past Fests have been fantastic.  I plan to present a talk
about using an offsite virtual linux machine as an outward facing
server.  I hope to have the talk ready in time for either the April
6 General PLUG meeting or the April 19 Advanced Topics meeting,
so PLUGgers will only have to choose among 7 other topics during
my time slot up north.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Wed Mar  1 16:33:06 2006
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Wed, 1 Mar 2006 16:33:06 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Testing iptables rules
Message-ID: <20060302003306.GB8605@gate.kl-ic.com>


iptables rules are complex, and usually the only way to test them
is to "go live" with them.  Are there any good offline parsers or
simulators for iptables rulesets? 

Ideally, it would be a tool that could read in the rulesets, and
a script to generate ip packets on various simulated interfaces,
then display them traversing the rules.

I did find one simulator, nfsim, that can do some of this, but it
is targeted at kernel code developers, and a little less flexible
for setting up oddball interfaces.  

I suppose if there are no such tester/simulators, somebody could
write one (perhaps a mangled version of nfsim) and put it up on
a pay-per-view web page, and make a little money.

Keith

Assuming you have a test box or two  . . . 

Load up your iptables rules on one, *
set up another configured to treat #1 as the gateway
use Netcat
or  nemisis
or  ip sorcery
or  _____ to generate traffic

view the logs to see if it's doing what you want.

* modified to log everything.

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-bounces at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-bounces at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Charlie Schluting
Sent: Wednesday, March 01, 2006 11:31 AM
To: General Linux/UNIX discussion and help; civil and on-topic
Subject: Re: [PLUG] Dumb DNS Question? (port 25 filtering)

John Jordan wrote:
> 
> But there is one additional question that just occurred to me. At 
> the point where I am trying to send e-mail I am already logged in. I 
> mean, I had to log in with my student ID and password or NoCat 
> wouldn't let me in, right? So evidently I'll have to log in again? How 
> does that solve the problem with spammers, etc.?

You authenticated to nocat to get network access.
Now, any other resource you want will require authentication too.

Basically what I'm saying is that you have to comfigure your email 
client to either send via PSU (then we'd have logs saying who spammed) 
or you can use "submission" ports for non-PSU servers that mail servers 
don't accept mail on (except from it's own users). So, if spammers can't 
connect to port 25 of e.g. yahoo.com, they can't send email. This is 
harder to explain than I thought :)

So, to "fix" your problem, you how two choices:
Configure your email client to send email (SMTP server in the config) 
using port 587 with authentication. Thunderbird actually has a "TLS" 
option, which provides encryption and authentication. You'll be able to 
specify either server in the config, and it should work from both places 
(IF comcast supports this).

Or, you can configure two SMTP servers and use the comcast one when 
you're at home, the PSU one when you're at PSU.

I would suggest sending all email through PSU. (i.e. change your setup 
so that you use PSU's SMTP server, port 587, with TLS)
You can still send email "From:" whatever you want.. so your comcast 
account will still function the same. It just gets relayed through PSU 
instead of comcast. Does that make sense?
See: http://www.uss.pdx.edu/bin/article.php?article=343700
And there's more documentation about email services there too.

-Charlie

On 3/1/06, Charles Sliger <chaz at bctonline.com> wrote:
> I'll add my own dumb question...
> Is it not possible to have the laptop get the SMTP server address via DHCP
> along with all the other info for the PSU environment?

Not a dumb question.  However, I think it makes more sense to promote
authenticated smtp than create a new architecture for dynamic smtp
assignment.  Since most email users these days use a pop3 or imap
server to retrieve mail from an ISP, from a user perspective it makes
more sense to use the same credentials as the pop3/imap account to
authenticate to smtp.

Or just use a web interface like me :-)

Jason

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Wed Mar  1 22:33:36 2006
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Wed, 1 Mar 2006 22:33:36 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Cheesy Postgrey/Mailman whitelist hack
Message-ID: <20060302063336.GA10763@gate.kl-ic.com>


A couple of weeks ago, I proposed a way to whitelist email addresses
for real people that were being stopped by Postgrey.  That method
involved a special webpage where folks could enter their email
address, and get added to the whitelist.  I've been ruminating on
that, and all the good feedback I got from the PLUG list.

I thought of an easier hack.  There are five Mailman mailing lists on
my server;  the folks that are using the mailing lists might also
encounter Postgrey problems.  The Mailman administration command
"list_members <group>" emits the email addresses of all the folks
that are on mail list "group".  So instead of constructing an
ad-hoc kludge based on a web page,  I hope to use Mailman as an
address entry engine instead.  

I have created a new mailman list named "allow".  Folks having
problems getting through Postgrey can sign up for this zero-traffic
moderated list.  Any time a person signs up for the allow list, as
well as at a time specified by cron, this triggers an email to
user "allow" which kicks off a script that runs list_members for
all the groups and builds a new whitelist for Postgrey.  

This Mailman based-approach is easier and probably more secure than
trusting my own ability to construct a webpage and authenticate
an address.  This approach whitelists all the members of the real
mailing lists, too.  I have not had problems with bad guys signing
up for Mailman (so far), and Mailman has methods for blacklisting
the bad guys.  If Mailman starts being abused by the black hats,
new versions will rapidly close those holes.  

Suggestions?

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

In-Reply-To: <20060302003306.GB8605@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20060302003306.GB8605@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Wed, 2006-03-01 at 16:33 -0800, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> iptables rules are complex, and usually the only way to test them
> is to "go live" with them.  Are there any good offline parsers or
> simulators for iptables rulesets? 

Not that I know of.  ipchains used to have a '-C / --check' option,
where you could specify packet parameters and test against an existing
chain, but iptables seems to have dropped that.  It's rather too bad; a
complex state-machine like Netfilter is easy to get wrong and when it is
wrong it can be very badly wrong.

Wil

On Wed, 2006-03-01 at 19:02 -0800, Charlie Schluting wrote:
> Charles Sliger wrote:
> > I'll add my own dumb question...
> > Is it not possible to have the laptop get the SMTP server address via DHCP
> > along with all the other info for the PSU environment?
> > Regards,
> > Chaz
> 
> I don't know of any DHCP server/client that supports this.
> I also don't know of any email clients that have the ability to lookup 
> which SMTP server to use (presumably this would be stored in a file 
> somewhere?).

dhcpd-options(5) has:
       option smtp-server ip-address [, ip-address... ];

          The SMTP server option specifies a list of SMTP servers available to
          the client.  Servers should be listed in order of preference.

So, ISC DHCPD supports it and I would presume dhclient's script could do
something useful with it (update a local MTA, perhaps?).  But that's a
long way from "plug-and-play"...

Wil

Using iptables -A INPUT -j LOG --log-prefix="...: " seems to help.

logging to the console.  Nothing like trying to vim in one Xterm

documentation on how to prevent logging to the screen for 
Redhat and Fedora systems.  I don't know if this happens a lot 
because of bugs or if there is a simple change that can be done 
to syslog.conf.  Maybe the kernel logger is to blame, but where 
is the kernel logger's config file???  This problem doesn't seem
to really be distro specific.

In-Reply-To: <c29537840603012141j6da900a0kcd8addb40813810f@mail.gmail.com>
References: <4406604C.4050200@schluting.com>
	<B0017717556@bct-mail.bctonline.com>
	<c29537840603012141j6da900a0kcd8addb40813810f@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <1141278813.4406885db9b69@xerxes.robinson-west.com>

Quoting "Jason R. Martin" <nsxfreddy at gmail.com>:

> On 3/1/06, Charles Sliger <chaz at bctonline.com> wrote:
> > How do you suppose really large organizations with mobile people solve
> this
> > when those people show up at various locations around the world?
> > Or for that matter people from their business partners who visit.
> > I just assumed that DHCP/DNS would provide all the information to let them
> > do things like email, etc.
> > Anyone out there have experience wrestling with such problems?
> 
> People from large companies typically use a VPN connection to connect
> to their corporate network remotely, and then use the same smtp
> settings they always use.
> 
> Jason

Ahh, but there may be good reason not to.  Do I want to do personal
correspondence through my boss'es server even if I am not too inclined
to worry about him eavesdropping?  If nothing else, it could be said
that personal emails crossing a corporate network are in bad taste
during any time of the day or night.

The idea of dhcp handing out smtp server settings makes sense.  After
all, why isn't there a standard service to dynamically set that up?
For that matter, why isn't there a fall back web server dns record 
like the MX record?  Maybe it could be called WS, for web server.

A possible solution is a new standard mail protocol that abstracts 
which smtp server you use and whether pop or imap is called for
to ensure that these things are controlled on the server side.
Web mail sites sort of do this, but not everyone likes webmail.
Specifically there are many detractors who notice that mailto:
tags in html pages try to access a local mail program...  A very
simple mail client that sends say a "do I encrypt?" message to a 
server looked up via a special DNS record should be able to work 
quite nicely.  

Seemless integrations suggests that you don't run into problems 
with middleware.  If you can get Windows, or even Linux, to open 
a web browser and start a webmail session when you click on a 
mailto: shortcut in an html document, that would make web mail 
far more palatable.  If imap worked the same way for every imap 
client that accesses the same imap server, this would help as 
well.

Authenticating who sends email through PSU servers and requiring that it
be encrypted, doesn't this smack of censorship and a pointless approach
to spam control?  How many people are afraid of being identified?  Even
if you are identified, how much can PSU do about it considering the 
first amendment?  Maintaining an advanced environment that requires 
people to possess intimate knowledge to use it efficiently, especially 
in a large University where it's easy to get lost in the crowd, doesn't
strike me as particularly conducive to productivity or learning.  Since
when are college students professionals that are comfortable with 
sophisticated environments?  Maybe this makes sense for PSU where 
the average student is probably over 30.

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Wed Mar  1 22:51:23 2006
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (plug_0 at robinson-west.com)
Date: Wed,  1 Mar 2006 22:51:23 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Cheesy Postgrey/Mailman whitelist hack
In-Reply-To: <20060302063336.GA10763@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20060302063336.GA10763@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <1141282283.440695eb5f665@xerxes.robinson-west.com>

Quoting Keith Lofstrom <keithl at kl-ic.com>:

> 
> A couple of weeks ago, I proposed a way to whitelist email addresses
> for real people that were being stopped by Postgrey.  That method
> involved a special webpage where folks could enter their email
> address, and get added to the whitelist.  I've been ruminating on
> that, and all the good feedback I got from the PLUG list.
> 
> I thought of an easier hack.  There are five Mailman mailing lists on
> my server;  the folks that are using the mailing lists might also
> encounter Postgrey problems.  The Mailman administration command
> "list_members <group>" emits the email addresses of all the folks
> that are on mail list "group".  So instead of constructing an
> ad-hoc kludge based on a web page,  I hope to use Mailman as an
> address entry engine instead.  
> 
> I have created a new mailman list named "allow".  Folks having
> problems getting through Postgrey can sign up for this zero-traffic
> moderated list.  Any time a person signs up for the allow list, as
> well as at a time specified by cron, this triggers an email to
> user "allow" which kicks off a script that runs list_members for
> all the groups and builds a new whitelist for Postgrey.  
> 
> This Mailman based-approach is easier and probably more secure than
> trusting my own ability to construct a webpage and authenticate
> an address.  This approach whitelists all the members of the real
> mailing lists, too.  I have not had problems with bad guys signing
> up for Mailman (so far), and Mailman has methods for blacklisting
> the bad guys.  If Mailman starts being abused by the black hats,
> new versions will rapidly close those holes.  
> 
> Suggestions?
> 
> Keith

Are there any postfix friendly or better yet MTA neutral alternatives
to mailman?

 On Wed, Mar 01, 2006 at 10:16:59AM -0800, Carla Schroder wrote:
> Hurray! HP and Samsung are the only printer vendors, as far as i know, that
> blatantly support Linux.

On Wed, Mar 01, 2006 at 09:35:47PM -0800, Bill Barry wrote:
> My encounter with Samsung linux drivers was not so
> memorable, it involved binary drivers and if I remember
> correctly their installation script overwrote some of my
> configuration files. The printer was an SCX-4016 which
> I eventually had to hook to a Windows machine and use Samba.

I don't know about most Samsung printers, but they do have great
support for some.  I bought a Samsung ML-2010  B&W laser printer. 
It is small (about 14x16 footprint) and cheap ($60 after rebate). 
The toner cartridge does not appear to be "chipped".  It is a USB
"winprinter", but it came with Linux drivers, and a GUI installer
for them, as well as a few pages of the skimpy printed manual
devoted to Linux.  There are also ML-2010 drivers on the web. 

Since I *don't like* manufacturer installers (they usually don't
play well with RPM or hardware management systems like SUSE YAST),
I used open source drivers from the web.  These work fine.

If you need a small and inexpensive B&W laser printer, you should
consider the Samsung.  If you are satisfied with it, a nice thank
you letter to Samsung, mentioning that you are using it with Linux,
will probably encourage them to keep providing Linux support.

I like HP printers better, of course, but they are expensive,
and for the application above, too large.  I have 3 old HP4M+
postscript printers (2 running, one for parts) in places where
I have the space, and in spite of their age they work great. 
At some point, I may purchase an HP color laser, someday, after
my old Tektronix Phaser 350 postscript crayon printer breaks. 
(This from the guy that kept his old Subaru running for 24
years, and is typing this on a Redhat 9 laptop)

Is there a list online of what printers use chipped toners, 
and which do not?

Keith

I had the same problem. Under KDE, go to System Settings->Red Hat Network Configuration (or just run /usr/bin/up2date-config from the cmd line). On the Retrieval/Installation tab, uncheck "Use GPG to verify package integrity."

>From: "Michael M." <debian at writemoore.net>
> plug_0 at robinson-west.com wrote:
> > With my own confusion about ports, flags, and addressing, it 
> > seems that IP networking needs a lot of work.  Supposedly IPv6 
> > is out, but doesn't IPv6 require new hardware?  It appears with 
> > IPv6 that there are security problems, at least with Bind 9 
> > aleady.
> 
> IPv6 is here, but it doesn't work for me under Debian.  I had to turn it 
> off completely in order to use Firefox, Mozilla and Ephiphany. 
> Konqueror, however, worked fine, but I think the version I was using was 
> not IPv6-enabled.  Also, w3m worked when invoked with the "-4" (IPv4 
> only) option.  Otherwise, it would time out like the others.

Define "doesn't work". Though it isn't fully supported, a lot of Debian
is fine with IPv6. Some programs do need recompilation to enable IPv6
support. Multiple folks are filing non-wishlist bugs against packages
which fail to support IPv6.

Note that your ISP does need to support IPv6, or you need a tunnel to get
to IPv6 sites.

> But I don't know about the new hardware requirement.  My machine, a 
> flat-panel iMac, is (IIRC) five years old, or four at the least.  IPv6 
> works fine under OS X, using both Safari and Camino.  Maybe you were 
> referring to routers or modems?

How many routers actually do IP in hardware? Even Cisco routers which
were designed to do IPv4 in hardware, can do IPv6 in hardware though it
took them a long time to implement.

AthlonRob wrote:

> 
>>Quoting AthlonRob <AthlonRob at axpr.net>:
>>
>>
>>>plug_0 at robinson-west.com wrote:
>>>
>>>>I hear Novell IPX is a good protocol, but it's hardly a free 
>>>>one and I doubt it's ubiquitous.  Sadly Novell Netware appears
>>>>to be going to IP networking offering no advantage anymore.  
>>>
>>>Yeah, except IPX isn't routable over a public network.
>>
>>And this is necessary for a LAN???  All you have to do is acquire
>>an ipx to ip gateway program if you MUST cross a public network.
> 
> 
> Well, let me rephrase, then.  Sure, IPX might be a decent protocol...
> but the fact that it isn't globally routable makes it worthless as a
> true IP competitor.

IPX _is_ globally routable. You just need an IPX-based global network.
The reason why IPX is not suitable for a network the size of the
Internet is because packets can't cross more than 15 routers or hops.
The IPX equivalent of the IP TTL is a 4-bit counter - unless Novell
changed that in a recent decade. :-)


> And you can't just willy-nilly translate from IPX to IP... what most of
> those "IPX gateway" programs do is just create tunnels over which IPX
> can run free.  Only really for old games, at that...

There were at least three real (not tunnels) IPX/IP gateways back in
the 1990s. I don't remember if any of them were Open Source - probably
not.

Ed

From johnxj at comcast.net  Thu Mar  2 23:43:03 2006
From: johnxj at comcast.net (John Jason Jordan)
Date: Thu, 2 Mar 2006 23:43:03 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] HP Linux imaging and printer
In-Reply-To: <4407E28C.2000909@alcpress.com>

	<4407E28C.2000909@alcpress.com>

On Thu, 02 Mar 2006 22:30:36 -0800
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com> wrote:

> As far as I can tell, HP has no Linux support for any of
> their scanners. I'm talking new scanners - something you
> can buy at a store. Is this the case?

I wanted one of those super-small and lightweight USB scanners so I could take it to the university with me if necessary. I can't remember where I found it -- Xsane website maybe -- but there is a web page somewhere that lists just about every scanner out there complete with how it works in Linux. I ended up getting a Canon LiDE 30 for under $100 on eBay and it is perfect, albeit kind of slow. Weighs just a few pounds and the color even matches my computer. Every feature is completely supported and works great with Xsane. I just plug it in, fire up Xsane, and scan away. But watch out -- the LiDE 30 is the model from like two years ago and it is the last of the line that work with Linux. Canon changed something deep inside the later models and none of them work with Linux.

As for HP, they used to make pretty good scanners, although never cutting edge. Nevertheless, reliable and well supported. I have an ancient IIcx on my desktop and in spite of its age it still works fine. But under the previous r?gime the decision was made to come out with new models every few months in order to boost sales, even though the only change was a different paint job. In the process, quality sank. And support pretty much disappeared also. I'd look elsewhere today.

Until then, there is Kinko's, which to open source people is somewhat
like whorehouses are to married men.  Libraries are also usually 
infected with windoze, too, but are often overly restricted on what
runs there.

I suspect another thing that screws up these weird media players are
strict Linux firewalls.  Ah, for the simpler (and imaginary) times
when you could design a protocol without worrying about security.

There are a lot of .rmv presentations out there, hopefully you can
find one to practice on. Guy Kawasaki does a lot of Raindance stuff,
and he's entertaining.

From scratchcomputing at gmail.com  Fri Mar  3 01:10:39 2006
From: scratchcomputing at gmail.com (Eric Wilhelm)
Date: Fri, 3 Mar 2006 01:10:39 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] USB drives ???
In-Reply-To: <4407F29A.2040003@axpr.net>
References: <5.1.0.14.2.20060302145510.023c1408@www.hotsushi.com>
	<4407E329.9080404@alcpress.com> <4407F29A.2040003@axpr.net>
Message-ID: <200603030110.39834.ewilhelm@cpan.org>

# from AthlonRob
# on Thursday 02 March 2006 11:39 pm:

>Ed Sawicki wrote:
>> I saw the drive. I wondered whether I could refomat it to ext3.
>> Any thoughts on this?
>
>I don't see any reason why not. ?As mine is going back and forth
> between Windows and sane boxes, I left it as vfat.. but it looks like
> a regular USB (SCSI) hard drive to user space.

Yeah, aside from the few exceptions (ahem, olympus camera that announces 
"I'm a shovel") the usb mass-storage protocol is pretty much just the 
usb hardware saying "there's something that behaves like a block device 
at the end of this cable" and the kernel assigns it the next random 
scsi id and away you go.  That means fdisk /dev/sda, 
mkfs.ext3 /dev/sda1, etc should give you no grief.  Maybe not the case 
on ipods if you want it to continue being an ipod, but drives are 
drives.  As for the backup button and such, that's a different beast 
(is there a hub in the box?) but if you can mount it as vfat on linux, 
you can reformat it.

--Eric

a collision course with your house, the pitch would stay the same until
impact. As I said, that's one's subtle.
--Larry Wall

From debian at writemoore.net  Fri Mar  3 02:52:37 2006
From: debian at writemoore.net (Michael M.)
Date: Fri, 03 Mar 2006 02:52:37 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] firewall
In-Reply-To: <200603030019.k230J0Bd080317@m5p.com>
References: <200603030019.k230J0Bd080317@m5p.com>
Message-ID: <44081FF5.5070302@writemoore.net>

Elliott Mitchell wrote:
>>From: "Michael M." <debian at writemoore.net>
>>
>>IPv6 is here, but it doesn't work for me under Debian.  I had to turn it 
>>off completely in order to use Firefox, Mozilla and Ephiphany. 
>>Konqueror, however, worked fine, but I think the version I was using was 
>>not IPv6-enabled.  Also, w3m worked when invoked with the "-4" (IPv4 
>>only) option.  Otherwise, it would time out like the others.
> 
> Define "doesn't work". Though it isn't fully supported, a lot of Debian
> is fine with IPv6. Some programs do need recompilation to enable IPv6
> support. Multiple folks are filing non-wishlist bugs against packages
> which fail to support IPv6.

"Doesn't work" as in the apps I mentioned above will not load any 
websites; instead, they'd time out.  For example, doing:

:$ w3m http://www.google.com

would not load Google.  It would sit there trying to open a socket until 
it finally timed out.  But when I did:

:$ w3m -4 http://www.google.com

it loaded Google without delay.

It's not the program that's the problem.  I found a couple of 
discussions that went back and forth between the kernel module or 
Debian's network stack as the source of the problem, though some were 
also blaming Netscape/Mozilla.  But AFAIK, w3m is unrelated to Mozilla, 
so I don't think it's a Mozilla problem.

See, for example:
http://lists.debian.org/debian-ipv6/2004/12/msg00014.html
http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=253590

I've also found at least one discussion on Ubuntu's developer forum 
pertaining to the IPv6 problem, and I had the same issue in Ubuntu.  My 
Debian kernel is 2.6.8, but I believe Ubuntu uses a newer kernel.

> Note that your ISP does need to support IPv6, or you need a tunnel to get
> to IPv6 sites.

I don't know whether it does or does not, but I do know that under OS X, 
I do have an IPv6 address (which, for all I know, might go unused) and 
this doesn't create any problems for me.  I have no issues with Safari, 
Firefox or Camino, which is a Mozilla Community Project and shares a lot 
of code with Mozilla/Firefox.  Under Debian (and Ubuntu), however, IPv6 
screws me up.  I had to disable it by commenting out the appropriate 
lines in /etc/modprobe.d/aliases.

There's nothing special I was trying to do with IPv6 -- I wouldn't have 
a clue how!  It's just that there's something amiss with the way Debian 
handles IPv6, or handles failed IPv6 queries, at least as compared to 
how OS X handles these things.

>>But I don't know about the new hardware requirement.  My machine, a 
>>flat-panel iMac, is (IIRC) five years old, or four at the least.  IPv6 
>>works fine under OS X, using both Safari and Camino.  Maybe you were 
>>referring to routers or modems?
> 
> How many routers actually do IP in hardware? Even Cisco routers which
> were designed to do IPv4 in hardware, can do IPv6 in hardware though it
> took them a long time to implement.

No idea.  It was just conjecture on my part.

-- 
Michael

Message-ID: <659b9ea30603031407x4e9d2cb3pf3b8a8e3f9d8d815@mail.gmail.com>

Go to the site, click on "archive" and you'll see that everything is
posted as MP3 files.  You can listen to these using any MP3 software
you'd like, like xmms, mplayer, or Windoze stuff like Windows Media
Player or RealPlayer.

The RSS feed allows you to subscribe to the feed so that you
automatically get the newest episodes when they become available.  I
use iTunes under CrossOver office to download mine, but when Juice
(formerly iPodder comes out with a linux port) I'll probably switch to
that.  There are lots of podcasting clients out there.  But, the file
which is downloaded is still nothing more than MP3.   So, you can use
any player which supports MP3, like iRiver, Zen, etc.  iTunes, for
example, lets you play them once downloaded through iTunes directly,
so you don't need a portable media player regardless.

If you don't already know, however, a podcast is NOT just posting MP3s
on a web page.  Podcasts are subscriptions to media using RSS, so that
your podcasting aggregator automatically downloads it.  Automation is
the key and is provided when you reference your media within an RSS
file.  If only we could change the stupid name, as it is neither
broadcasting nor restricted to iPods only.

Does that help?

Chris

Irregardless of its silly portmanteau-of-the-month label, a "podcast"
doesn't necessarily have anything to do with iPods (or broadcasting,
for that matter). Most are just digital audio files (MP3, typically).
You don't even need an RSS feed parser to deal with them. The PLUG
talks are archived such that you can just download individual files
and play them with whatever software/device you prefer.

Last night's ImageMagick talk:
<http://www.podasp.com/episodes/p/pd/pdxlug/238.mp3>

Using iptables -A INPUT -j LOG --log-prefix="...: " seems to help.  
Except for one major headache on my Fedora Core 3 system, undesired 
logging to the console.  Nothing like trying to vim in one Xterm 
while you watch /var/log/messages on another only to have the 
messages muddy up your editing window.  I could use good 
documentation on how to prevent logging to the screen for 
Redhat and Fedora systems.  I don't know if this happens a lot 
because of bugs or if there is a simple change that can be done 
to syslog.conf.  Maybe the kernel logger is to blame, but where 
is the kernel logger's config file???  This problem doesn't seem
to really be distro specific.

-------------------------------------------------
This mail sent through IMP: http://horde.org/imp/
_______________________________________________

[chaz> ] Mike,
Yes, klogd is the culprit.  Make the following config change:

/etc/sysconfig/syslog
	KLOGD_OPTIONS="-x -c 3"
Sets the default console log level to 3 (ERR).
This stops iptables log messages from being displayed on the console.
Regards,
Chaz
Charles L. Sliger,  Information Systems Engineer,  chaz at bctonline.com

From ehem at m5p.com  Fri Mar  3 22:03:19 2006
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Fri, 3 Mar 2006 22:03:19 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] firewall
In-Reply-To: <20060303162933.E81C047A8@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <200603040603.k2463JKp093161@m5p.com>

>From: "Michael M." <debian at writemoore.net>
> Elliott Mitchell wrote:
> >>From: "Michael M." <debian at writemoore.net>
> >>IPv6 is here, but it doesn't work for me under Debian.  I had to turn it 
> >>off completely in order to use Firefox, Mozilla and Ephiphany. 
> >>Konqueror, however, worked fine, but I think the version I was using was 
> >>not IPv6-enabled.  Also, w3m worked when invoked with the "-4" (IPv4 
> >>only) option.  Otherwise, it would time out like the others.
> > 
> > Define "doesn't work". Though it isn't fully supported, a lot of Debian
> > is fine with IPv6. Some programs do need recompilation to enable IPv6
> > support. Multiple folks are filing non-wishlist bugs against packages
> > which fail to support IPv6.
> 
> "Doesn't work" as in the apps I mentioned above will not load any 
> websites; instead, they'd time out.  For example, doing:
> 
> :$ w3m http://www.google.com
> 
> would not load Google.  It would sit there trying to open a socket until 
> it finally timed out.  But when I did:
> 
> :$ w3m -4 http://www.google.com
> 
> it loaded Google without delay.
> 
> It's not the program that's the problem.  I found a couple of 
> discussions that went back and forth between the kernel module or 
> Debian's network stack as the source of the problem, though some were 
> also blaming Netscape/Mozilla.  But AFAIK, w3m is unrelated to Mozilla, 
> so I don't think it's a Mozilla problem.
> 
> See, for example:
> http://lists.debian.org/debian-ipv6/2004/12/msg00014.html
> http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=253590
> 
> I've also found at least one discussion on Ubuntu's developer forum 
> pertaining to the IPv6 problem, and I had the same issue in Ubuntu.  My 
> Debian kernel is 2.6.8, but I believe Ubuntu uses a newer kernel.

This isn't IPv6 not working, this is IPv6 attempting to operate when your
network has no support. The response:
http://lists.debian.org/debian-ipv6/2004/12/msg00016.html

Covers it. The kernel module gets loaded, it attempts to route the packet
onto the local subnet despite no default route. Packet gets dropped
instead of producing an error.

> > Note that your ISP does need to support IPv6, or you need a tunnel to get
> > to IPv6 sites.
> 
> I don't know whether it does or does not, but I do know that under OS X, 
> I do have an IPv6 address (which, for all I know, might go unused) and 
> this doesn't create any problems for me.  I have no issues with Safari, 
> Firefox or Camino, which is a Mozilla Community Project and shares a lot 
> of code with Mozilla/Firefox.  Under Debian (and Ubuntu), however, IPv6 
> screws me up.  I had to disable it by commenting out the appropriate 
> lines in /etc/modprobe.d/aliases.

Sounds like the failure mentioned in that followup. This though is not a
Debian failure, but a kernel bug. Sounds like MacOS X correctly handles
the situation of no IPv6 default route (produce an error internally and
have connect() fail).

> There's nothing special I was trying to do with IPv6 -- I wouldn't have
> a clue how!  It's just that there's something amiss with the way Debian
> handles IPv6, or handles failed IPv6 queries, at least as compared to
> how OS X handles these things.

This is a problem of how the kernel handles the /lack/ of IPv6, rather
than a problem of how is handles the presence of IPv6.

I think at least one survey was done which discovered that no Senator
read the Patriot Act before passing it. True, that doesn't mean they were
unaware of the implications, but you should agree that is a bad sign at
best. If you've looked at the amount of legislation which goes through,
let alone the amount introduced, you'd realize there is no way they could
realize the consequences of all of it. Further all too often they try to
legislate technical issues, for which they don't have the background. In
these situations how would it even be possible for them to know?

> (R-Douchebag)", looking to give the Broadcast Flag new life.

I make a distinction between "introduce legislation" and "vote on the
bill"; most legislators *don't* read everything that comes across their
desk, but if they wrote (or co-authored) a bill, I'd hope they have some
idea what it does. The PATRIOT act was notorious for being rushed
through and I'm pretty sure you're right on that count -- no one read it
fully.

True, "all the implications" is a bit broad, I suppose.  I suppose I
should say they have an idea of what they intend the bill to do and have
written it accordingly.

AthlonRob wrote:
> Ed Sawicki wrote:
> 
>>IPX _is_ globally routable. You just need an IPX-based global network.
>>The reason why IPX is not suitable for a network the size of the
>>Internet is because packets can't cross more than 15 routers or hops.
>>The IPX equivalent of the IP TTL is a 4-bit counter - unless Novell
>>changed that in a recent decade. :-)
> 
> 
> It is routable, but there's no standardization to say your network won't
> use the same addresses my network uses...

Some years back, Novell had a program called "IPX Everywhere" or
a similar name in which they encouraged people to register for
a unique IPX prefix (network address). I did. This, of course, was
needed if IPX customers wanted to interconnect.

At the same time, AT&T partnered with Novell to offer a worldwide
IPX-based network. I always assumed that AT&T achieved that with
IPX/IP gateways, thus solving the 15 hop limitation. But they might
have extended the TTL. I remember there were a few unused bits in the
IPX header.

Ed

From aaron at bavariati.org  Sat Mar  4 10:38:09 2006
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Sat, 4 Mar 2006 10:38:09 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Certifications
In-Reply-To: <030420061330.262.4409968C000563CE000001062205886172020102020E039D@comcast.net>

Message-ID: <20060304183808.GA18460@syrinxpc.com>

On Sat, Mar 04, 2006 at 01:30:52PM +0000, rmannon at comcast.net wrote:
> Do you guys/gals think the sys admin certs are a well rounded, or
> should I go after  some of those all encompassing linux jujitsu master
> certs that cost an arm and a leg.

They're all sysadmin certs, right?  Sure, the Red Hat one is more
expensive and has a practical exam, but they all take some knowledge.

I took the LPI Level 1 exams at Free Geek a while ago, and even as a
7-year Linux user/admin, I learned some new stuff while preparing for it.

I'd suggest starting with that and an A+, and look at achieving a basic
SAGE skill level.  They have a standard for rating sysadmins; a SAGE
Level 2 admin is pretty dang competent.  (It's self-rated, not by exam.)

People know A+ certifications now, and "Linux Professional Institute"
looks pretty good on a resume.  CCNAs aren't that hard to get, either.

Let your employer pay for the expensive ones.  And don't forget, you can
deduct tuition.

Move fast, there's lots of folks hiring sysadmins right now.  I think
PSU Office of IT is still looking for a Linux/Solaris admin.  Hey, free
tuition and generous benefits...



From miken at hotsushi.com  Sat Mar  4 10:02:07 2006
From: miken at hotsushi.com (Mike Neal)
Date: Sat, 04 Mar 2006 10:02:07 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Certifications
In-Reply-To: <030420061330.262.4409968C000563CE0000010622058861720201020
	20E039D@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.2.20060304093943.02a21008@www.hotsushi.com>

Hi

A particular cert may be required to apply for a position.

IMHO, besides showing you can pass tests, certs are useful for
1. Applying to entry level positions when you don't have much experience.
2. Satisfying HR types who use degrees and certs to compensate for not 
fully understanding necessary job skills.
3. To differentiate yourself from similar candidates.
4. Demonstrates commitment to career advancement.
5. Know that you have broad understanding of the topic.

Certs are vendor specific like Red Hat, Novell, etc. or vendor neutral like 
, CompTIA and LPI. The LPI organization and development process is more 
"open" than the rest.

To pass cert tests, use some combination of master the material versus cram 
for the exam. There are lots of self study materials and a range of online 
and classroom courseware. At least visit the cert web site and study the 
Certification Test Objectives pages.

Checkout IBMs online tutorials for LPI: 
http://www-128.ibm.com/developerworks/linux/lpi/?S_TACT=105AGX03&S_CMP=ZHP

While you're at it, checkout the rest of IBM developerworks site, a nice 
present to the community.

Freegeek has offered LPI exams (someone add details).

Cheers,
Mike

CCNA is good, but (obviously) Cisco-centric.  You'll get a great
overview of networking technologies and TCP/IP, but you'll also get a
bunch of IOS commands, which is useful if you're a netadmin working
with Cisco equipment, but perhaps not as useful for anyone else.

Jason (CCNA who no longer works with Cisco equipment)

Aside from the package management questions (debs or rpms), it is
basically distro-neutral... and it's fairly cheap (when compared to
the distro specific certs) at $100 per exam and no mandatory class.

... just my 2 cents.

-kevin

> two months, and it won't boot.  It dies before touching the floppy or

LILO problem.  Need to either have a small /boot partition at the start of the 
drive, or use grub instead.

Forget my previous reply/question: you're entirely right.  The "boot
floppy" and "bootable CD-ROM" I was trying with don't boot any other
machine either, lables notwithstanding.  Once I'd made a floppy that
could boot a working machine it booted the broken one as well.  It was
an ancient debian rescue disk, on a 2.2 kernel, but with it I was able
to run grub-install, reboot to "L 07 07 07" again, boot off the floppy
and run grub-install again, and finally boot off of the hard drive.
As far as I can tell, the machine's back to working.  No motherboard
problems here.

lilo is not on the machine.  I don't understand how it got involved in
the boot process.  But I'm happy now, and can worry about that some
other time. :-)

> Using iptables -A INPUT -j LOG --log-prefix="...: " seems to help.  
> Except for one major headache on my Fedora Core 3 system, undesired 
> logging to the console.  Nothing like trying to vim in one Xterm

> documentation on how to prevent logging to the screen for 
> Redhat and Fedora systems.  I don't know if this happens a lot 
> because of bugs or if there is a simple change that can be done 
> to syslog.conf.  Maybe the kernel logger is to blame, but where 
> is the kernel logger's config file???  This problem doesn't seem
> to really be distro specific.
> 
> -------------------------------------------------
> This mail sent through IMP: http://horde.org/imp/
> _______________________________________________
> 
> [chaz> ] Mike,
> Yes, klogd is the culprit.  Make the following config change:
> 
> /etc/sysconfig/syslog
> 	KLOGD_OPTIONS="-x -c 3"
> Sets the default console log level to 3 (ERR).
> This stops iptables log messages from being displayed on the console.
> Regards,
> Chaz
> Charles L. Sliger,  Information Systems Engineer,  chaz at bctonline.com

Having a Slackware install CD is another good way to do rescues.  The way 
Slackware installs, you start in a working Linux environment which happens
to be incredibly useful for fixing things.  Anymore, I'm moving towards
freedos and loadlin to get into Linux.  This is a nice clean way, especially
if Winhose is installed anywhere, to avoid the boot sector nightmere.
One problem I've run into is wanting to run parallel Linux systems on the
same machine so that there is a main and a backup system.  Even adding a
blank hard disk can mess up grub.  If PC's supported an off hard disk 
boot sector, this could significantly alleviate this issue.  If you can
boot to thumb drive before hard disk, this is something I'd recommend 
exploring.

Michael C. Robinson

>> As far as I can tell, the machine's back to working.  No motherboard
>> problems here.
>>
>> lilo is not on the machine.  I don't understand how it got involved in
>> the boot process.  But I'm happy now, and can worry about that some
>> other time. :-)
>>
>> Thanks very much for your help this Saturday evening!
>>
>> --Eric
>
> Having a Slackware install CD is another good way to do rescues.  The way
> Slackware installs, you start in a working Linux environment which happens
> to be incredibly useful for fixing things.  Anymore, I'm moving towards
> freedos and loadlin to get into Linux.  This is a nice clean way, especially
> if Winhose is installed anywhere, to avoid the boot sector nightmere.
> One problem I've run into is wanting to run parallel Linux systems on the
> same machine so that there is a main and a backup system.  Even adding a
> blank hard disk can mess up grub.  If PC's supported an off hard disk
> boot sector, this could significantly alleviate this issue.  If you can
> boot to thumb drive before hard disk, this is something I'd recommend
> exploring.

If you are using a distro that does SELinux, you will screw up the 
security contexts doing that. I don't believe Slack uses SELinux extended 
attributes.

There is a recovery disc for Fedora Core that works and does not muck up 
SELinux.

Kevin,

I passed both of the LPI level one tests at Free Geek.  They are
providing them at a discounted rate of $40/exam (instead of $100).
Regarding vendor neutral exams, this is what I have gathered:

Comptia's Linux+ is the easiest, and is said to represent six months of
on the job training as a Linux SysAdmin.

LPIC-1 is more difficult than Linux+ and represents 12-18 months of
experience.  That is based on talk on the LPI mailing lists. There
currently are ~28,000 LPIC-1s in the world.

LPIC-2 is significantly more difficult than LPIC-1, and represents 24-36
months experience - again garnered from the LPI mailing lists.  There
are currently ~4,800 LPIC-2's.

If you shoot for the LPIC-1 exam, here is another good site to find some
training information.


Good luck,

W. Reid Leake

File Size Limit Problem

I have been doing backups across my LAN lately and have been
encountering some file size limit issues with FC4.

The problem is this.  I have two systems:

System A (RH FC4) and system B (Knoppix)

image to system A.  All operations are done as root.

>From system B:

  dd if=/dev/hda | bzip2 | ssh systemA 'cat > file'

aborts short of a full transfer with no diagnostic

  dd if=/dev/hda | bzip2 | ssh systemA 'cd /scr ; cat > imagefile.bz2'

aborts with "File limit exceeded (bash)'

To get the transfer to work I have to start the ssh server on Knoppix
and from system A:

  ssh systemB 'dd if=/dev/hda | bzip2 ' | cat > imagefile.bz2

Both logged directly into system A or via ssh from system B into system
A "ulimit" returns "Unlimited".

* So where is the limit coming from on system A??

* How do I remove the limit that appears to be imposed with an ssh
  transfer into the FC4 (system A) system??

Carla Schroder wrote:
> O networking geeks, do we care about "datagrams" and "segments" and "packets", 
> or can we just call everything a packet without fighting over it?

IMHO they're all packets... to differentiate between the various levels
is just going in to more specifics than is usually necessary unless
you're dealing with very knowledgeable and nitpicky network engineers.

When we speak of datagrams, frames, or whatnot... does the context tell
us what layer we're dealing with even if the proper packet term isn't
used?  If not, then you're not communicating effectively with whoever
you're communicating with.

Rob

From eriberto at eriberto.pro.br  Mon Mar  6 10:29:08 2006
From: eriberto at eriberto.pro.br (Eriberto)
Date: Mon, 06 Mar 2006 15:29:08 -0300
Subject: [PLUG] IPS HLBR 1.0 released (off-topic)
Message-ID: <duhv3h$4li$10@sea.gmane.org>

IPS HLBR - Version 1.0 can detect malicious traffic using regular
expressions

Version 1.0 of Hogwash Light BR, released march 5th 2006, brings two
interesting new features. The first one is the ability of using
regular expressions to detect intrusion attempts and e-mails with
virus or phishing. The second is the use of lists with banned words.

HLBR is an IPS (Intrusion Prevention System) that reads network
traffic in the layer 2 of the OSI model. Since it works like a bridge,
it stays in-line in the network topology and doesn't need an IP
address. So, HLBR is invisible to attackers. Traffic filtering
(including the packets contents) can be done with simple rules.
Version 1.0 can use regular expressions to filter the packets. Below
is an example of rule with regular expressions:

(please see http://hlbr.sourceforge.net/hlbr-rule-1.gif)

In short, all TCP traffic destined to port 25 of the e-mail server
will be filtered. If the text:

filename="anything_different_of_line_breaks.s__c__r"

(please ignore underlines in s__c__r)

is found inside the packet, that means there are an attachment .scr in
the e-mail (virus). So this packet will suffer the action named 'virus'.
This action logs the event, dumps the malicious traffic in tcpdump
format and drops the packet. Below is an example of rule against a type
of buffer overflow attempt against DNS servers:

(please see http://hlbr.sourceforge.net/hlbr-rule-2.gif)

In this case, due to the use of pipe characters (|), HLBR will check
the traffic for the hexadecimal sequence given as an attack signature.

HLBR lets you use rules for blocking attacks against network servers.
In order to fully understand it please read our documentation at
http://hlbr.sourceforge.net/ips-en.html - explanations about the IPS
concept including charts.

HLBR site is at http://hlbr.sourceforge.net.

(Translated from Portuguese by Andr? Bertelli - andre (a) bertelli.name)

Not really.  It's closer to the clip/magazine/firearm confusion among people 
who have not been properly introduced to modern (ie last 100 years) firearm 
technology.  The clip (of ammunition) fits in the magazine, fits in to and 
feeds the firearm: Each component breaks down into a bunch of sub-components,

*really* dealing with a 7-layer burrito.

I personally am wary of people with lots of certifications.. when I
interview people its pretty easy to see who actually knows what they are
talking about in relation to the certifications they list. Some areas have
made it so easy to get the certs these days it takes little more then a few
days worth of cram sessions before you can go get it.

I personally have a CCNA and I think if you study for the certification and
can glean more then just what its trying to teach you, for instance with the
CCNA.. if you can take away the practical info about TCP/IP and networking
in general and also take in the cisco stuff as well then its beneficial.

just my .02 cents

From ron at Opus1.COM  Tue Mar  7 04:18:28 2006
From: ron at Opus1.COM (Ronald Chmara)
Date: Tue, 07 Mar 2006 04:18:28 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] ip, udp, tcp terminology
In-Reply-To: <200603061550.19828.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <200603061550.19828.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <a913ff71f5f2a85ad04db00f93dfe41b@opus1.com>

On Mar 6, 2006, at 3:50 PM, Carla Schroder wrote:
> O networking geeks, do we care about "datagrams" and "segments" and 
> "packets",
> or can we just call everything a packet without fighting over it?

Oh, dear doctors of medicine, can't we just call everything "illness", 
without talking about germs, viruses, genetics? (Okay, bad example).

Oh, dear attack/defense geeks, can't we just call everything malware, 
instead of talking about virii, trojans, and worms?

In short, no. People who work in fields where a single bad *segment* 
can slam an OS into silence, as compared to a group of segments being 
re-assembled results in crashing an OS... well, those people must know, 
and work on (and in) the differences. There are portions of 
communication which are only dangerous when combined with other 
portions, just as there are portions which by *themselves* are pretty 
brutal.

Having descriptive language helps us sort out the what, and where, of 
an attack, misbehavior, or oddity. If it were all the same, we wouldn't 
need words to describe the differences.

-Bop

On Tue, 7 Mar 2006, TedK wrote:

> On a related note, as an old guy I looked into the cheap Internet access
> offered by the AARP (PeoplePC deal for AARP members), I called and was told
> that the deal was only available for Windows users. Not that they would
> only support MS Windows you know not answer questions about Linux, but no,
> only MS Windows, sorry.

Ted,

   This is very common; I see it in the business community all the time. In a
way there's a rational explanation for this: most of these folks (AARP,
business consultants, natural resource companies, and more) are not into
computers other than as tools they must use. As such, they go with the flow
and don't even think of looking for alternatives.

   Back in 1990 when I first arrived and was working for someone else, all the
computers were DOS and not networked (except by sneakernet). Of course,
WordPerfect was the processor of choice for all the words produced. I tuned
my machine to have a black screen with grey foreground. Everyone else had the
default of white on blue and would ask me, "How'd you do that?" Never
occurred to them to look at the tool they used all the time to see what they
could do with it.

   In the intervening 16 years, nothing's changed in most places. This is not
to write that I am happy with the situation, but sometimes it's like pushing
water uphill.

Rich

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Tue Mar  7 17:00:35 2006
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Tue, 7 Mar 2006 17:00:35 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Open source drivers and patents (was: Congratulations to
	Carla)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0603070625290.2088@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0603070625290.2088@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20060308010035.GC3206@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Tue, Mar 07, 2006 at 06:38:55AM -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Carla Schroder's article in Enterprise Working Planet is one of
>   the news picks on Groklaw.net.
...

Here's Carla's article:
http://www.enterprisenetworkingplanet.com/nethub/article.php/3589561


I can tell you exactly why there are so few open source hardware
drivers.  There is no big conspiracy, at least not the one you think.  
Carla, normally so very smart about such things, and Pam at Groklaw,
who ought to know - biffed it.

The general reason is patents.  No, not to protect the patents of the
manufacturer of the device in question, but the patents NOT owned by
the manufacturer.  

Most of us agree that many patents are stupid and should not have been
issued.  However, because of recent changes in the management of the
patent office, patent examiners are actually encouraged to approve
lousy patents - it means more revenue.  With the patent office being
treated by Congress like a cash cow, the office itself gets little of
the revenue gathered by fees.  Slightly increasing the approval rate,
and spending less time per patent, and hiring some really questionable
examiners at very low salaries, and outsourcing the examination 
process overseas, allows the patent office to stay in the black.  At
the cost of some really crappy patents.  The assumption is, let the
courts battle it out.  Patents not issued means less revenue.  Duh.

But the courts are part of the problem.  Before 1982, patent plaintiffs
would shop the country for the district court with the most favorable
track record - the rates of successful attacks on patents, or successful
defenses of them, varied by a factor of 5 from district to district.
In 1982, Congress created the CAFC, the Court of Appeals for the 
Federal Court, and tasked it with patent litigation.  Unsurprisingly,
this court became a revolving door agency for judges and staff, who
would shuttle back and forth to the major patent attorney offices.
Successful litigations protecting patents skyrocketed.  The result
was incentives to get even more bad patents, by parties that had no
intent to do anything with them but blackmail manufacturers with them.
The result is even more patents.

There are now something like 500 electrotechnology patents being
issued per week.  The vast majority are poisonous dreck, often 
repetitive, overly broad, and covering existing technology.  I have a
few patents - I have seen major players like Texas Instruments take a
thesaurus to my patents and apply for patents that describe the same
invention in different words.  If I use my own patented ideas, I risk
getting taken to court for violating a copy of my own patent.

So, with perhaps 100,000 active patents, averaging 20 pages each,
covering the design of subcircuits and architectures for integrated
circuits, many overlapping and repetitive, it is nearly impossible
to design a chip without violating hundreds or thousands of patents.
Further, if a manufacturer was stupid enough to engage a large staff
to read all these stupid patents, in an attempt design around all of
them, they now open themselves up to triple damages for "knowingly"
violating a patent.  Ignorance is less expensive.

Fortunately, *finding* these patent violations is very difficult in
many cases;  tearing down a chip covered with millions of transistors
and connected in a possibly obfuscated way is enormously expensive;
it costs more than the original design.  I can design chips ONLY because
the patent vultures have a very hard time seeing what I am doing.

Imagine you are a troll at a patent mill, with your half-dozen
stupid patents on some aspect of computer graphic circuit design. 
How are you going to find out if a manufacturer has violated your
stupid patent?  A teardown of every graphics chip on the market
would cost you tens of millions of dollars, with only a small
chance of finding "your" "invention" in any particular one.  Even
if you win an enormous court settlement, it will not compensate
you for all the teardowns that did not pan out.

---- Enter open source drivers ----

What if the trolls had a clear view of the inner workings of the
targetted chips - their architecture, their clever ideas, how to use it?  

That is what an open source driver is - a complete description of
how the chip is used, mandated to be open to everyone, including the
trolls.  Rather than engage in million dollar teardowns, the trolls
merely need to Google for Linux drivers.  A search process that used
to cost tens of millions of dollars now costs thousands.  So the
trolls can spend a few thousand on a bad patent, a few more thousand
on a search, and a few thousand on retaining a lawyer.  The litigation
itself will be expensive, but the bastards at CAFC will just hold
your arms while the trolls rape you.

Only the very largest manufacturers, with big legal departments, or
the very smallest, who are too small to be worth suing, can afford
to produce open source drivers.  And there are no "small guys" in
chip manufacturing.

With the legal environment like that, the surprising thing is that
there are any open source drivers at all.  They are often produced
by reverse engineering overseas, and can still subject manufacturers
to risk.  Reverse engineering in the US subjects the open source
driver writer to the tender mercies of the Digital Millenium Copyright
Act, AKA the "keep my patent violations secret" act.  

OK, so the situation sucks.  It will remain sucky as long as people
let their congresscritters pass stuff like that.  And citizens will
do that as long as some pinheaded technologists claim that "protecting
intellectual property" is a good thing, rather than a form of rape,
and we let them get away with it, rather than spit in their faces.

----

So Carla, give the manufacturers a break.  Many would like to
provide you with open source drivers, but they will get their asses
sued off if they do.  It is a sad state of affairs, but they did
not create it - our political representatives did.  If you want to
change the situation, turn the bastards out of office.  To do that,
you will have to convince a lot of your neighbors that "intellectual
property" is not only unnecessary to technological advance, but the
biggest barrier to it.  There are a lot of people to convince, and
there are a lot of liars with Big Media bullhorns opposing you. 
But there is also the fact of Linux, which is a pretty amazing
intellectual accomplishment given the IP crowd's claim that such
things can't happen without patents...

Keith

Refs:

For more information on how the patent office got so screwed up,
read "Innovation and Its Discontents" by Jaffe and Lerner, 2004
by Princeton University Press.  

The bit about patent trolling in open source drivers is from David
Livingston(?) at RedHat.

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From johnxj at comcast.net  Tue Mar  7 21:30:57 2006
From: johnxj at comcast.net (John Jordan)
Date: Tue, 7 Mar 2006 21:30:57 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Can I make a link happen automatically?
Message-ID: <440DFB91.32373.4B078DF8@localhost>

Some time ago I installed Firefox in the 32-bit chroot environment 
on my Ubuntu-64 Breezy laptop, along with Adobe Reader and 
RealPlayer. Right after I installed it I discovered I couldn't go 
anywhere with it. Other applications in the 64-bit world had no 
problem. After much advice and suggestions from people here I 
finally determined that it was a DNS problem. The chroot 
environment was not seeing the DNS server addresses in 
/etc/resolv.conf, which apparently change whenever I connect to a 
different place, e.g., going from home to PSU, back again, etc. 

With more help from people here I now have a little command to 
enter that links the 64-bit version to the 32-bit version of resolv.conf:

sudo ln -f /etc/resolv.conf /chroot/breezy/32bits/etc/resolv.conf

This works great. However, it is a pain in the neck. I need to 
automate the process somehow. My first choice would be to create 
some kind of command that would make the link update 
automatically any time there is a change in the file in the 64-bit 
world. I.e., if /etc/resolv.conf changes it will automatically trigger 
the link command.

As a second choice, can I add the link command in front of the 
command that launches Firefox-32 (the one installed in chroot)? 
The command to launch 32-bit Firefox in the Gnome application 
drop-down menu is "dchroot -d firefox %U." Could I just stick the 
link command in front of it by adding some secret code in between 
so Linux will realize it is two commands, not just one?

Or does anyone have a better way to avoid having to open a 
terminal and type out that command and my password every time I 
go to a new place?



From ehem at m5p.com  Tue Mar  7 21:50:42 2006
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Tue, 7 Mar 2006 21:50:42 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] mounting an ISO read/write?
In-Reply-To: <20060308053101.D19AE45E9@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <200603080550.k285ogUj053426@m5p.com>

>From: AthlonRob <AthlonRob at axpr.net>
> Kurt Sussman wrote:
> > The ISO file is writable. The mount directory is writable. The loop
> > device is writable.
> 
> ISO 9660 is a read-only filesystem.  You can't just dynamically write
> data to it....

That is the way it was designed, but it might be possible to do dynamic
writing with the right hacks. I notice that recent 2.6 kernels have
support for packet writing (used for CD-RW and DVD-RW drives with RW
media). Perhaps only other filesystems read-write on RW media, but that
is something (but not portable).

>From: Kurt Sussman <plug at merlot.com>
> A deeper google suggests that ISOs are built whole, and not as
> filesystems. If it can be mounted as a filesystem, though, why can't
> someone write a 'write' function for isofs? 

It wasn't designed to handle constantly changing data. After all
originally all CDs were prerecorded. Might be possible if someone tried
though.

From aaron at madebyai.com  Tue Mar  7 23:37:36 2006
From: aaron at madebyai.com (Aaron Ten Clay)
Date: Tue, 7 Mar 2006 23:37:36 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Can I make a link happen automatically?
In-Reply-To: <440DFB91.32373.4B078DF8@localhost>
References: <440DFB91.32373.4B078DF8@localhost>
Message-ID: <200603072337.42370.aaron@madebyai.com>

> As a second choice, can I add the link command in front of the 
> command that launches Firefox-32 (the one installed in chroot)? 
> The command to launch 32-bit Firefox in the Gnome application 
> drop-down menu is "dchroot -d firefox %U." Could I just stick the 
> link command in front of it by adding some secret code in between 
> so Linux will realize it is two commands, not just one?
> 
> Or does anyone have a better way to avoid having to open a 
> terminal and type out that command and my password every time I 
> go to a new place?
> 

You could create a script to run both commands, or (not being a gnome user I don't know for sure) it may be possible to separate multiple commands with a semicolon.

Another way you could do this would be creating a cron job to run once a minute that checks the modification time of both files, and copies the resolver configuration into the chroot when it's stale.

A third option would be to investigate having your dhcp client update both files. Some of them can update multiple files, or be piped to a script which runs tee and gets both files modified. (dhcpcd is the one I'd investigate first)

-HTH
Aaron

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Wed Mar  8 02:07:49 2006
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Wed, 8 Mar 2006 02:07:49 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Open source drivers and patents (2)
In-Reply-To: <200603071730.23672.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0603070625290.2088@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<20060308010035.GC3206@gate.kl-ic.com>
	<200603071730.23672.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <20060308100749.GA6724@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Tuesday 07 March 2006 17:00, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
KL> I can tell you exactly why there are so few open source hardware
KL> drivers.  There is no big conspiracy, at least not the one you think.
KL> Carla, normally so very smart about such things, and Pam at Groklaw,
KL> who ought to know - biffed it.
KL>
KL> The general reason is patents.  No, not to protect the patents of the
KL> manufacturer of the device in question, but the patents NOT owned by
KL> the manufacturer.


On Tue, Mar 07, 2006 at 05:30:23PM -0800, Carla Schroder wrote:
CS> You're confusing two issues here- Linux support of any kind, and FOSS
CS> drivers.  The ideal would be nice well-written FOSS drivers. The
CS> patent-paranoid can still supply closed-source binary drivers.
CS> The fact is the majority of vendors are unwilling to support anything
CS> but Windows, and it's not because of lame market-share arguments.
CS> We're all grownups here, and we know it's a combination of pressure
CS> from Redmond and plain old dimwittedness. 

Keith responds:
Carla, please read what you wrote again.  You mention the lack of
open drivers, and then start spinning conspiracy theories.  I responded
to your statement about open drivers.  "Linux support of any kind" is
indeed another kettle of tofu, and is in fact at least three kettles.

I design hardware, and work with a few of the companies that produce
drivers, and actually have taken the time to ask some of these people
what their concerns are.  We had some folks from HP at a recent PLUG
meeting to talk about printer drivers.  Their concerns, both expressed
to the whole meeting and to me privately, paint a much more complex
and nuanced picture than the "pressure from Redmond" or "stupidity"
(or "wickedness" or "indifference" or "venality" or "greed" or
"Bill Gates inflatable doll fetish") theories.  

Since you feel your article was about a combination of open and
binary drivers, I will explore what you think you wrote about.
Let's look in the three (!) binary driver kettles.

Like you, I dislike binary drivers.  I dislike them because the
Kernel Gods, in their Infinite Wisdom, have decided that binary 
drivers are a Bad Thing.  They do not provide a common API that
allows one binary driver to work with all kernels, or two drivers
that work with all 2.4 and 2.6 kernels, say.  That would not be
impossible or even difficult, and it might in fact make the kernel
more robust.  But it is Politically Incorrect, because it is Not GPL. 
This is, IMHO, an example of the Linux community shooting itself
in the foot.  And I take some responsibility for that, because it
would not be difficult to fork the kernel just slightly, and
maintain a few glue routines that provide an interface for standard
binary drivers, and compile those routines into the kernels from
the main tree.  I have not helped make this happen.  Mea Culpa.

So to match all the kernels, we actually need zillions of binary
drivers for one device.  Or at least a large range of drivers that
will "insmod -f" into groups of similar kernels.   What is a
hardware manufacturer to do?  Support one driver for one kernel
variant?  Drivers for all the popular distros?  Drivers for every
combination of kernel 2.X.YY ?  They only have to support four
or five drivers for all of Windows.  Get real!

So now we get to the three kettles of binary drivers.  Manufacturers
can support (1) most kernels, or (2) a few kernels, or (3) none. 
Every kernel version they don't support lights up the phones in
Bangalore, as angry Linux geeks berate them for not supporting
Slackbuntu or RedPanties or some other obscure distro with a
tweaked kernel.  Supporting none is a lot easier. 

Blessings on those that actually make an attempt, and put up with
the foolishness that results.  They probably do it because many
manufacturers (like HP) develop drivers on Linux first, and then
port to Windoze.  Often,  the coders themselves push the Linux
drivers out into the world, without letting the bean counters 
know.  If somebody ever does a cost-benefit analysis of this,
and finds out how much Linux costs to support, we are screwed.

But again, this cacaphony of binary-phobic kernels is our fault,
not the manufacturers.  We can fix this if we choose.

I will join you in your contempt of the manufacturers who don't
mention Linux (in)-compatability.   However, in practical reality
I have found there is nothing like a Google search before buying. 
If the community says the included Linux drivers are hard to use,
I don't care if the manufacturer claims Linux compatability.  And
I don't believe the mantra of "requires Win 98, Win 2000, Win XP"
on the box if Linux folks have written of their successes.  For 
wireless cards especially, it is critical to find out what people
have had success with, because versions of products change.  The
manufacturer's sites are indeed useless.  But we know that before
we look at them, right?   Useless websites will be with us long
after Windows crumbles into dust.

The Google search is hard to do when you are standing in the aisle
at Fry's, about to purchase a "Happy Family Mixed Vegetable Brand"
gizmo and wondering if it will work.  It is bad enough to drive 20
minutes each way to Fry's from Beaverton on the offchance that the
items you want will be there.  It must be hell to drive there from
eastern Oregon, with only a vague idea of what's there (Hint:
reboxed crapola).  Thank goodness for mail order and UPS, and
friends in Portland glad to help with your shopping.  

Keith

Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

  Many people have asked about the meaning of our name. "Baidu" was
  inspired by a poem written more than 800 years ago during the Song
  Dynasty. The poem compares the search for a retreating beauty amid
  chaotic glamour with the search for one's dream while confronted by
  life's many obstacles.  "... hundreds and thousands of times, for her
  I searched in chaos, suddenly, I turned by chance, to where the lights
  were waning, and there she stood." Baidu, whose literal meaning is
  hundreds of times, represents persistent search for the ideal.

What a great story.  Makes Google look cold and heartless.

From srau at rauhaus.org  Wed Mar  8 08:53:25 2006
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Wed, 8 Mar 2006 08:53:25 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] ip, udp, tcp terminology
In-Reply-To: <200603061550.19828.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <200603061550.19828.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <20060308165325.GB13853@rauhaus.org>

* Carla Schroder <carla at bratgrrl.com> [060306 15:50]:
> O networking geeks, do we care about "datagrams" and "segments" and "packets", 
> or can we just call everything a packet without fighting over it?

I care. ;-)

The terminology I know & love is at layer 4 of the OSI model, tcp and
udp chop up the data from the higher layers in to _segments_.

At layer 3, IP wraps up those tcp or udp segments in to IP _packets_. If
the layer 2 techology is ethernet, then at layer 2 we use ethernet
_frames_.

Layer 1 is just bits on the wire...

--Stafford
