You're running Ubuntu right?  /etc/network/ifup.d (from memory, I'm at work and
there's nothing but Solaris and Windows around me) contains scripts that are
executed whenever the network interface comes up.  If you include your ln ...
command in one there the linking would happen automagically evertime the interface
came up, no matter where you were.

That thought "I need to automate the process somehow."  That's a good one.  Hold
on to it.  Great attitude to take.

Then perhaps the best solution would be to create a shell script (~/bin/chrootff.sh) like so:
----
#/bin/sh
sudo ln -f /etc/resolv.conf /chroot/breezy/32bits/etc/resolv.conf
exec dchroot -d firefox %U
----
(Don't forget to chmod u+x the script)

Then just use this script as the command for your menu entry for firefox 32 bit.
> 
> > Another way you could do this would be creating a cron job to run once
> > a minute that checks the modification time of both files, and copies
> > the resolver configuration into the chroot when it's stale.
> 
> I don't want to wait 60 seconds after booting before being able to 
> get on the net. Can a cron job be run more often, like every five 
> seconds or so? If so, would that be a drag on the system? I know 
> nothing of cron, but I'll go check it out if this is a viable solution. I 
> just don't want to bog down my computer. I read "man cron" but 
> didn't understand more than a few words of it.
> 
This really wouldn't be an ideal solution in any case. It's possible with some cron daemons to have scripts run more often than 60 seconds, but even if the overhead for the system is minimal, it exists nonetheless.

I only suggested it because you hinted more than firefox may be having issues with DNS, and it'd be one way to avoid changing the run commands for all the apps you run chrooted.

> > A third option would be to investigate having your dhcp client update
> > both files. Some of them can update multiple files, or be piped to a
> > script which runs tee and gets both files modified. (dhcpcd is the one
> > I'd investigate first)
> 
> This is over my head. I've heard of dhcp -- doesn't that have 
> something to do with the connection? I know I have to specify 
> "dhcp" in the choices in System > Administration > Networking. 
> What is "your dhcp client"? I tried "man dhcpcd" and "man dhcp," 
> but nada. Is dhcpcd something on my computer? Or on the 
> connection end? Sorry I'm too dumb about this stuff.
> 
> Thanks for the suggestions.
DHCP stands for Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol. Technical issues aside, it's how your system is able to communicate with a foreign network without you manually configuring an IP address and related information. There are several somewhat-common dhcp clients for unix/linux type OSes. dhcpcd is IMHO the most configurable of them. A lot of distros use ISC DHCP client, which is also fairly configurable but tends to be slower and is definitely bloated.

In any event, mucking around with the init scripts your distro uses to do network management to get the DHCP client to work with multiple files is not a task for the faint of heart.

HTH,
Aaron

On Wednesday 08 March 2006 02:07, Keith Lofstrom wrote:

> Keith responds:

Granted, I did not present a clear position on open vs. closed drivers. 
However, as far as conspiracy theories go, they're not theories.  The DOJ 
blew it- who gives a rip about the antique Netscape browser, sheesh. The real 
anti-competitive behavior is collusion with hardware vendors. Microsoft 
exerts tremendous pressure on its partners and resellers (perhaps "victims" 
is a better word) to support only Windows. Microsoft offers certification for 
its vendors. The price of this is extremely restrictive NDAs- the vendors 
cannot discuss anything, including their own specifications or the fact that 
the NDA even exists. When MS releases a service pack or security patch that 
breaks devices, oh well, all they have to do write new drivers and get 
re-certified. Anyone who tries to remain independent pays much higher prices 
for MS licenses, and is denied access to documentation and other essential 
resources.
  
> Like you, I dislike binary drivers.  I dislike them because the
> Kernel Gods, in their Infinite Wisdom, have decided that binary
> drivers are a Bad Thing.  They do not provide a common API that
> allows one binary driver to work with all kernels, or two drivers
> that work with all 2.4 and 2.6 kernels, say.  That would not be
> impossible or even difficult, and it might in fact make the kernel
> more robust.  But it is Politically Incorrect, because it is Not GPL.

The whole point of Linux and FOSS is not to bail out self-enslaved Redmond 
serfs, though that is a common side-effect, or to give a free ride to 
commercial hardware vendors, though again that is a common side-effect. If 
you consider FOSS to be merely "politically correct" you do not understand it 
at all.
 
> So to match all the kernels, we actually need zillions of binary
> drivers for one device.  Or at least a large range of drivers that
> will "insmod -f" into groups of similar kernels.   What is a
> hardware manufacturer to do?  Support one driver for one kernel
> variant?  Drivers for all the popular distros?  Drivers for every
> combination of kernel 2.X.YY ?  They only have to support four
> or five drivers for all of Windows.  

I cry a river. If they had not painted themselves into a very small insane 
patent/DMCA/NDA corner, which you say is the main problem, they could simply 
open the specs and let the FOSS devs and distribution maintainers take care 
of it. And, if supporting closed drivers is so difficult, how does NVidia 
support such a wide range of architectures and kernels with a very small 
number of self-installing binaries?  Consider wireless adapters- how does 
supporting a limited number of wireless chipsets present such big 
difficulties? There are a zillion different brands of wireless adapters all 
using the same few basic radio chipsets- Broadcom, Atheros, Prism, and a few 
others. One basic Atheros driver, for example, supports dozens of different 
devices. Doesn't sound so awful to me.

Another little nugget to ponder- How can so many products support Mac OSX but 
not *nix? It's a lot shorter leap to other 'nixes than it is from windoze, 
and Linux has a lot larger market share than OSX. Linux + Unix is even 
bigger.

Your posts are interesting, and they paint an even bleaker picture than the 
one I already had. As far as I can see, every woe you state is 
self-inflicted. I'm not blaming the folks in the trenches, the devs and 
engineers- they are just as victimized as us customers by shortsighted, 
dimwitted management, and the rapacious Microsoft.

No reasonable person expects perfect Linux support for every single device as 
soon as it hits the market. What most folks want is a truly competitive 
market, not the ridiculous handcuffed mess we have now. Just think of what 
the computing landscape would look like without Linux...it would be a Winduz 
wasteland, and Windows would be even awfuller than it is now, if that is 
possible.

Subject: [PLUG] Re: Open source drivers and patents (3)
In-Reply-To: <20060308172656.C42A58F14@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
References: <20060308100749.GA6724@gate.kl-ic.com>
	<20060308172656.C42A58F14@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <20060308183731.GA14499@gate.kl-ic.com>

Keith Lofstrom <keithl at kl-ic.com> wrote:
KL> Like you, I dislike binary drivers.  I dislike them because the
KL> Kernel Gods, in their Infinite Wisdom, have decided that binary 
KL> drivers are a Bad Thing.  They do not provide a common API that
KL> allows one binary driver to work with all kernels, or two drivers
KL> that work with all 2.4 and 2.6 kernels, say.  That would not be
KL> impossible or even difficult, and it might in fact make the kernel
KL> more robust.  But it is Politically Incorrect, because it is Not GPL. 
KL> This is, IMHO, an example of the Linux community shooting itself
KL> in the foot.  And I take some responsibility for that, because it
KL> would not be difficult to fork the kernel just slightly, and
KL> maintain a few glue routines that provide an interface for standard
KL> binary drivers, and compile those routines into the kernels from
KL> the main tree.  I have not helped make this happen.  Mea Culpa.

On Wed, Mar 08, 2006 at 09:26:51AM -0800, Galen Seitz wrote:
GS> I think you are underestimating the difficulting of doing this.
GS> 
GS> "You think you want a stable kernel interface, but you really do not,
GS> and you don't even know it." -- GKH
GS> 
GS> http://www.kroah.com/log/linux/stable_api_nonsense.html

A good pointer, but I think you (and perhaps Greg Kroah) misunderstand
what a binary driver interface should be.  Greg's essay regards open
source drivers, either in the main kernel tree or not.  He calls
binary driver writers "leeches", which is a slur, not an analysis, and
shows a marked misunderstanding of the motivations for binary drivers. 
I touched on that in my first posting;  for those that got here late,
binary drivers often result from avoiding costly patent litigation.

Nobody demands the schematic or the mask data for the chips in the
computers they use; it is obvious that at some level, everyone accepts
"binary drivers" if they are unable to understand them.  I am glad 
that Greg can do such great kernel coding work, but to the ordinary
user both the kernel and the chips underneath are black boxes.  The
user wants something that "just works", and doesn't care how it is
delivered.  Every one of us has this attitude for the aspects of
the world we take for granted.  It is called division of labor,
and modern civilization depends on it.

Successful systems make use of division of labor, and in technology
this occurs through defined interfaces and abstraction layers.  When
Galen designs a circuit board, he rarely concerns himself with the
chemistry of copper or the tempering of through-hole drills.  He just
follows the manufacturer's design rules for circuit board layout,
which are extremely simplified abstractions of all the picky
implementation details.  Yes, he might be able to design a smaller,
faster board if he bypassed these simplifying rules and worked at
a lower level, but his design time would increase enormously.  

Right now I am working with a client to define an interface for
a block of circuitry I am designing for their integrated circuit 
chip.  The client does not need to concern themselves with what
is inside the interface, and I don't need to concern myself with
what is outside it.  We could optimize the behavior of the system
by interpenetrating each other's domains, but we would reduce
engineering progress to a snail's crawl.  Defined interfaces are
what allow chip designers to double silicon productivity every
18 months.  If software methods had kept pace, then we could
write an operating system from scratch in an afternoon.

A defined interface in software would be a well defined set of glue
code that works in kernel space and delivers a consistent set of 
data structures and subroutine calls to the binary drivers using it. 
That will be a *slow* piece of code, because data structures must
be translated by the glue code, and legacy subroutines must be
emulated with new ones.  This whole mess of spagetti will need to
be frequently rewritten to match a rapidly changing kernel.  But 
it means the binary driver I got with my Super Whizzy Gizmo three
years ago will work with this week's kernel - slowly, perhaps.

Some high performance devices will not be supportable with this slow
technique.   Some poorly written binary device drivers will wreak
havoc from within kernel space - Greg has a good point that stability
will suffer.  In other words, welcome to Windoze!  But users like
Carla and I are demanding drivers for Linux, closed binary if that 
is the only available option, and it should be our concern if we
trade off stability for increased functionality.  A brick is very
stable but not very versatile.

Keith

Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

Subject: [PLUG] mounting an ISO read/write?
In-Reply-To: <20060308051524.GB7929@merlot.com>

	<20060308051524.GB7929@merlot.com>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

I don't know the layout of an iso9660 filesystem, but since the ISO  
is a set size and it contains both the metadata and the data  
together.  I'd imagine, there isn't any free space in the filesystem  
to write new metadata or data to....

If you have the disk space you can make a new changed iso file by:
mounting the iso
Copying the data from the iso to a writable filesystem
Making the changes to the copy
Run mkisofs to make a new iso

On Mar 7, 2006, at 9:15 PM, Kurt Sussman wrote:

> AthlonRob (AthlonRob at axpr.net) typed this ...
>> Kurt Sussman wrote:
>>> The ISO file is writable. The mount directory is writable. The loop
>>> device is writable.
>>
>> ISO 9660 is a read-only filesystem.  You can't just dynamically write
>> data to it....
>

>
> A deeper google suggests that ISOs are built whole, and not as

>
> I guess I have to build a FreeBSD machine so I can run the build

> there's a bootable CD I can use.

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Tue Mar  7 15:27:32 2006
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (plug_0 at robinson-west.com)
Date: Tue,  7 Mar 2006 15:27:32 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Vonage...
Message-ID: <1141774052.440e16e4984b5@xerxes.robinson-west.com>

Recently, my friend has switched to Vonage and she uses it over
cable.  It works well now that she has a local number.  Question,
how different are the regulations considering that Vonage is
VoIP based compared to a telephone line from the local bell?
Specifically, is privacy a problem with VoIP service?  A VoIP
phone doesn't require a specific phoneline, so how do 
the line tapping rules apply?  Major plus of Vonage, it's 
cheaper than CenturyTel's service out here in Scappoose.

Can Linux establish a dial-up ppp connection over Vonage?
Why does Vonage offer add on fax service?

One problem with her Vonage router, it's hiding her global ip
address from her.  Uge!  If she doesn't know it, she can't send
it to me over the Internet.  I offer limited access, her ip
address only, to certain services in an effort to keep those 
services private.

I set up EasyTCP so she can send me her ip address manually.
I only wrote a client for Fedora, I haven't given my friend a
Windows client.  I have a hunch that I can get the connection
source via EasyTcp and that there's a way to tunnel the session
via ssh, but how do I do ssh under Windows XP?  I've never 
installed perl to Windows XP either.

I wish Comcast would tell people what ip block their dynamically
assigned ip addresses are going to come from.  I also wish that
Comcast would stop arguing that dynamic assignment of ip addresses
makes managing their network easier.  I have a static subnet on
DSL, why is this so hard to get for cable?  Static assignment can
be done by dhcp.  If I could get her on a static ip,
I wouldn't have to monkey around to determine her current address
dynamically.

In a nutshell, I can either find a new way for my friend to determine
her global ip address from her end or I can focus on securely receiving
a message on my end so I can determine her global ip address.  Both 
approaches allow me to ip limit entry to a specific service.


If anyone knows how to serve a simple web page that tells you the
ip address that is connecting to it, that would be a good start.

Michael C. Robinson

From ianburrell at gmail.com  Wed Mar  8 12:34:33 2006
From: ianburrell at gmail.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Wed, 8 Mar 2006 12:34:33 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Vonage...
In-Reply-To: <1141774052.440e16e4984b5@xerxes.robinson-west.com>
References: <1141774052.440e16e4984b5@xerxes.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <d91f09cd0603081234w5b93f1b2ve0932979242b4225@mail.gmail.com>

On 3/7/06, plug_0 at robinson-west.com <plug_0 at robinson-west.com> wrote:
> Recently, my friend has switched to Vonage and she uses it over
> cable.  It works well now that she has a local number.  Question,
> how different are the regulations considering that Vonage is
> VoIP based compared to a telephone line from the local bell?
> Specifically, is privacy a problem with VoIP service?  A VoIP
> phone doesn't require a specific phoneline, so how do
> the line tapping rules apply?  Major plus of Vonage, it's
> cheaper than CenturyTel's service out here in Scappoose.
>

The privacy is worse with Vonage.  The audio traffic can be captured
while travelling over the Internet since it is not encrypted.  Vonage
is subject to the new Internet wiretap rules.  It can also be
wiretapped where it enters the POTS.

> Can Linux establish a dial-up ppp connection over Vonage?
> Why does Vonage offer add on fax service?
>

Modem connections aren't supported.  The adapters have special support
for fax pass-through.  They offer add-on fax service because people
want to continue to use their fax machines.

> One problem with her Vonage router, it's hiding her global ip
> address from her.  Uge!  If she doesn't know it, she can't send
> it to me over the Internet.  I offer limited access, her ip
> address only, to certain services in an effort to keep those
> services private.
>

You don't have to use the Vonage adapter in NAT mode.  I put mine
behind my Linksys router.  I use a script which gets the outside IP
address from the Linksys' admin website and uses that to setup a
DynDNS name.  I am pretty sure there is an admin site for the Vonage
adapter which does provide the external IP address.

> I wish Comcast would tell people what ip block their dynamically
> assigned ip addresses are going to come from.  I also wish that
> Comcast would stop arguing that dynamic assignment of ip addresses
> makes managing their network easier.  I have a static subnet on
> DSL, why is this so hard to get for cable?  Static assignment can
> be done by dhcp.  If I could get her on a static ip,
> I wouldn't have to monkey around to determine her current address
> dynamically.
>

The dynamic IP address assignment from Comcast is pretty static.  My
cable modem has has had the same IP address for at least a year. 
Comcast wants to make it harder for people to host servers over their
connections.  I bet it is also much easier to confgiure dynamic IP
addresses for DHCP instead of static ones.

> In a nutshell, I can either find a new way for my friend to determine
> her global ip address from her end or I can focus on securely receiving
> a message on my end so I can determine her global ip address.  Both
> approaches allow me to ip limit entry to a specific service.
>

Since this is a pretty common problem, I bet there are Windows
programs which do the job of either accessing the router admin site or
going to website to find the external IP address.  Getting you the
address is probably the issue.  You might want to setup a dyndns.org
domain name and use that.

> If anyone knows how to serve a simple web page that tells you the
> ip address that is connecting to it, that would be a good start.
>

That is pretty trivial.  The CGI environment variable REMOTE_IP holds
the remote IP address.

 - Ian

>>>>> "Carla" == Carla Schroder <carla at bratgrrl.com> writes:

Carla> Do you clean your build tree first? If you have old config,
Carla> object, and dependency files lying around from previous builds,
Carla> it will use those. Do 'make mrproper' first to start from a
Carla> pristine state. Somewheres in your Makefile it tells you what
Carla> 'make mrproper' and 'make clean' do.

Sorry, I left out that detail.  This is a clean untar'ing.  First step
is:

  $ cd /src
  $ tar xjvf /src_archive/kernel/v2.6/linux-2.6.15.6.tar.bz2
  $ cd linux-2.6.15.6
  $ cp ../linux-2.6.15.5/.config .
  $ make oldconfig
  $ make -j4
  $ su
  # make install

That's about as pristine as you are going to get.

If it's an option, I'm pretty sure the UDF spec allows for writing to
the filesystem (hence, the packet-writing CDs are formatted UDF) -- I
have no idea if the kernel supports writing to UDF (reliably) yet,
though last time I checked (2.1.x) it was "no".

Message-ID: <200603090210.k292AxSe062705@m5p.com>

>From: Wil Cooley <wcooley at nakedape.cc>
> On Tue, 2006-03-07 at 21:50 -0800, Elliott Mitchell wrote:
> > That is the way it was designed, but it might be possible to do dynamic
> > writing with the right hacks. I notice that recent 2.6 kernels have
> > support for packet writing (used for CD-RW and DVD-RW drives with RW
> > media). Perhaps only other filesystems read-write on RW media, but that
> > is something (but not portable).
> 
> I think "packet writing" is a different filesystem--UDF.

Is UDF distinct from ISO9660?

My understanding is packet writing isn't a filesystem at all, instead an
alternative mode of writing that works with optical media, instead of
conventional block-by-block which they apparently have problems with.


>From: ".Mac Account" <dwight.hubbard at mac.com>
> I don't know the layout of an iso9660 filesystem, but since the ISO
> is a set size and it contains both the metadata and the data
> together.  I'd imagine, there isn't any free space in the filesystem
> to write new metadata or data to....

Mixing metadata and data is a trivial problem. XFS and ReiserFS do it.
This merely isn't conventional Unix filesystem design. This makes
performance optimization and filesystem integrity checking more
difficult, but if everything is behaving appropriately (no power loss,
no reset button) there are no problems. Simply differing set of
parameters to work within.

From nsxfreddy at gmail.com  Wed Mar  8 22:44:46 2006
From: nsxfreddy at gmail.com (Jason R. Martin)
Date: Wed, 8 Mar 2006 22:44:46 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Can I make a link happen automatically?
In-Reply-To: <c834ec80603081404o1718c114o6738fab44d042239@mail.gmail.com>
References: <440DFB91.32373.4B078DF8@localhost>
	<c834ec80603081404o1718c114o6738fab44d042239@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <c29537840603082244ucfac2d7l13f30777cad30bb6@mail.gmail.com>

On 3/8/06, Rogan Creswick <creswick at gmail.com> wrote:
> On 3/7/06, John Jordan <johnxj at comcast.net> wrote:
> >
> > sudo ln -f /etc/resolv.conf /chroot/breezy/32bits/etc/resolv.conf
> >
>
> Could some one explain why you need to do this more than once?  Is
> something in the chroot blowing away this link periodically? If so,
> that sounds like the problem that should be fixed...

DHCP client daemons typically move the existing resolv.conf to a
backup and create a new one with the DNS info from the DHCP server, so
they can restore the original later.  The hard link would have to be
maintained with the most recent file created by the DHCP client
daemon.  As it is, I would guess the 64-bit resolv.conf he created the
link from either got unlinked (deleted) or moved to a backup which
doesn't contain the right info and isn't used by the 64-bit
application environment.

I think the easiest solution is either what Aaron suggested (a FF
script wrapper that updates the link) or investigating if there's a
place in the networking scripts to insert a post-DHCP update script.

Jason


From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu Mar  9 08:47:56 2006
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu, 09 Mar 2006 08:47:56 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] mounting an ISO read/write?
In-Reply-To: <200603090210.k292AxSe062705@m5p.com>
References: <200603090210.k292AxSe062705@m5p.com>
Message-ID: <1141922876.7216.1.camel@willow.odshp.com>

On Wed, 2006-03-08 at 18:10 -0800, Elliott Mitchell wrote:
> >From: Wil Cooley <wcooley at nakedape.cc>
> > On Tue, 2006-03-07 at 21:50 -0800, Elliott Mitchell wrote:
> > > That is the way it was designed, but it might be possible to do dynamic
> > > writing with the right hacks. I notice that recent 2.6 kernels have
> > > support for packet writing (used for CD-RW and DVD-RW drives with RW
> > > media). Perhaps only other filesystems read-write on RW media, but that
> > > is something (but not portable).
> > 
> > I think "packet writing" is a different filesystem--UDF.
> 
> Is UDF distinct from ISO9660?

Yes

> My understanding is packet writing isn't a filesystem at all, instead an
> alternative mode of writing that works with optical media, instead of
> conventional block-by-block which they apparently have problems with.

No, it isn't a filesystem, but because it works differently than the
disk-at-once or track-at-once mode that ISO9660 was designed for, it
benefits from a new filesystem.

Wikipedia has a nice set of pages on it:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_Disk_Format

Wil

Wil Cooley <wcooley at nakedape.cc>

On Wed, 8 Mar 2006 09:09:18 -0800 (PST)
"Michael Rasmussen" <mikeraz at patch.com> wrote:

> Another common element is that with each change your network interface goes down
> and comes back up.
> 
> You're running Ubuntu right?  /etc/network/ifup.d (from memory, I'm at work and
> there's nothing but Solaris and Windows around me) contains scripts that are
> executed whenever the network interface comes up.  If you include your ln ...
> command in one there the linking would happen automagically evertime the interface
> came up, no matter where you were.

This sounds like a great idea. However, I'm not sure which script to
edit. In /etc/network I have the following tree:

if-down.d
   postfix
if-post-down.d
   wireless-tools
if-pre-up.d
   wireless-tools
if-up.d
   postfix
run
   ifstate
interfaces (file)
options (file

Assuming it was the right file, I opened the if-up.d/postfix file in
gedit. Its contents are:

---------------------
#!/bin/sh -e
# Called when a new interface comes up
# Written by LaMont Jones <lamont at debian.org>

RUNNING=""
# If master is running, force a queue run to unload any mail that is
# hanging around.  Yes, sendmail is a symlink...
if [ -f /var/spool/postfix/pid/master.pid ]; then
	pid=$(sed 's/ //g' /var/spool/postfix/pid/master.pid)
	exe=$(ls -l /proc/$pid/exe 2>/dev/null | sed 's/.* //')
	if [ "X$exe" = "X/usr/lib/postfix/master" ]; then
		RUNNING="y"
	fi
fi

# start or reload Postfix as needed
if [ ! -x /sbin/resolvconf ]; then
	cp /etc/resolv.conf $(postconf -h
queue_directory)/etc/resolv.conf if [ -n "$RUNNING" ]; then
		/etc/init.d/postfix reload >/dev/null 2>&1
	fi
fi

# If master is running, force a queue run to unload any mail that is
# hanging around.  Yes, sendmail is a symlink...
if [ -n "$RUNNING" ]; then
	if [ -x /usr/sbin/sendmail ]; then
		/usr/sbin/sendmail -q >/dev/null 2>&1
	fi
fi
<sudo ln -f /etc/resolv.conf /chroot/breezy/32bits/etc/resolv.conf>
-----------------------

Not knowing anything about programming the text means nothing to me,
but I'm guessing I should just add my link command at the bottom and
resave it, like the above < > line that I added, right?

> on to it.  Great attitude to take.

From mikeraz at patch.com  Thu Mar  9 10:45:58 2006
From: mikeraz at patch.com (Michael Rasmussen)
Date: Thu, 9 Mar 2006 10:45:58 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Can I make a link happen automatically?
In-Reply-To: <20060309093550.4e4c9820.johnxj@comcast.net>
References: <440DFB91.32373.4B078DF8@localhost>
	<60678.170.135.112.12.1141837758.squirrel@mail.patch.com>
	<20060309093550.4e4c9820.johnxj@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <48617.170.135.112.12.1141929958.squirrel@mail.patch.com>


John Jason Jordan wrote:
> This sounds like a great idea. However, I'm not sure which script to
> edit. In /etc/network I have the following tree:
>
> if-down.d
> if-post-down.d
> if-pre-up.d
> if-up.d

Each of those directories contain scripts to be run when if- changes.

if == interface

so,
 if-down.d scripts are executed when an interfaces goes down
 if-up.d scripts are ...

The names of the scripts tell you what system is being affected.

So don't edit the postfix file unless you want to change the behavior of postfix.

What do you want to do?  link/copy resolve.conf  so it would make sense (at least
to me) to create a file called resolve.conf_up_to_date in if-up.d

Why?

When the interface comes up you'll have your new networking environment, that's
when you want to make the change.  resolve.conf_up_to_date is a filename that
gives you a pretty good clue as to the script actions six months from now when
you've forgotten what you did.

All it needs to contain is:

  #!/bin/bash
  ln -f /etc/resolv.conf /chroot/breezy/32bits/etc/resolv.conf

sudo's not needed becuase the thing will be run as root.

Now, some error checking would be nice, maybe log a message stating whether or not
the action was successful.  I'll leave those modifications as an exercise for the
reader.

From wcm at guinix.com  Thu Mar  9 12:21:10 2006
From: wcm at guinix.com (Wayne Marshall)
Date: 9 Mar 2006 12:21:10 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] blurb: slackmatic package build system for slackware
Message-ID: <20060309122110.59635edf@alloy.copperisle.com>

The slackmatic project is a package build system for Slackware.
It is intended to make it easy to acquire, build and install
additional software in standard Slackware ".tgz" format.

See: http://www.slackmatic.org/

Features:

 * easy to use
 * simple, transparent build specification
 * BOIM: build once, install many
 * automates 100% compliance with Slackware package policy
 * supports use of dietlibc for many packages
 * distributed port repositories

The system is non-intrusive and relies on the standard Slackware
package management utilities.  The slackmatic system simplifies
package development by centrally scripting all the download,
checksum, patch, build configure, compile, and package creation
work--so you don't have to!

The project works with Slackware and all Slackware-compatible
distributions.

We recently surpassed our first 100 port milestone, including the
following repositories:

* "ahl"
Andreas Liebe's repo contains over 20 ports including the Opera
web browser and several multimedia toolkits and libraries.
The "ahl" repository is the first place to go if you are
working with audio/video applications on Slackware.

* "clear"
Charles Lear's repo contains over 30 ports including beagle,
rubrica, and many additional desktop apps.  Checkout the "clear"
repository for a great and growing resource to enhance your
Gnome desktop environment on Slackware.

* "guinix"
For server installations, the "guinix" repository includes most
of the djb suite of software from Daniel J. Bernstein, including
qmail, djbdns, and daemontools.  All software in this repo may
be built automatically with dietlibc for tiny, tight, fast, and
secure statically-linked executables.

* "wcm"
This repo includes postgresql, sqlite, dillo, sylpheed-claws and
other applications.

The project welcomes other contributed repos, which are very
easy to set up following the online documentation.  Let us
know about your own repository and help keep slackmatic growing!

The project was developed right here in Portland, Oregon.
I would welcome the participation of any interested PLUG
members.

For more information:

  http://www.slackmatic.org/

Wayne

OK, did that. There is now a file called resolv.conf_up_to_date
containing the above two lines in /etc/network/if-up.d. I checked in
Konqueror and its properties shows that it's a shell script. I guess
that happens automatically to anything in that folder, because all I
did was save it there from gedit (had to launch gedit as root in order
to write to that folder).

Wait ... I just discovered something. In a terminal window I navigated
to /etc/network/if-up.d and did an ls command. It showed postfix and
resolv.conf_up_to_date. But postfix displayed in green, and
resolv.conf_up_to_date was just black and white. After more checking in
Konqueror I discovered that the difference was file permissions, plus
the "executable" box was not checked on resolv.conf_up_to_date. I shut
down and relaunched Konqueror with sudo, then changed the permissions
to match postfix, and checked the executable box.

Then, with root-gedit I opened resolv.conf in chroot and deleted the
entries under server, and resaved. And then I tried to go somewhere
with Firefox-32, and was satisfied when it couldn't go anywhere. 

At that point I figured I was ready to test the new script, so I shut
down and restarted. As soon as everything was up I launched Firefox-32,
expecting that it would work fine. It did not. I opened resolv.conf in
gedit and noted that the server addresses had not been replaced. So the
script didn't do anything. However, there were no error messages during
the boot process. And when I run the command from a terminal, as I have
been doing, it then adds the correct entries to resolv.conf in chroot.

> the action was successful.  I'll leave those modifications as an exercise for the

Maybe I need to figure that out in order to see what is going wrong.

On Thu, 9 Mar 2006 13:11:00 -0800 (PST)
Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> wrote:

> On Thu, 9 Mar 2006, Wayne Marshall wrote:
> 
> > The slackmatic project is a package build system for Slackware. It
> > is intended to make it easy to acquire, build and install
> > additional software in standard Slackware ".tgz" format.
> 
>    I'll take a look at this shortly. In the meantime, what does this
> give us that checkinstall doesn't?
>

Many software packages are simply not checkinstall compatible. For
example, all of the djb packages, as well as many others.

On the other hand, slackmatic build scripts may be easily written to
cope with any possible source build.

Other benefits of slackmatic:

  * full and automatic compliance with Slackware package policy (binary
ownership, stripped binaries, gzipped man pages, etc.)

  * distributed port repositories: leverage the package build work
already tested by others

  * optional integration of Felix von Leitner's dietlibc: tiny
statically-linked executables, without the overhead of GNU libc

See also the faq document for more information:

  http://www.slackmatic.org/site.cgi?faq

Thanks for your interest in slackmatic!

Wayne

This shouldn't matter, as DHCP should only change /etc/resolv.conf, not
trounce on the symlink.  I think that is where you should be looking,
symlinks don't break because the contents of the file changes.  I do
have a question, what is your 32bit resolv.conf when the symlink is
broken?  Something must be breaking it.

From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Fri, 10 Mar 2006 07:52:29 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] tee --rotate_if_exists mybatchapp.err ? 
In-Reply-To: Message from RParr <RParr@TemporalArts.COM> 
	of "Fri, 10 Mar 2006 00:54:41 GMT." <4410CE51.50608@TemporalArts.com> 
Message-ID: <20060310155234.06A0D8F14@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

RParr <RParr at TemporalArts.COM> wrote:

> I am trying to find and/or create, essentially, an enhanced version of
> the "tee" utility
> such that, when file mybatchapp.err already exists, the following command
> 
> $ mybatchapp 2>&1 | tee --rotate_if_exists mybatchapp.err
> 
> would first rotate mybatchapp.err (ala logrotate) to mybatchapp.err.1,
> rotate existing mybatchapp.err.1 to mybatchapp.err.2, etc.
> 
> My goal is to have the LAST run of mybatchapp logged into the same,
> std name.
> I have some scripts currently using temp files (ie logging into
> mybatchapp.$$.err)
> but that builds up a lot of log files and makes it difficult to write
> log analysis scripts.
> 
> I'm trying to find/create a command-line utilty because I need to
> invoke this kind of functionaliy
> from Perl scripts, bash scripts, and Java utilities.  All three let me
> easily output through a pipe into
> such a utility.
> 
> If someone knows of such a utility (or combination of utilites),
> great.  I thought I had used one in the past
> but I can not find it.

Something like this might work for you.  Keep in mind that this is GNU cp
specific.

application | (cp --backup=t /dev/null application.log;tee application.log)

Perhaps there's an easier way to piece this together, but I think this will
work.

galen


From heinlein at madboa.com  Fri Mar 10 07:56:17 2006
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 10 Mar 2006 07:56:17 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Looking for a sed script
In-Reply-To: <4410D760.8050302@gmail.com>
References: <4410D760.8050302@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.OSX.4.64.0603100745520.1358@arrowhead.galois.com>

On Thu, 9 Mar 2006, Sean Whitney wrote:

> I have a customer who has supplied me with several hundred spreadsheets
> containing several hundred rows that contain interface statistics.
>
> Unfortunately, it's in a really useful format like 44.21M or 0.356k
>
> I want to convert these to bits.
>
> I am wondering if sed can
>
> recognize a field in the nature of ( ,44.21M,) and convert that value to
> ( ,44210000, )

I'm not sure sed is the best tool for that sort of manipulation; awk 
or a general-purpose scripting language (perl, python, ruby) would 
probably serve you better. I think this snippet of perl is akin to 
what you want:

   tr/a-z/A-Z/;
   if ( /,([0-9.]+)([BKM]?),/ ) {
     ($num, $mul) = ($1, $2);
     $num *= 10**3 if $mul eq 'K';
     $num *= 10**6 if $mul eq 'M';
     $num *= 10**9 if $mul eq 'B';
     print ',', $num, ',';
   }

-- 
Paul Heinlein <> heinlein at madboa.com <> www.madboa.com

# from Paul Heinlein
# on Friday 10 March 2006 07:56 am:

>> I have a customer who has supplied me with several hundred
>> spreadsheets containing several hundred rows that contain interface
>> statistics.
>I'm not sure sed is the best tool for that sort of manipulation; awk
>or a general-purpose scripting language (perl, python, ruby) would
>probably serve you better. I think this snippet of perl is akin to
>what you want:

Better yet, since CSV is such a horrible and fragile format (maybe your 
particular CSV doesn't have arbitrary linebreaks thrown in), use the 
spreadsheet directly.

  http://search.cpan.org/~hmbrand/Spreadsheet-Read-0.14/Read.pm

That's still only going to give you access to the formatted (displayed) 
values (I guess they are statically stored in most spreadsheets.)  But, 
it should be more robust than dealing with csv.  It comes with xlscat, 
which makes a good example to crib off of.  Works on sxc, xls, etc, and 
even csv if you only want an abstraction layer.

In-Reply-To: <1142012141.4534.38.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On 10 Mar 2006, at 9:35, Derek Loree wrote:

> I think John's original idea is the best solution, create a script
> that will create the link, then launch the browser.  This script could
> then be placed in the command window for the launcher.

That's what I started to do, although without an actual script. I just 
wanted to concatenate the update link command and the 
command to launch Firefox. Unfortunately, I'm using Gnome, and I 
can't figure out if there is a magic character that tells Gnome "after 
this is a second command." I can update the link and launch 
Firefox simultaneously in the command line by putting a semicolon 
between the update link command and the command to launch 
Firefox. But if I do it in the drop-down application menu it doesn't 
work. I googled and couldn't find the answer.

I thought of doing this because even n00bie me could understand 
what I was doing. Plus, when I go to PSU I always have to launch 
Firefox in order to bring up NoCat and log in. However, now that I 
have an icon that just runs the update link command, I think it's 
actually a better solution. I have to update the link always when I 
change locations. But when I come home I am on ethernet to the 
cable and there is no NoCat. Hence, I don't really need to launch 
Firefox -- in fact, I usually don't. Instead, I need the net for 
streaming radio, which means RealPlayer, which is also in chroot. 
So having the icon do the update link command without launching 
Firefox is turning out to be a better idea anyway. 

On the other hand, if I could figure out how to do it for Firefox I 
could duplicate it for RealPlayer. After all, those are the only two 
internet apps in chroot. But sometimes the effort required to figure 
out how to do something is too great considering the benefit 
derived from the solution.

Now, if I could just get the update link command to type my 
password in for me, I would have it reduced to nothing more than 
one click. :)

Thanks to all for the discussion. :)


From dave at dhdo.org  Fri Mar 10 13:16:35 2006
From: dave at dhdo.org (Dave)
Date: Fri, 10 Mar 2006 13:16:35 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Looking for a sed script
In-Reply-To: <200603100948.11846.ewilhelm@cpan.org>
References: <4410D760.8050302@gmail.com>
	<Pine.OSX.4.64.0603100745520.1358@arrowhead.galois.com>
	<200603100948.11846.ewilhelm@cpan.org>
Message-ID: <1142025395.6854.5.camel@localhost.localdomain>

To add to the perl "don't reinvent the wheel" mantra, there are several
other options places where someone has reinvented the wheel. Depending
on how you want to get at the data and what you want to do --

http://search.cpan.org/~jzucker/DBD-CSV-0.22/lib/DBD/CSV.pm - A DBI
driver for using SQL-like queries against the CSV file.

http://search.cpan.org/~tmtm/Text-CSV-Simple-1.00/lib/Text/CSV/Simple.pm
- Simple parsing of CSV text files.  The read_file method reads the
Whole Dang Thing into a big array of list references.  (You can
optionally use want_fields to filter out unwanted columns)

And http://search.cpan.org/~alancitt/Text-CSV-0.01/CSV.pm - the heavy
hitter of the above -- make sure you read the caveats at the bottom and
do any munging on your data beforehand if needed.

From eli.stair at gmail.com  Fri Mar 10 15:18:45 2006
From: eli.stair at gmail.com (Eli Stair)
Date: Fri, 10 Mar 2006 15:18:45 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Uninterruptable Sleep: How To Wake It UP
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0603101511300.25069@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0603101511300.25069@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <f4468cae0603101518v1407f390l37e3b719fbd05d12@mail.gmail.com>

Once it's in IOwait you can't stop _that_part... check your interface
stats and you'll likely see it's still transfering the data.  Once
that is done (current/all data TX queue) it will exit.  Unfortunately,
if you killed it while it was sending you'll likely end up with a
portion of the the data in each location and possibly
missing/corrupted files.

Hindsight is 20/20, try rsync over SSH (or a piped tar) next time :)

/eli

	<Pine.LNX.4.63.0603101526570.25069@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <f4468cae0603101542s4bf2bbbdwa8bd2b78035fec5c@mail.gmail.com>

BTW, if that's a large transfer over dialup or somesuch, you can pull
the same trick as with stale NFS mounts.  Depending on kernel/mount
options, you can add an entry for the hostname in /etc/hosts, set up
an alias for the IP on your loopback or ethernet interface, and
sometimes change your routing table so it catches it locally and
presto-chango you've got a dead NFS mount you were copying over :)

Sometimes you don't have to go through all of it to work...

/eli

On 3/10/06, Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> wrote:
> On Fri, 10 Mar 2006, Eli Stair wrote:
>
> > Once it's in IOwait you can't stop _that_part... check your interface stats
> > and you'll likely see it's still transfering the data. Once that is done
> > (current/all data TX queue) it will exit. Unfortunately, if you killed it
> > while it was sending you'll likely end up with a portion of the the data in
> > each location and possibly missing/corrupted files.
>
> Eli,
>
>    If I correctly understand you, it's actually crawling the data over the
> network and will -- sometime in the next week or two -- actually finish.
> That's OK. I can live with that.
>
> > Hindsight is 20/20, try rsync over SSH (or a piped tar) next time :)
>
>    Yes. And foresight, too. I should have used cp (or scp) rather than mv;
> that works like a charm. Then I rm the directory at the source.
>
> Thanks,

From blitters at gmail.com  Fri Mar 10 16:39:34 2006
From: blitters at gmail.com (Steve D...)
Date: Fri, 10 Mar 2006 16:39:34 -0800

On 3/10/06, Lost In Space <randy.rowlette at gmail.com> wrote:
>  I am doing a presentation for SNMP tools for a Data Communications class I
> am taking and was wondering if anyone had any ideas on where to find some
> good information regarding SNMP Tools. I have googled it and come with some
> information, but would like to see if any Network Administrators have a
> preference of tools they use and maybe there own personal insights on SNMP
> tools.

  I like Cricket.  It's a useful tool, except for the killer learning
curve to get it installed and running.

The big Open Source SNMP toolkit is Net-SNMP.  It *is* da'bomb.  It
can be a bit tough to use.  The documentation is a few releases behind
the code.

  I'm currently writing a custom NMS system that uses a lot of SNMP. 
It's my third major SNMP project.  Send me an email if you need any
pointers.  I can share some scripts for using "snmptrap", snmptrapd,
and how to write custom trap handlers.

Steve D...

From scratchcomputing at gmail.com  Sat Mar 11 08:39:27 2006
From: scratchcomputing at gmail.com (Eric Wilhelm)
Date: Sat, 11 Mar 2006 08:39:27 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] [OT] Source for 110vac->12vdc converter
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0603110746350.32657@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0603110746350.32657@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200603110839.28216.ewilhelm@cpan.org>

# from Rich Shepard
# on Saturday 11 March 2006 07:50 am:

>The
>charging cradle is attached to the computer because that cradle is
> also used to synchronize it with jpilot on the workstation.

usb?

> automobile adapters that will charge it while I'm driving, but this
> trip I'll be car-less.

Seems like an extra step.  How could the phone be getting 12V over usb?  
The auto adaptor is likely a step-down DC-DC converter.

>? ?Can someone suggest a source for a wall-wart into which I can plug
> the auto adapter so I can recharge the phone while I'm gone?

Plug the cradle into a powered usb hub?  If that's too clunky, the wall 
wart you want is probably 5V (check the output voltage on your car 
charger.)  Radio shack has a large selection of tips that are 
interchangeable with their wall warts.  Believe it or not, the output 
voltage is actually much more stable under load on their wall warts 
than the ones that get shipped with most gadgets.  I guess it's a 
better class of wall wart (they are quite a bit larger and than most 
and pricey.)

--Eric

DNS problem. It looks like you're not getting the domain name servers into /etc/resolv.conf. If you can go somewhere with an IP address but not with a human-readable name, that's a DNS problem. Open /etc/resolv.conf in a text editor and see what it says. Also, 192.168.0.1 looks like the IP for yourself. If I do a whois on the second one I get:

jjj at Devil5:~$ whois 205.171.3.65

OrgName:    Qwest Communications Corporation
OrgID:      QCC-18
Address:    1801 California Street
City:       Denver
StateProv:  CO
PostalCode: 80202
Country:    US

NetRange:   205.168.0.0 - 205.171.255.255
CIDR:       205.168.0.0/14
NetName:    QWEST-INET-35
NetHandle:  NET-205-168-0-0-1
Parent:     NET-205-0-0-0-0
NetType:    Direct Allocation
NameServer: DCA-ANS-01.INET.QWEST.NET
NameServer: SVL-ANS-01.INET.QWEST.NET
Comment:    ADDRESSES WITHIN THIS BLOCK ARE NON-PORTABLE
RegDate:    1995-03-17
Updated:    2006-02-06

OrgAbuseHandle: QIA2-ARIN
OrgAbuseName:   Qwest Abuse
OrgAbusePhone:  +1-877-886-6515
OrgAbuseEmail:  abuse at qwest.net

OrgNOCHandle: QIN-ARIN
OrgNOCName:   Qwest IP NOC
OrgNOCPhone:  +1-877-886-6515
OrgNOCEmail:  support at qwestip.net

OrgTechHandle: QIA-ARIN
OrgTechName:   Qwest IP Admin
OrgTechPhone:  +1-877-886-6515
OrgTechEmail:  ipadmin at qwest.com

# ARIN WHOIS database, last updated 2006-03-10 19:10
# Enter ? for additional hints on searching ARIN's WHOIS database.
jjj at Devil5:~$

So it looks like the second one may be your domain name server. I don't know enough about how these things work to be of more help.

I agree.  I have one of those qwest actiontec gt701's and it does the same
thing.  It passes out its own ip as the first dns server, then passes out
the second of the 2 ip's that you've set for dns servers.

The only way past it for me was to manually set the /etc/resolv.conf with a
true dns server.  Although if you leave the interface configured for dhcp it
may overright the resolv.conf file the next time your reboot the system and
put the 192.168.0.1 address back in there.  It that case you may want to
configure that adapter manually.

Aaron


From carla at bratgrrl.com  Sat Mar 11 22:54:55 2006
From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Sat, 11 Mar 2006 22:54:55 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] remote ssh and nat
Message-ID: <200603112254.55118.carla@bratgrrl.com>

All right NAT gurus, here's your chance to strut your stuff. I've always taken 
the lazy way to SSH into LANs. I make an iptables rule to allow SSH into the 
gateway box:

-A INPUT -p tcp --dport 22 --sport 1024:65535 -m state --state NEW -j ACCEPT

I ssh into the gateway box, then ssh from there to whatever LAN host I 
need to get into. 

To illustrate: remotehost is a remote PC on a different network. windbag 
is my gateway/firewall, and stinkpad is a LAN host. Windbag and stinkpad are 
on 192.168.1.0/24. Windbag has two NICs, wan and lan.

carla at remotehost:~$ ssh windbag.foo.net
carla at windbag.foo.net's password:
Linux windbag 2.6.12-10-386 #1 Mon Feb 13 12:13:15 UTC 2006 i686 GNU/Linux
Last login: Sat Mar 11 17:07:24 2006 from foo-29.isp.net

carla at windbag:~$ ssh stinkpad
carla at stinkpad's password:
Last login: Sat Mar 11 17:07:50 2006 from windbag.foo.net

[carla at stinkpad ~]$

This works fine, and I don't have a pressing need to find a better way. But I 
was fiddling around and wondering, can I write rules that will let me log 
directly into stinkpad, or any other LAN host, without having to log into 
windbag first? Assume all LAN hosts have private, non-routable addresses.

I tried forwarding:

$ipt -t nat -A PREROUTING -i $WAN_IFACE -p tcp --dport 10000 -j DNAT 
--to-destination 192.168.1.12:22
$ipt -A FORWARD -p tcp -i $WAN_IFACE -o $LAN_IFACE -d 192.168.1.12 --dport 22  
-j ACCEPT

But this doesn't work, because all outgoing traffic is SNAT-ed, so the remote 
SSH client sees the same IP for all hosts, so when it sees a different host 
key it pitches a fit:

@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@
@ ? ?WARNING: REMOTE HOST IDENTIFICATION HAS CHANGED! ? ? @
@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@
IT IS POSSIBLE THAT SOMEONE IS DOING SOMETHING NASTY!

I don't want to be continually replacing host keys, or disabling 
StrictHostKeyChecking. What other options are there? (besides putting 
everything on routable IPs)

--

?Carla Schroder
?check out my "Linux Cookbook", the ultimate Linux user's
?and sysadmin's guide! http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/linuxckbk/
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

From heinlein at madboa.com  Sun Mar 12 07:14:40 2006
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sun, 12 Mar 2006 07:14:40 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] remote ssh and nat
In-Reply-To: <200603112254.55118.carla@bratgrrl.com>

On Sat, 11 Mar 2006, Carla Schroder wrote:

> I tried forwarding:
>
> $ipt -t nat -A PREROUTING -i $WAN_IFACE -p tcp --dport 10000 -j DNAT
> --to-destination 192.168.1.12:22
> $ipt -A FORWARD -p tcp -i $WAN_IFACE -o $LAN_IFACE -d 192.168.1.12 --dport 22
> -j ACCEPT
>
> But this doesn't work, because all outgoing traffic is SNAT-ed, so 
> the remote SSH client sees the same IP for all hosts, so when it 
> sees a different host key it pitches a fit:
>
> @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@
> @ ? ?WARNING: REMOTE HOST IDENTIFICATION HAS CHANGED! ? ? @
> @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@
> IT IS POSSIBLE THAT SOMEONE IS DOING SOMETHING NASTY!
>
> I don't want to be continually replacing host keys, or disabling 
> StrictHostKeyChecking. What other options are there? (besides 
> putting everything on routable IPs)

I think there are two possible solutions using nothing more than ssh 
configuration settings. In ~/.ssh/config you can set CheckHostIP to no 
or set HostKeyAlias to 192.168.1.12 (or its hostname).

I think the latter approach is the one typically used for ssh 
tunnelling; it's what I use when ssh-ing from from off-site machines 
through my home firewall to internal hosts. See ssh_config(5) for 
details.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

On Sunday 12 March 2006 07:14, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On Sat, 11 Mar 2006, Carla Schroder wrote:
> > I tried forwarding:
> >
> > $ipt -t nat -A PREROUTING -i $WAN_IFACE -p tcp --dport 10000 -j DNAT
> > --to-destination 192.168.1.12:22
> > $ipt -A FORWARD -p tcp -i $WAN_IFACE -o $LAN_IFACE -d 192.168.1.12
> > --dport 22 -j ACCEPT
> >
> > But this doesn't work, because all outgoing traffic is SNAT-ed, so
> > the remote SSH client sees the same IP for all hosts, so when it
> > sees a different host key it pitches a fit:
> >
> > @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@
> > @ ? ?WARNING: REMOTE HOST IDENTIFICATION HAS CHANGED! ? ? @
> > @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@
> > IT IS POSSIBLE THAT SOMEONE IS DOING SOMETHING NASTY!
> >
> > I don't want to be continually replacing host keys, or disabling
> > StrictHostKeyChecking. What other options are there? (besides
> > putting everything on routable IPs)
>
> I think there are two possible solutions using nothing more than ssh
> configuration settings. In ~/.ssh/config you can set CheckHostIP to no
> or set HostKeyAlias to 192.168.1.12 (or its hostname).
>
> I think the latter approach is the one typically used for ssh
> tunnelling; it's what I use when ssh-ing from from off-site machines
> through my home firewall to internal hosts. See ssh_config(5) for
> details.
>

I found what I think is the best solution, thanks to the gang at Linuxchix. 
Well, actually the best solution is "use real IPs. Death to NAT." But that 
won't happen until Y3K, when IPv6 is finally implemented. :)

The trick is to use your ~/.ssh/config file. For example, you have two hosts 
behind your NAT firewall, host1 and host2. You need something like these 
iptables rules to forward ssh traffic to the correct hosts:

$ipt -t nat -A PREROUTING -i $WAN_IFACE -p tcp --dport 10000 -j DNAT 
--to-destination 192.168.1.12:22
$ipt -A FORWARD -p tcp -i $WAN_IFACE -o $LAN_IFACE -d 192.168.1.12 --dport 22  
-j ACCEPT

$ipt -t nat -A PREROUTING -i $WAN_IFACE -p tcp --dport 10001 -j DNAT 
--to-destination 192.168.1.13:22
$ipt -A FORWARD -p tcp -i $WAN_IFACE -o $LAN_IFACE -d 192.168.1.13 --dport 22  
-j ACCEPT

In ~/.ssh/config, write this:

Host host1
HostName me.mine.net (IP address works too)
Port 10000
UserKnownHostsFile ~/.ssh/host1

Host host2
HostName me.mine.net
Port 10001
UserKnownHostsFile = ~/.ssh/host2

Log in this way:

$ ssh host1

At your first login, you'll get the usual "The authenticity of host '1.2.3.4' 
can't be established" etc foo blah. Say yes, and it will create ~/.ssh/host1 
and copy the host key to it.

SSH tunneling is simpler to use, but it has its drawbacks. This gives you 
end-to-end encryption, more control, and I think more security, especially if 
you need to keep a tight rein on users.

From ehem at m5p.com  Sun Mar 12 19:46:34 2006
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Sun, 12 Mar 2006 19:46:34 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] remote ssh and nat
In-Reply-To: <20060312200005.9B4EE457E@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <200603130346.k2D3kYFc018453@m5p.com>

>From: Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>
> On Sat, 11 Mar 2006, Carla Schroder wrote:
> > I don't want to be continually replacing host keys, or disabling 
> > StrictHostKeyChecking. What other options are there? (besides 
> > putting everything on routable IPs)
> 
> I think there are two possible solutions using nothing more than ssh 
> configuration settings. In ~/.ssh/config you can set CheckHostIP to no 
> or set HostKeyAlias to 192.168.1.12 (or its hostname).

The latter may not be as evil as the former, but it is still fairly evil.


>From: Carla Schroder <carla at bratgrrl.com>
> I found what I think is the best solution, thanks to the gang at Linuxchix. 
> Well, actually the best solution is "use real IPs. Death to NAT." But that 
> won't happen until Y3K, when IPv6 is finally implemented. :)

IPv6 is implemented, just not yet universally. I believe some ISPs in the
PDX area do in fact allow you to send IPv6 directly on their networks.

> The trick is to use your ~/.ssh/config file. For example, you have two hosts 
> behind your NAT firewall, host1 and host2. You need something like these 
> iptables rules to forward ssh traffic to the correct hosts:

> In ~/.ssh/config, write this:
> 
> Host host1
> HostName me.mine.net (IP address works too)
> Port 10000
> UserKnownHostsFile ~/.ssh/host1
> 
> Host host2
> HostName me.mine.net
> Port 10001
> UserKnownHostsFile = ~/.ssh/host2

So close to what you really wanted. Set HostKeyAlias to the hostname that
is the end point. You'll no longer need separate known hosts files.

Another trick is that known hosts files are mappings of IP addresses to
keys, but that need not be unique. Important for round-robin DNS names
is you can have the same hostname match multiple keys. This is not
appropriate for this case as you prevent SSH from verifying that you're
connecting to the appropriate host (your gateway could MitM you, and
you'd never known).

> At your first login, you'll get the usual "The authenticity of host '1.2.3.4' 
> can't be established" etc foo blah. Say yes, and it will create ~/.ssh/host1 
> and copy the host key to it.

It is pretty darn simple to create the file yourself and add the
appropriate line. Crucially, yet again you can be sure you're not getting
MitM'ed by a malicious router.

> SSH tunneling is simpler to use, but it has its drawbacks. This gives you 
> end-to-end encryption, more control, and I think more security, especially if 
> you need to keep a tight rein on users. 

SSH tunneling also gives you end-to-end security. Very definitely better
security that the scheme you've been using because your password is never
present on your gateway machine. Also allows for the paranoid case where
you don't even want to forward packets without some flavor of
authentication. You can just as easily do iptables fun in the OUTPUT
chain, rather than the FORWARD chain.

Subject: [PLUG] Linux based smart phone
Message-ID: <9AFECDC22C4D6942BDFFCBDFCDB27A97074ED613@cityemail.bit.city>


http://www.imcosys.com/html/technische_daten.html

http://www.computerworld.com/mobiletopics/mobile/story/0,10801,109438,00.htm
l?source=NLT_HW&nid=109438

 MARCH 10, 2006  (IDG NEWS SERVICE)  - Swiss company
ImCoSys AG debuted its new Linux smart phone, which
runs embedded Linux and includes additional applications
such as a browser, calendar and music player, at the
CeBIT trade show in Hanover, Germany, this week.

ImCoSys, which wrote the applications, expects the
phone to become commercially available in June in
Europe and the U.S. The lightweight device is
packed with features, including Global Positioning
System (GPS), Bluetooth and Wi-Fi. It also operates
over General Packet Radio Service (GPRS) networks.

I am going to be giving a short presentation to 20 people on Why they 
should use Linux instead of Windows. They are students. Is there 
anything else I should include? I have stats for proof of numbers

Overview of Linux and Windows

   1.

      cost

   2.

      software

   3.

      infections

   4.

      usability

   5.

      support


Cost (for 25 systems)

   1.

      Windows

         1.

            home version $2500 ($100 per 1)

               1.

                  office = 12,500 ($500 per 1)

         2.

            pro $37500 ($150 per 1)

               1.

                  office = 12,500 ($500 per 1)

         3.

            server $37,000

               1.

                  office = 12,500 ($500 per 1)

   2.

      Linux

         1.

            home users $0 to ?$70

         2.

            professional $0 to ?$100

         3.

            Server $0 to ?36,000

   3.

      Why the cost difference?

         1.

            Licensing

               1.

                  Windows pc's must have ind. Lic.

               2.

                  Linux very limited lic.

                     1.

                        Most distro's do not have lic.

                     2.

                        Most distro's can be installed many times


Software

   1.

      Windows

         1.

            lots of freeware

               1.

                  much has virus'

               2.

                  spyware

               3.

                  security vulnerabilities

         2.

            Secondary programs

               1.

                  automatically installed

                     1.

                        new free game installs

                           1.

                              game

                           2.

                              aol

                           3.

                              virus

                           4.

                              adware

                           5.

                              spyware

         3.

            Purchasable software

               1.

                  ranges from $0-$0000


   2.

      Linux

         1.

            thousands of free packages

               1.

                  no secondary packages installed

                     1.

                        NO virus

                     2.

                        NO spyware

                     3.

                        NO vulnerabilities

               2.

                  commands have to be given to install

                     1.

                        dependent packages


         2.

            Purchasable

               1.

                  few that are charged

Infections

   1.

      Windows

         1.

            easily infected by

               1.

                  virus's

               2.

                  malware

   2.

      Linux

         1.

            cannot be infected with

               1.

                  virus's

               2.

                  malware


Usability

   1.

      Windows

         1.

            standardized structure

               1.

                  cross os standardization of applets

               2.

                  very few changes between OS

         2.

            familiar

               1.

                  the widest used operating system

         3.

            easy to update

         4.

            Difficult to upgrade w/o loosing apps and docs

   2.

      Linux

         1.

            vary naming scheme

                     1.

                        some distro's call things by different names

         2.

            packages are not hiding in sub applets like windows

                     1.

                        add/remove programs is hidden in control panel

         3.

            choose many different window management

                     1.

                        xfce (menu based, very fast)

                     2.

                        fc4 (menu based, very fast)

                     3.

                        gnome (icon and menu, speedy)

                     4.

                        kde (pretty icon & menu slightly slower > gnome,
                        faster > xde)

                     5.

                        xde (WinXP look alike slightly slower)

                     6.

                        wvm (Win95 look alike, fast)



         4.

            easy

                     1.

                        common user's

                           1.

                              can learn linux in a day

                           2.

                              be very comfortable


Support

   1.

      Windows

         1.

            costly

               1.

                  1^st issue free

               2.

                  35 per issue

         2.

            repair services

               1.

                  50-100 per hour

   2.

      Linux

         1.

            free online support

               1.

                  chat groups

                     1.

                        X-Chat

                           1.

                              #linuxhelp

                           2.

                              #debian (and so on)

         2.

            free email support

               1.

                  email discussion groups

                     1.

                        PLUG

         3.

            in person support

               1.

                  Linux Clinic

               2.

                  repair services 50-100

         4.

            training

               1.

                  free through FreeGeek

                     1.

                        hardware

                     2.

                        software

               2.

                  white papers

                     1.

                        step-by-step instructions

                     2.

                        http://www.ubuntuguide.org/


Overview: Total cost of ownership is higher because Microsoft Windows 
cost more to obtain software, remove infections and support. Linux TCO 
is lower because it is inexpensive to obtain, programs support are free, 
and Linux cannot be infected with malware, spyware, virus, or malicious 
code.

On Mon, 13 Mar 2006, Christian wrote:

> I am going to be giving a short presentation to 20 people on Why they should 
> use Linux instead of Windows. They are students. Is there anything else I 
> should include? I have stats for proof of numbers
>
> Overview of Linux and Windows
>
>  1.
>
>     cost

You also need to include the cost of the equivelent apps.

With Windows, when you buy the OS you get a small number of apps.  (It 
varies depending on how you got it.  Some machines have additional apps 
bundled.) Anything beyond that is extra.  (And the prices can add up 
quick.)

Think about what it would cost to add

- An office suite
- C and C++ compilers
- HTML editors
- Image manipulation software
- Server applications (html, mail, database, etc.)
- media applications
- CD/DVD burners

and so on...

To get the same types of software for Windows that comes with most Linux 
systems would be many thousands of dollars extra.  (Plus more everytime an 
"upgrade" comes out.)

When I first started with Linux, the argument was "there was no software 
for it".  Now there is too much.

It is possible to get ported apps for Windows, but you find that sometimes 
there are limitations due to lack of features in Windows.  (Lack of fork, 
weird threading model, lack of symlinks, weird case issues on filesystems, 
etc.)

On Mon, 13 Mar 2006, Lost In Space wrote:

> Just a thought, but I believe that Linux could be infected with malware,
> spyware, viruses, and malicious code if it were created for Linux. Is this
> an incorrect thought. I may be totally incorrect as Linux does not use
> executibles as Windows does, but it does seem possible that it could be
> infected although much more difficult than Windows

It is quite possible.

They are much harder to spread, however.

Under Windows, the original assumption was that every user was the 
equivelent to root.  Not the case anymore, but so many of the apps need 
that sort of permissions to run that it is still the case on far too many 
systems. (MS Word for a very long time required the ability to modify 
system binaries in order to run.)

With Linux, users are not allowed (unless you do something stupid) to 
modify system binaries.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Mon Mar 13 09:52:25 2006
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 13 Mar 2006 09:52:25 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] got info?
In-Reply-To: <4415A910.9090204@rocksolidservice.com>
References: <4415A910.9090204@rocksolidservice.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.OSX.4.64.0603130933330.1711@arrowhead.galois.com>

On Mon, 13 Mar 2006, Christian wrote:

> I am going to be giving a short presentation to 20 people on Why 
> they should use Linux instead of Windows. They are students. Is 
> there anything else I should include? I have stats for proof of 
> numbers

The tendency in Linux/Unix is to store files and do process 
communication via open standards, while the Windows world tends to do 
so via unpublished or proprietary methods. (Note that "tendency" 
doesn't mean "hard and fast rule.") Open standards will allow you to 
work with your data more transparently and for a longer period of 
time.

The tendency in Linux/Unix is to emphasize tool building while Windows 
emphasizes tool purchasing (same note on "tendency"). Unless your 
process and data dovetail more or less exactly with a vendor's idea of 
the same, it'll be much easier to get *your* job done on a Linux box.

Not only is the cost of any individual Windows host probably 
higher than its Linux counterpart, so the cost of administering 
multiple machines higher in the Windows world. Remote, scaleable 
administration tools are typically included with Linux, while decent 
remote-administration tools are usually an additional cost in a 
Windows infrastructure.

Windows or Mac OS X is probably the better choice when

a) you absolutely need bleeding-edge hardware;

b) all you want to do is assemble what loosely may be termed
    "documents": word processing files, multimedia presentations,
    spreadsheets, audio/visual streams, e-mail messages; these apps are
    for the most part more mature on proprietary platforms;

c) you need to work and play well with an IT department that only
    supports proprietary operating systems;

d) you want to be able to play the latest and greatest games available
    for purchase in consumer electronics stores.

-- 
Paul Heinlein <> heinlein at madboa.com <> www.madboa.com

>> would it be worth attending even if you are a complete

Pete is definitely right.  In fact, that's one of the main points of the 
"(and why you should care)" bit.

Anyone with some inkling of how programming works should be able to keep 
up (e.g. you understand that the CPU doesn't speak source code, etc.)  

Those who are unfamiliar with scripting and interpreted languages but 
know Solder/Assembler/C/C++/Java may be at a disadvantage when it comes 
to groking runtime.  But there should be enough info to bootstrap you 
into the concept.

If you've worked with python, ruby, or lisp (to name a few) you're 
probably qualified for at least a little educational heckling.

The talk was primarily designed for Perl programmers that want to know 
what is going on under the hood in order to become better users of 
perl.  There is also a fair amount dedicated to the analysis of Perl 
code with the aim of refactoring large codebases.  It has already been 
in front of a room full of Perl hackers, and I think it was educational 
for all involved.

But hey.  I'm flexible.  If only two people that know assembler show up, 
I'm sure it will still be fun.

Christian wrote:
> I am going to be giving a short presentation to 20 people on Why they 
> should use Linux instead of Windows. They are students. Is there 
> anything else I should include? I have stats for proof of numbers

More than anything you should always recommend the right tool for the 
job.  I think a better approach to what /you/ are trying to do would be 
to emphasize the strengths of Linux rather than try to push dogma on to 
someone else.

> Overview: Total cost of ownership is higher because Microsoft Windows 
> cost more to obtain software, remove infections and support. Linux TCO 
> is lower because it is inexpensive to obtain, programs support are free, 
> and Linux cannot be infected with malware, spyware, virus, or malicious 
> code.

This may be true (to a point) for home users, but this is just not true 
as a blanket statement.  It requires context.  There seems to be this 
misconception that there are no ace admins in the Windows world.  On a 
corporate network it is nowhere near the problem it is with your 
neighbor if halfway properly maintained.  But I digress..

Look, go push Linux.  I like it and want more people to use it too.  But 
keep it real.  Things like learning it in a day is a world apart from 
learning half a dozen basic tasks, which is what you probably really 
meant.  Linux has no viruses or vulnerabilities and can't be infected by 
such?  C'mon!  That's an outright lie!  I could tear apart a lot more of 
your points (like Windows not having the *same* free support you speak 
of for Linux) as well but I just don't have time.

People have to know what they're getting into.  They need to know that 
many times Linux is work.  That you are rarely able to just download and 
install a program you need with Linux compared to the Windows way of 
doing things.  This is the perspective they'll be coming from, and if 
you don't speak on a level they can understand, then you haven't said 
anything at all.  You're pushed past advocate, through fanboyism and 
become an out of control train with some of what you say.

Hi,

TCO is only part of the argument. Money overshadow larger issues because 
it's quantifiable and it's money. Intangibles won the argument for me.

Open Source is fun. There is a community of people sharing the wealth and 
encouraging innovation. Nobody is trying to beat me up for license 
violations, push the latest $$upgrade$$, sell me add on stuff I don't want 
and hide the details I need to understand the systems. Don't forget, we 
have a penguin and they don't.

Open source is free. Like free speech, there is a larger world when you 
have choices and can make decisions that fit you best. In house developers 
have a new way of thinking. They can see and change source code. Network 
admins have a new world of resources. One Sunday morning my question to the 
Postfix list was answered by Weitse Venema, the author! There is a 
different culture for everyone involved in the organizations information 
systems which is difficult to appreciate until you've been there.

If you manage people, it's obvious that the most significant variable in 
the productivity equation is morale. Get out of the Microsoft gulag as fast 
as is reasonable and enjoy the fresh air.

Cheers,
Mike

Message-ID: <200603131117.14853.ewilhelm@cpan.org>

# from m0gely
# on Monday 13 March 2006 10:56 am:

While I totally agree that all advocacy should be honest and include 
full disclosure, this statement is at least a little off.

>That you are rarely able to just download and
>install a program you need with Linux compared to the Windows way of
>doing things.

Assuming that the "windows way" means stumbling across a website, 
punching in your visa# and downloading an exe, then yes Linux is not 
that.

But, Linux (the kernel) is a different beast than Windows (the OS), so 
you have to compare Distributions.

Installing packages with aptitude (on Debian (IME), and probably Ubuntu 
and Fedora) is almost always completely painless and o-so-much more 
convenient than dealing with exe installers.  I'm reminded of the 
semi-annual process of reinstalling windows and the hand-holding 
process of walking the system through the double-click, wait, click, 
wait, click, stand on head, reboot, click, reboot process of installing 
all of the third-party applications, not to mention setting up the 
desktop, hotkeys, start menu, and everything else that I get when I 
simply copy my home directory on a linux machine.

Installing from tarballs can be a real pain, but Windows gives you zero 
tools that can even compare to aptitude.  I'll also mention the fact 
that there is no semi-annual reinstall process with Linux.

Even Debian is not the "buy now", download-and-install experience, but 
only in the same sense that Mac is not that as much as Windows.  
There's no technical barrier in the way of vendors providing .deb 
packages, but there is a huge technical barrier to Windows apps being 
installed via aptitude.

--Eric

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Sun Mar 12 08:32:15 2006
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (plug_0 at robinson-west.com)

Subject: [PLUG] Vonage...

References: <1141774052.440e16e4984b5@xerxes.robinson-west.com>
	<d91f09cd0603081234w5b93f1b2ve0932979242b4225@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <1142181135.44144d0f788e6@xerxes.robinson-west.com>

> The dynamic IP address assignment from Comcast is pretty static.  My
> cable modem has has had the same IP address for at least a year. 
> Comcast wants to make it harder for people to host servers over their
> connections.  I bet it is also much easier to confgiure dynamic IP
> addresses for DHCP instead of static ones.

I don't use dynamic ip addresses privately because I don't understand how to
implement dynamic dns updates.  I'm afraid of the whole idea of letting
a computer, hopefully on the correct network, register a name in exchange for
a useful ip address.  Dynamic dns updating still looks experimental where it
is essential if you use dynamic ip assignment, unless you don't care about
being able to identify computers on your network by their ip address.
When you implement a firewall policy of computers are allowed out by 
specific ip address, you have to know which ip goes to which computer.
The other downside of dynamic ip assignment is that it becomes harder,
in the event of a dns outage for example, to ssh into a specific 
computer.

The other thing about dynamic ip assignment via dhcp, how do you network
boot a computer that has been given an ip address dynamically?

Long term, since the modem that I gave to my friend won't work over Vonage, 
I'll have to come up with another plan to provide her with backup Internet
access.  She lives close enough to me that a radio link should be possible.

Concerning Comcast's cost, why did Comcast rent her the cable modem if she
signed up for the service during a promotion that offered free cable modem
after purchasing it?  More disturbing, what is this FCC regulatory cost she
is getting nailed with considering that she doesn't have cable tv and
was told there won't be any taxes when she signed up?  Her cable bill
claims that there is a new FCC tax affecting all cable customers.

From carla at bratgrrl.com  Mon Mar 13 14:02:54 2006
From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Mon, 13 Mar 2006 14:02:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] iptables, dmz, public addys
Message-ID: <200603131402.54294.carla@bratgrrl.com>

hey all,

Here's the scenario:

Suppose I have a nice tri-homed Linux iptables firewall/gateway. Default 
filter table policies are:

$ipt -P INPUT DROP
$ipt -P FORWARD DROP
$ipt -P OUTPUT ACCEPT

My three network segments are 

wan 1.2.3.4
lan 192.168.1.1
dmz 192.168.2.1

On the dmz are a few public servers, the usual web, mail, ftp, wotever. These 
have public routable IPs. To correctly route incoming traffic to them, do I 
need only FORWARD rules? Like this:

$ipt -A FORWARD -p tcp -i $WAN_IFACE -o $DMZ_IFACE -d 1.2.3.44 --dport 80 -j 
ACCEPT

I don't want any DNAT or SNAT on the server IPs, I want to use their real IPs. 
The idea is to forward only traffic that belongs to the servers, and drop all 
the other junk at the gateway. (all them charming ssh attacks and ms sql 
worms etc. ad nauseum, thank you very much microtwits)

I'll have a limited bit of time for testing later this week, so I want to get 
it right the first time.

thanks!

On Mon, Mar 13, 2006 at 01:09:45PM -0800, m0gely wrote:
> I'm talking about something easy.  Updating Moz, or better yet getting 
> java to work in it.  Look, these things may be easy for you and me.  But 
> you don't just download the program to your desktop and run it.  There's
