There is? At least with Debian and its derivatives, Mozilla Firefox
(to use your example) is an "apt-get install firefox" away. And that's
it. It doesn't require any more configuration. As far as the average
non-technical computer user is concerned, I can't imagine they'd find
this procedure any more difficult than the usual point-n-click Windows
style of installer, which often asks them which components they want
installed, where they want to install the software, if they want
shortcuts placed here and there, etc. There are certainly plenty of
packages out there that are not of the install-and-forget variety, but
for the most part they're not the sort of desktop applications that
most people are going to care about.

On Mon, 2006-03-13 at 10:16 -0800, m0gely wrote:

> One example.  I can run XP fine on a dual 333Mhz machine I have that 
> just about croaks w/ Lindows.  CentOS is better on that machine but 
> still no where near as responsive as XP.

And there is a good reason for this.

Windows has access to the video card hardware acceleration.  

X does not.  (At least not at the level where it is needed.)

There are a couple of reasons for this.  Microsoft has information that
allows them to have drivers that make use of this information, where X
does not.  (Due to the proprietary limitations on 3d graphics
acceleration.)

This is changing however.  XGL is being worked on.  I have played with
the beta and it is as fast and responsive as any Windows product, if not
faster.  And that is with FULL eye candy mode turned on.

Want to see something cool?  Take a look at
http://getkororaa.com/#download .  It is a bootable live Linux distro.
It is .01 beta, so don't expect rock solid stability.  You will want an
nVIDIA or ATI card to run it.  (Preferably nVIDIA.  Some models of ATI
have problems.  But I repeat myself.)

Expect to see Linux pass Mac and Windows in the eye candy department
within the next few years.

On Mon, 2006-03-13 at 09:43 -0800, alan wrote:
> On Mon, 13 Mar 2006, Christian wrote:
> 
> > I am going to be giving a short presentation to 20 people on Why they should 
> > use Linux instead of Windows. They are students. Is there anything else I 
> > should include? I have stats for proof of numbers
> >
> > Overview of Linux and Windows
> >
> >  1.
> >
> >     cost
> 
> You also need to include the cost of the equivelent apps.
> 
> With Windows, when you buy the OS you get a small number of apps.  (It 
> varies depending on how you got it.  Some machines have additional apps 
> bundled.) Anything beyond that is extra.  (And the prices can add up 
> quick.)
> 
> Think about what it would cost to add
> 
> - An office suite
> - C and C++ compilers
> - HTML editors
> - Image manipulation software
> - Server applications (html, mail, database, etc.)
> - media applications
> - CD/DVD burners
> 
> and so on...
> 
> To get the same types of software for Windows that comes with most Linux 
> systems would be many thousands of dollars extra.  (Plus more everytime an 
> "upgrade" comes out.)

Personally, I wouldn't stress this point very much, the reason being
that there is so much quality freeware available for Windows, in all
those categories (with the possible exception of C/C++ compilers -- I
have no idea, never used one).  Back when I was using Windows, at some
point I made a decision to start preferring OSS over proprietary
software.  Over the course of a few months, I dropped every closed
source app I was using in favor of OSS "equivalents."  "Equivalents" in
quotes because, in fact, the OSS was in almost all cases better than the
proprietary software I'd been using.  Really, I think the only software
I was sorry to abandon was Xnews, which remains the best newsreader I've
ever used (alas, Windows only -- freeware, but not open-source).  It was
the success of this experiment that led me to Linux eventually.  I
figured if all the OSS was better than proprietary software on Windows,
than probably an open-source OS would be better than a proprietary OS
like Windows.

Also, there are superb resources for Windows users looking for freeware,
whether open-source or not.  The newsgroup alt.comp.freeware is great,
and it maintains the Pricelessware list of the best freeware, almost all
of which runs on Windows.  And there is some excellent open-source
software on Windows that just doesn't have any equal on Linux -- for
instance, foobar2000, the best damn audio player on the planet.  BSD
license, but only works on Windows.

I think it would be a mistake to pretend that you have to spend lots
more money on software once you buy Windows.  Actually, I think it would
*be* a mistake to spend more money on software if you're running
Windows, unless you have specialized needs (in which case, you'd
probably *have* to run Windows anyway).  The best stuff is free, and
that includes security apps like anti-virus and firewall software.

I wish more Linux advocates would stress the utility and all-around
awesomeness of OSS, even on proprietary platforms like Windows and OS X.
I think people would be more likely to dip their toes in the OSS world
if they were encouraged to do it from the comfort of their existing
OSes, rather than exhorted to switch OSes and deal with all the
potential for hardware hassles that exist.  Many, of course, already
have, with Firefox and OpenOffice.org.

Installing Linux *can* be easy, but it isn't necessarily easy.  Every
day on the various Debian mailing lists there are dozens of pleas for
help with various and sundry pieces of hardware that don't "just work."
But any Windows user can install Firefox or foobar2000 or CDex in 30
seconds flat, and be introduced to OSS.

-- 
Michael

There are several good shell replacements for Windows, some of them free
and open-source.  I used BB4Win (Blackbox for Windows) well before I
started using Linux.  I used another one for awhile -- can't remember
the name -- that was developed by a nice guy in Australia.  Incredibly
simple and lightweight window manager.  Windows XP runs so much better
when you don't load Explorer!

And on OS X, you can install X11 (Apple's own implementation, or via
Fink or OpenDarwin) and use any number of X DEs or WMs, including Gnome,
Fluxbox, etc.

And of course, a lot of KDE (and some Gnome) users under Linux spend a
great deal of time trying to get those DEs looking and working like OS
X.  And IceWM is a conscious effort to emulate the look and feel of
Windows 95.

Really, the notion of the desktop being tied to the OS is *so* 1994. :-)

-- 
Michael

Subject: [PLUG] Hosed rpm database...
Message-ID: <1142319402.4416692a16eb0@xerxes.robinson-west.com>

I accidentally used the P option to tar improperly again and started hosing
/var on a Fedora Core 3 system.  Forunately, I stopped the command and this
system obviously still works.  Question, is there any trick to rebuild the
rpm database?  I untarred a Fedora Core 1 var image partially over my /var
directory.  I'd love some tips to find out what files were overwritten by
my mistake.  For starters, I can output tar's messages to a file and kill
the command when it gets to var so I can tell what files are likely to be
broken.

It would be sweet with a local copy of the archive to see which files 
on my main system match the files in the copy exactly.

Silly question, but why don't the security enhancements of SE Linux protect
against clobbering /var, /dev, /etc, etcetera?

If anyone is wondering, I was trying to untar a system so I can NFS root
boot it off of this machine.  Frustratingly enough though, this is the
second time I've partially corrupted the host system.

It would make an awful lot of sense for Fedora to have a tool to rebuild
a list of what's installed from the rpms themselves.  There should be a
special installation option where rpm determines for a binary package if
that package is installed to the system already, even if the local rpm
database under /var is trashed.

From creswick at gmail.com  Tue Mar 14 11:12:42 2006
From: creswick at gmail.com (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Tue, 14 Mar 2006 11:12:42 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Gnome panel application launcher
In-Reply-To: <20060313205019.0e3d5c1a.johnxj@comcast.net>
References: <20060313204339.9ad7cc63.johnxj@comcast.net>
	<20060313205019.0e3d5c1a.johnxj@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <c834ec80603141112r258af57cj7acad8977ca32fb1@mail.gmail.com>

On 3/13/06, John Jason Jordan <johnxj at comcast.net> wrote:
> On Mon, 13 Mar 2006 20:43:39 -0800
> John Jason Jordan <johnxj at comcast.net> wrote:
>
> > Any gnome users here?
>
> Never mind. Problem was Gnome expects "gksudo" in the application launcher, not just "sudo."

FWIW, sudo expects input on stdin (standard input), which is not
typically available with a gui launcher.  One way to debug these
things is to tell the launcher to use a terminal (in gnome,
right-click on launcher -> properties, check "Run in terminal").  That
should show you what's up. gksudo is a gtk wrapper around sudo (which
you probably figured out.. in any case, that is the right way to go
about it :).

--Rogan

On Mon, 13 Mar 2006 plug_0 at robinson-west.com wrote:

> Question, is there any trick to rebuild the rpm database?

Unless rpm has seen major improvements since I did the same thing years 
ago, there is only one way to rebuild the rpm databases:

Use rpm to reinstall everything.

Supposedly there is a way to rebuild those databases that involve convoluted 
incantations & sacrificing virgins to unspeakable gods -- which is 
documented somewhere on the rpm mailing list. Tried it, it didn't work 
for me. Bleh. Next time I need the help of unspeakable supernatural 
beings, I'll just stick with a more mainstream vendor like WinTentacles 
or Crawling-Chaos-R-Us.

FWIW, if this makes you want to commit violence against someone at Red Hat, 
I'll understand.

Geoff

Before you try that, try

rpm --rebuilddb

If that gives you errors, you may have stale lock files.  I will have to 
figure out where they are.  (It is easy to do.)

If the db is totally unrecoverable, you will need to reinstall after 
making a fresh database.

I used web mail for a while - I got annoyed with it because it was
slow and I was already used to mutt.  So instead I just improved my
ssh setup, and added mindterm so I can make ssh connections from just
about any java-equipped browser.  Especially as I have ssh listening
on port 80 of my alternate IP address, so I can get past port blockages.

OTOH, I hate it when somebody hijacks a thread and changes the 
subject, and it appears I just did it.  The offending web mail app
was "twig", and it choked on the thousands of mail folders I have
collected over the years.  I hope squirrelmail is better than that.

My laptop hard drive died on me.  I have a complete backup from when I 
installed the drive in September, but would rather like to get some of 
the data I had sitting on the drive if I can.  I haven't lost anything 
critical... just a few, "oh shoot, I'll have to try and get that phone 
number again" type pieces of data I had sitting in IM logs and whatnot.

The drive boots the Linux kernel but errors with UnrecoverableError 
messages as it attempts to mount the filesystem (ReiserFS 3).  This 
leaves me unable to get ANYTHING as everything was in the single FS
(of course).  So I ask... what would you guys try and do to try and
get some of the data off the drive?  There are tools, I think, that
will skip over the sections that error out on me, to try and get as
much of the data off as possible, but I've not used them before and 
don't know for sure how I'd then try and get data off the partially 
damaged filesystem image... last I read, Reiser wasn't exactly well 
known for their recovery tools.  :-\

Again, it's not a huge deal if I lost the data... I'd just like to try 
and see what I can get off the drive before I RMA it back to Seagate - 
it is under warranty until July of 2010.  :-)

Rob

Subject: [PLUG] Cable laying permit...
In-Reply-To: <1142186973.441463dd1bc86@xerxes.robinson-west.com>

On 3/12/06, plug_0 at robinson-west.com <plug_0 at robinson-west.com> wrote:
>
> Google search string that missed totally:
>
> Scappoose Oregon cable laying permits -RV
>
> I'm curious what it costs to get the necessary permits to run your own
> cables along city streets?  Not that I can afford this now, but I am
> curious.
> Comcast obviously got permits to run their network thoughout Scappoose
> and St. Helens, what is the process for someone else to acquire similar
> permits?  If you are able to site some kind of line, do you pay property
> tax on it?


Boy this is a complicated question, the simplest answer is that the average
joe, just can't. Even big companies that want to run their own dedicated
lines from office to office  *can't*  you basicly have to go through a telco
at some point. They are the ones that own the rights to the utilities and
they don't just let every joe, bob and harry rig their own lines on their
equipment (yes, telephone poles are considered equipment) My suggestion
would be to get some cheap DSL at both locations and set up a VPN between
them, that will give you the privacy and reliability you need at a cost you
could probably manage.

*Shameless Plug* For Scappoose DSL I know that Opus:Interactive has DSL
service in the Scappose Area, I used to Intern for them a few years ago,
they are a great bunch of people so I have no shame in pimping some business
their way. They're also a local company so that is a + in my book
too.//Shameless Plug//

Laying line is generally left to the "big boys" these days, Verizon, Level3,
AT&T, Qwest...

Even in the long run you would proabaly never recoupe the cost of laying
your own line verse leasing a high speed line for a long period of time.

While competing with Comcast is obviously large scale, what about two people
> who live down the street from each other that want a dedicated network?
> Has anyone done a cable installation within a city block for a
> neighborhood
> network?


Comcast Already had the infustructure in place they have just upgraded it to
allow cleaner  signaling and such...

Why do Comcast and the local phone company essentially have Internet Access
> monopolies?


Basicly because they owned the lines WAY before anyone else and they've
managed to keep control of them wether that is a good thing or not is
debateable but really not "on-topic" for the purposes of this discussion.


I haven't heard of any significant Comcast competitors in the
> cable market, at least for Scappoose.


That is because they don't exist. Comcast owns the cable lines that run to
your house, and have thus far successfully blocked out any other provider
from using their lines to provide service. No competition makes life easier
for comcast. (It also makes our cable bill $109...)


Satellite doesn't seem to be a decent
> alternative for Internet because you usually have to have a phoneline to
> use
> it.  I know Starband offers a two way satellite, but this product isn't
> Linux friendly and it doesn't impress me.  It was installed in a company
> I worked for briefly, I think it's a Radio Shack service.


Starband and DirectWave both have 2 way Sat now, the biggest issue with Sat
Service is latency, It takes a long time to go from Ground to Sky to
Ground(NOC) to Internet to NOC to Sky to Ground. (it's a lot of hops...)


Why didn't the local cell phone companies when they put their towers in in
> Scappoose start offering high speed Internet access?


They are upgrading the cell networks to carry more and more data but when
they were constructed their main focus was (and still is) to carry as many
customers per cell tower as possible, and for the cell providers voice data
(as it should) takes precidents.


Are telephone and cable services expensive because a small number of
> players have their own private networks, or are other reasons more
> significant concerning the high cost?


Maintaining such a vast and complex network is extremely expensive, unlike
our home networks where we install a router, get our computers online and
don't think about the broad network beyond the jack, the infustructure
behind that jack needs to be constantly upgraded and maintained.

Say I want to run a high speed coax cable or phone lines from one end of
> Scappoose to the other, what would this most likely cost?


most likely you will not be able to "just do it."

Michael C. Robinson
> concerned networking enthusiast.



I hope this answers your question.

Tim Thorpe

On 14 Mar 2006, at 10:15, Christian wrote:

> sygate firewall free

Sygate personal firewall is what I use on my Windows 2000 
desktop. What I like about it is 1) unlike ZoneAlarm, it seems to 
have no bugs and evil interactions with the rest of my computer, 
and 2) even a doofus like me can figure out how to configure it, and 
3) I can stop any application from being able to get out to the net. 

The last item is really handy in this age of monopolistic software 
companies wanting their products to phone home all the time. 
Currently all Adobe products are blocked, as is Quickbooks and 
Internet Explorer.

I've used it for a long time and have never had a virus. Of course, I 
also know better than to open a file in an e-mail unless I use 
something safe. E.g., if someone sends me a Word file I'll open it 
in OpenOffice.org Writer.

Where I feel more vulnerable is with my Ubuntu-64 laptop. At home 
I am behind a router, and I did install Firestarter. But I have no idea 
how to configure Firestarter beyond the standard installation. It 
worries me when I connect at some wifi hotspot, especially places 
like coffee shops.

Subject: [PLUG] Gnome panel application launcher
In-Reply-To: <c834ec80603141112r258af57cj7acad8977ca32fb1@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20060313205019.0e3d5c1a.johnxj@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <4416D472.28779.6D96BD2F@localhost>

On 14 Mar 2006, at 11:12, Rogan Creswick wrote: 

> On 3/13/06, John Jason Jordan <johnxj at comcast.net> wrote:
> > On Mon, 13 Mar 2006 20:43:39 -0800
> > John Jason Jordan <johnxj at comcast.net> wrote:
> >
> > Never mind. Problem was Gnome expects "gksudo" in the application
> > launcher, not just "sudo."
> 
> FWIW, sudo expects input on stdin (standard input), which is not
> typically available with a gui launcher.  One way to debug these
> things is to tell the launcher to use a terminal (in gnome,
> right-click on launcher -> properties, check "Run in terminal").  That
> should show you what's up. gksudo is a gtk wrapper around sudo (which
> you probably figured out.. in any case, that is the right way to go
> about it :).

Yeah, I knew about telling the application launcher to use a 
terminal. That is how I made my little link command work. The 
command is 

sudo ln -f /etc/chroot/breezy/32bits/etc/resolv.conf /etc/resolv.conf. 


It wouldn't work by clicking on the launcher entry until I told the 
launcher to use the terminal. 


However, now that I know about gksudo I tried it, and unchecked 
the "use terminal." I expected that this would pop up the pretty GUI 
window asking for my password instead of a terminal asking for my 
password. However, it did not. Nothing happened. It just didn't work 
at all. 


Oh well, changed it back to "sudo" and "use terminal." I'll figure out 
the why of this some other day.

In-Reply-To: <659b9ea30603091741j355d035fy8f3c68c971e80358@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20060309213920.GB8701@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Thu, Mar 09, 2006 at 05:41:14PM -0800, Chris Dawson wrote:
> I am not sure RadioShack still sells those $50 wireless microphones. 
> I called all over to buy on a few weeks back and was not lucky.  They
> told me they are discountinued.

I bought one of two they had at the Washington Square Radio Shack. 
There are also two at the Beaverton Radio Shack.  The Radio Shack
website lists the local stores that have it, so you can also try
Lloyd Ccenter or Jjanzen Bbeach.  Item number 32-1257 .


> You can get one at Fry's for about $70 that works pretty well.  Can
> this be something we can jack into the podcast recording as well?

I think so.  The wireless unit has two outputs,  a 1/4" microphone
jack and an RCA line jack.  The PA sounds better off the RCA jack. 
The PA has a second speaker output, also a 1/4" phone jack.  So
either build an RCA splitter from the line jack, or else connect
to the 1/4" speaker or microphone outputs.  Let me know how you
would like to connect, and bring the appropriate cables to A.T.

So ... presenter's laptop, projector, PA, wireless, podcast ...
I think we need a bigger power strip, too!

The microphone is wired straight into the transmitter.  It seems
unidirectional, no noise cancelling, so feedback is a problem if
the gain is too high.  I suspect we will want to keep the PA a
good distance from the speaker.  The transmitter does have a large
mute button, so the presenter can stop the feedback after hearing
is destroyed but before bleeding begins.

Keith

From rsteff at comcast.net  Tue Mar 14 14:49:32 2006

Renegade Penguin wrote:

> Aren't those *power* poles not *phone* poles?  Anyone know who owns the 
> poles actually?

My knowledge is from the 1960's in Cincinnati, but I suspect that it is 
similar around the country.

Sometimes the electric utility owns the poles, and sometimes the phone 
company owns the poles. I have no idea who decided which company would 
install which poles, but once there, the other company rents space for 
their wires or cables.

I think ownership was indicated by a metal strip with numbers stamped 
thereon. I suspect it was some kind of serial number that also indicated 
  who owned the pole.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens

From sofar at foo-projects.org  Tue Mar 14 18:01:35 2006
From: sofar at foo-projects.org (sofar)
Date: Wed, 15 Mar 2006 2:01:35 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] Recovering as much as I can...
In-Reply-To: <44173637.5080908@axpr.net>
References: <44173637.5080908@axpr.net>
Message-ID: <3ccb94f430739fb7b735aa27eff9d5ba@localhost>



On Tue, 14 Mar 2006 13:31:35 -0800, AthlonRob <athlonrob at axpr.net> wrote:
> My laptop hard drive died on me.  I have a complete backup from when I
> installed the drive in September, but would rather like to get some of
> the data I had sitting on the drive if I can.  I haven't lost anything
> critical... just a few, "oh shoot, I'll have to try and get that phone
> number again" type pieces of data I had sitting in IM logs and whatnot.
> 
> The drive boots the Linux kernel but errors with UnrecoverableError
> messages as it attempts to mount the filesystem (ReiserFS 3).  This
> leaves me unable to get ANYTHING as everything was in the single FS
> (of course).  So I ask... what would you guys try and do to try and
> get some of the data off the drive? 

first thing to do before anything else:

- enter BIOS, set disc to PIO mode 0 and turn off multi-byte transfers, DMA etc.
- boot cdrom and use hdparm to turn all speed options off

This saved my life many many times on IDE drives in the 20GB-80GB range - a lot of those started dropping like lemmings on me due to temperature problems after 3 years sustained use. Dropping the speed made the (I suspect!) cache memory and controller on the disc behave

This way I have retreived all information of many ""died"" hard discs without any trouble.

Auke

On Tue, 14 Mar 2006 18:07:50 -0800, fh hillsboro <linux at frankhunt.com> wrote:
> Oops, might have spoken too soon.  I can READ mail just fine and send to
> my internal network but I can't send to any address outside my net.
> 
> I get a "Relay access denied" error.  I've seen this stuff happen in
> sendmail and know what to do about it there, but not in postfix since I
> am a n000bie.
> 
> Anybody know the solution for this???

SMTP admin class #1 - how to setup a smtp server properly ;^) (I honestly wish someone would write the notes for this tho!).

seriously, you should setup your smtp server to relay all mail to your ISP's mailhost ONLY. In postfix that would be one of these:

relayhost = [gateway.my.domain]
relayhost = [mailserver.isp.tld]

hth,

Auke

m0gely wrote:
> I don't understand the frustration here.  If one runs Windows, which has 
> no source available, why be bothered by a free and reputable, non-oss 
> addon?  The bottom line is there is no money out of your pocket.  If 
> people are *so* hung up on not having the source that they can't even 
> see the rest of the picture (again, for reputable companies) then I 
> don't know what to say.

The licenses on these "free" products are often fairly restrictive, for 
one.  If I have somebody running Windows, they absolutely need Antivirus 
protection and need some sort of a good firewall between them and the 
Internet.

Not everybody can migrate away from Windows.  To assume they can is naive.

Given that, you have a choice.  Either find a "free" product with a 
license that is nonrestrictive enough to allow your legal use of the 
software, use the software illegally, or find and use a truly free 
product out there.  I, personally, would much rather support OSS 
developers than some project out there to simply capture some of the 
market share to leverage their money making ability in the future.

But that's just me.  :-)

Rob

From chaz at bctonline.com  Tue Mar 14 20:40:53 2006
From: chaz at bctonline.com (Charles Sliger)

Subject: [PLUG] iptables, dmz, public addys
In-Reply-To: <200603131402.54294.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <B0018081273@bct-mail.bctonline.com>

Carla,
Yes, you only need FORWARD rules to let traffic get to the DMZ servers.
For greater security you can create multiple rules that are server-specific
so that traffic is restricted to the server/ports that are legitimate.
Regards,
Chaz

From: plug-bounces at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-bounces at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Carla Schroder
Sent: Monday, March 13, 2006 2:03 PM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: [PLUG] iptables, dmz, public addys

hey all,

Here's the scenario:

Suppose I have a nice tri-homed Linux iptables firewall/gateway. Default 
filter table policies are:

$ipt -P INPUT DROP
$ipt -P FORWARD DROP
$ipt -P OUTPUT ACCEPT

My three network segments are 

wan 1.2.3.4
lan 192.168.1.1
dmz 192.168.2.1

On the dmz are a few public servers, the usual web, mail, ftp, wotever.
These 
have public routable IPs. To correctly route incoming traffic to them, do I 
need only FORWARD rules? Like this:

$ipt -A FORWARD -p tcp -i $WAN_IFACE -o $DMZ_IFACE -d 1.2.3.44 --dport 80 -j

ACCEPT

I don't want any DNAT or SNAT on the server IPs, I want to use their real
IPs. 
The idea is to forward only traffic that belongs to the servers, and drop
all 
the other junk at the gateway. (all them charming ssh attacks and ms sql 
worms etc. ad nauseum, thank you very much microtwits)

I'll have a limited bit of time for testing later this week, so I want to
get 
it right the first time.

thanks!

--

?check out my "Linux Cookbook", the ultimate Linux user's

You can verify that in Postfix (/etc/postfix/main.cf) that the line 
"mynetworks" includes 127.0.0.1/8 and the internal IP address of the web 
server (assuming you're behind a firewall and don't allow relaying from 
the outside), in my case 172.16.1.10/16.  That solved "my" problems when 
I encountered that error.

Tim


From linux at frankhunt.com  Tue Mar 14 22:20:51 2006
From: linux at frankhunt.com (fh hillsboro)
Date: Tue, 14 Mar 2006 22:20:51 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Recommendations for webmail?
In-Reply-To: <4417B0A0.3050405@bruce4.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0603141632230.5091@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>	<cad3ced9b51c615943fb38cb86e10d6e@localhost>	<441774F2.3040408@frankhunt.com>	<441776F6.70505@frankhunt.com>
	<4417B0A0.3050405@bruce4.com>
Message-ID: <4417B243.4050800@frankhunt.com>

After much head scratching/banging & two bottles of Fat Tire, I came 
upon a solution.  In main.cf, based on configuration examples and advice 
from the internets, I had mynetworks_style = class.  Upon changing to 
mynetworks_style = subnet all is well, tested and working.

I'm happy now.

One more Fat Tire, then off to dreamland.

OpenWebMail has the one feature my boss required in a webmail
application: spell-check.  It has other nice features too.

I've been running it since Dec. so far it is less buggy than
SquirrelMail.  I'm actually running them both, as I already have some
users hooked on SM.

The only draw back was that no where is it documented that it won't run

version running at the same time.

well if you use DHCP it will overwrite it every time your computer
connects.... but FC4 might have some other screwy stuff changin
resolv.conf.... I don't know since I stopped using it around FC2, I
found it just installed far too many things and I like to keep my
systems slim, that and I like to know whats installed.

If you are using DHCP just make you IP static instead and redo your
resolv.conf file.... its should change again

In-Reply-To: <20060314214803.337EF8F14@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

On Tue, 2006-03-14 at 13:47 -0800, Galen Seitz wrote:
> AthlonRob <athlonrob at axpr.net> wrote:
> 
> > My laptop hard drive died on me.  I have a complete backup from when I
> > installed the drive in September, but would rather like to get some of
> > the data I had sitting on the drive if I can.  

I had similar problems about a year ago.

> > The drive boots the Linux kernel but errors with UnrecoverableError
> > messages as it attempts to mount the filesystem (ReiserFS 3).

ReiserFS is reportedly more sensitive to corruption. Chances are better
that recovery tools (all available on the live version of Knoppix) will
work. I had a similar problem with a multiboot system - a couple of the
partitions were formatted to reiserfs, a couple of others to ext3.

>   This
> > leaves me unable to get ANYTHING as everything was in the single FS
> > (of course).  So I ask... what would you guys try and do to try and
> > get some of the data off the drive?  There are tools, I think, that
> > will skip over the sections that error out on me, 

As Galen suggests, dd_rescue skips over error bits.
> 
> I haven't used it myself, but dd_rescue seems to be a popular choice.
> http://www.garloff.de/kurt/linux/ddrescue/

I think with one of the partitions, I had bunches of errors, and it
eventually borked. I had to do a "dd_rescue -r" - a reverse read, which
took a bit longer.

After completing the recovery, I tried a dd_rhelp, written by the author
of dd_rescue for more difficult situations. It worked well, just took
about 5 or 6 hours to get through a big (I don't remember how big,
probably around 10 GB) partition.

My procedure was to boot a Knoppix live CD - and connect to a FireWire
drive. I remember that it connected fine to my network, so I could have
saved in that direction as well. Once saved, you can dd the image back
to the new drive.

Thanks and good luck,
Mike

The first. Assume a single shared Internet connection for both public services 
and private LAN. The dmz NIC connects to a switch with a nice little batch of 
servers, each one with its own gen-u-wine public IP.  So I want to have each 
one Internet-accessible via its own address. I don't want to use DNAT/SNAT 
because that's just dumb when you have real routable public IPs. Performance 
hit, too complex, etc blah. I don't know if this is something that is better 
handled with iproute, or something that iptables is good for. If I had an 
actual pool of public IPs to play with I could figure it out, but alas, out 
there are many cows and few IPs.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Wed Mar 15 16:32:55 2006
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Wed, 15 Mar 2006 16:32:55 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Open source drivers and patents (3)
In-Reply-To: <1142465798.4418a5068c168@xerxes.robinson-west.com>
References: <20060308100749.GA6724@gate.kl-ic.com>
	<20060308172656.C42A58F14@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
	<20060308183731.GA14499@gate.kl-ic.com>
	<1142465798.4418a5068c168@xerxes.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <20060316003255.GC3185@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Wed, Mar 15, 2006 at 03:36:38PM -0800, plug_0 at robinson-west.com wrote:
> I've been following this discussion and have some questions:
> 
> What are patents and what are they truly intended for?

Intentions are held by people.  Which people's intentions do you care
about?

The intentions of the writers of the Constitution were primarily to
reward folks with temporary monopolies for publically disclosing trade
secrets, in particular manufacturing arts that European governments
did not want us to have.  Cash grants were considered instead, but
there was no source of funding.  Later, this became transmogrified
into rewarding original inventors.  Later, this became a reward for
lawyers working for large companies.

> How costly is it to violate a patent?

The sky is the limit.  Lemelson got over a billion dollars on a patent
that was later thrown out of court by a persistent opponent.  The
recent Blackberry suit was $160M IIRC.  Violating my patents costs
almost nothing, because I can't easily fight back.

> Why don't companies outsource Linux support to other companies?
?? Many do.   Is this a question about patents?

> How valuable is any electronic device if it is artficially limited
> by politics?

Depends.  Radios are valuable, and very limited by government.  
Big Mouth Billy Bass is useless, and unlimited by government. 
Politics is not government, but a way to choose a government.

> I hear that seeds are being patented and that farmers are under attack
> from biochemical companies.  What was the situation with patents prior to
> the Industrial Revolution verses the situation today?  Long term, will
> all the good ideas be patented making them unavailable to FOSS devs?

IBM and other large companies have huge patent portfolios they 
explicitly permit open source developers to use.  If Microsoft ever
tried to use their patent portfolio to stop Linux, IBM would use their
patent portfolio and huge legal staff to shut down Microsoft stone
cold dead.  Mutual assured destruction.  Small outfits with patents,
"patent mills", will attack anything and anybody - legalized extortion.

> To what degree should a society protect inventors through royalties
> and patents?

To the same extent that it protects prisoners with firing squads.
Inventors are not "protected" by patents,  mostly they are thwarted
by them.  Threats and protections are two different things.  So are
expectations and property.

Patents are a license to sue and create economic havoc without being
punished.  They are allegedly justified by the larger havoc that would
occur if inventors were not paid - but unlike lawyers, inventors and
others have many ways to make money besides lawsuits and extortion.
Linux, and science, and many parts of the free market show that you
can make plenty of money creating ideas without government-mandated
monopolies.


> Should patents be harder to get?

Impossible in almost all cases, except for mine :-)  There are some
interesting notions in the book "Innovation and its Discontents". 
It isn't about easier/harder, it is about appropriate and productive.
Should it be easier or harder to get money?  Depends on whether you
are talking about free exchange or robbery.

If you want a book that will reinforce some of your opinions, read
"Hot Property" by Pat Choate.  You can absorb some history from that. 
I think Choate gets quite a few things wrong, but...

There are many books on the subject of patents and their public value.
You will learn more from reading the right books than asking questions
on a technical software list.

Keith

Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

> 80

> > address?  Or are you using several dmz servers and you would like to

> >
> > Both can be done.
> 
> The first. Assume a single shared Internet connection for both public services 
> and private LAN. The dmz NIC connects to a switch with a nice little batch of 
> servers, each one with its own gen-u-wine public IP.  So I want to have each 
> one Internet-accessible via its own address. I don't want to use DNAT/SNAT 
> because that's just dumb when you have real routable public IPs. Performance 
> hit, too complex, etc blah. I don't know if this is something that is better 
> handled with iproute, or something that iptables is good for. If I had an 
> actual pool of public IPs to play with I could figure it out, but alas, out 
> there are many cows and few IPs.

You don't even want the dmz, in that case.  All you need to do is use
the router supplied by your ISP (usually called a modem by the ISP),
plug that into your switch with your firewall as one of the bunch of
nice servers.  The exception to this is if your ISP assigned a subnet to
you, then you need to setup the router as a gateway for that subnet.  In
this case, no iptables rules are needed, though they can be applied.

Good Luck,

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Thu Mar 16 08:38:18 2006
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Thu, 16 Mar 2006 08:38:18 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] New venue for advanced topics
Message-ID: <20060316163818.GB12261@gate.kl-ic.com>


I am hard of hearing.  I kludged up a PA and wireless microphone
system for Advanced Topics at Jax so I could hear the speaker over
the machine noises from the kitchen, with the side benefit that
the people in the back of the room might hear, too. 

Jax has had "jazz nights" on thursday and friday for a while, and
they are now doing it on wednesday across the hall, every wednesday
for the forseeable future.  Every time the door opens between bar
and meeting room, the music swamps the speaker and the questioners.
So the arms race escalates, and it was more difficult for me to hear
last night with the PA than without in the past.  Now that I have
something to tap into, I can use headphones, but that doesn't help
me hear the questions and it doesn't help anyone else.

In a few months, TriMet will be rerouting transit onto 3rd and 4th
street while they rebuild the mall.  It will be impossible to find
parking nearby - hauling projector and PA will become very difficult.

And Jax may decide that jazz night needs the big room on wednesdays.
We may be "out on our ears" with little warning.  Especially if the
acoustic competition reduces attendance for our meetings.

So - we should look for another place for Advanced Topics.  A new
venue will need Beer, sufficient room for 20 to 40 people,  nearby
parking, Beer, usable transit, food, and Beer.  This will be hard
to find - Alan has looked.  Someplace between the west hills and
east 39th would probably be sufficiently accessable. There are some
restaurants with space up around 11th and Burnside, but they have
inadequate Beer.  Bridgeport might work, if they have an appropriately
sized room.  Unfortunately, the McMenamins want room rent, as does
the Lab.  There are some small restaurants up near Lloyd Ccenter
that might have space, but again the Beer situation might suck. 
Beer is important for many, because it makes unprepared speakers
and nonsequitur questions tolerable.

Jax has been good for us, and I don't want to ditch them if we can
work something out.  It might be possible to move to monday night
now that football season is over, and that will give us search time
until the fall.    

Ideas?

Keith

From heinlein at madboa.com  Thu Mar 16 09:20:38 2006

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Thu Mar 16 11:12:14 2006
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Thu, 16 Mar 2006 11:12:14 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Low-end laptops for firewall routers
Message-ID: <20060316191214.GA12770@gate.kl-ic.com>


The Free Geek laptops mailing list is discussing what to do with
the pile of old low-end laptops they have accumulated.  I suggested
firewall routers - with a couple of 10Mbps PCMCIA ethernet cards
a >50MHz laptop does a decent job of firewalling a SOHO site.  They
probably also would make dandy Personal Telco node computers.

Is anyone motivated to put together a "minimum requirements" Linux
firewall router disk image?  It might be worthwhile to build a CD
with a "hard disk wipe and install" package that leaves a small
laptop ready for final configuration over the net.  Some machines
might not have CD drives; for those, floppy-based network boot might
work.  Laptops with neither a floppy or a CD would need to have their
hard drives pulled.

I imagine one remaining issue might be finding enough PCMCIA ethernet
cards and dongles to go with them.  I suspect the dongles don't end
up at Free Geek with the computers very often.

I don't have any spare cycles right now.  Anyone else looking for
a project?

Keith

Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993

Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

On Thursday 16 March 2006 11:12, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> The Free Geek laptops mailing list is discussing what to do with

> firewall routers - with a couple of 10Mbps PCMCIA ethernet cards

> I imagine one remaining issue might be finding enough PCMCIA ethernet

>
> I don't have any spare cycles right now.  Anyone else looking for
> a project?
>

Have you considered IPCop? It meets all of your requirements, except telco 
stuff- it's a complete small, specialized Linux distribution customized to be 
a complete firewall/router/intrusion detector. It comes with VPN, OpenSSH, 
Snort, DHCP, DNS cache, and bunch of other goodies. It's designed to run 
headless, and can be administered either via SSH or its HTML interface. I've 
used it on PII 233 boxes satisfactorily. It supports ethernet, dialup, 
wireless, multiple networks- all in all, quite a nice package. And it's all 
GPL.

From carla at bratgrrl.com  Thu Mar 16 12:39:10 2006

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 2006 12:39:10 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] remote ssh and nat
In-Reply-To: <200603130346.k2D3kYFc018453@m5p.com>
References: <200603130346.k2D3kYFc018453@m5p.com>
Message-ID: <200603161239.10423.carla@bratgrrl.com>

On Sunday 12 March 2006 19:46, Elliott Mitchell wrote:
> > SSH tunneling is simpler to use, but it has its drawbacks. This gives you
> > end-to-end encryption, more control, and I think more security,
> > especially if you need to keep a tight rein on users.
>
> SSH tunneling also gives you end-to-end security

Actually, it doesn't. To give an example, if you fetch your mail with an SSH 
tunnel, traffic between the remote SSH server and the mail server will be 
transmitted in the clear. This is a nice in-depth article:

http://www.securityfocus.com/infocus/1816

> Actually, it doesn't. To give an example, if you fetch your mail with an SSH 
> tunnel, traffic between the remote SSH server and the mail server will be 
> transmitted in the clear. This is a nice in-depth article:

Your example was using SSH to a gateway machine, and them SSH from the
gateway to an internal network machine. Building from that I was
suggesting merely using the first SSH connection to terminate a tunnel
into your internal network, then use SSH on top for the actual
connection.

The multiple levels of tunneling is inefficient, but it does allow the
gateway machine to do its job and still gets you into your internal
network. More significantly it means your authentication tokens are never
present in the clear on the gateway. Thus cracking the gateway merely
allows access to the internal network, it doesn't give an attacker access
to the internal machines without more work.

In this situation though, you very definitely need to verify the
destination host key, as otherwise cracking the gateway allows an
attacker to MitM you.


--

Could it be an IPv6 issue?  I ask only because that was the problem I
had, and it took me a while to figure out what was going wrong.

You could test it by firing up w3m (text mode browser/pager) and trying
to load a website with the "-4" option, which tells w3m to use IPv4
only.  If it loads with -4 and not without it, then that's probably the
issue.

From johnxj at comcast.net  Fri Mar 17 12:24:02 2006
From: johnxj at comcast.net (John Jason Jordan)
Date: Fri, 17 Mar 2006 12:24:02 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Mounting Thumb Drive
Message-ID: <20060317122402.48e1eefa.johnxj@comcast.net>

The 512 MB Cruzer thumb drive I bought on eBay arrove.

Now I need to mount it. I created a mount point as /media/thumbdrive. But I can't figure out what Linux is calling the drive. I did dmesg | tail and it seems to be /dev/sda -- at least it identifies something there as /dev/sda and having 512 MB. If I go to File > Open in any application it shows up as SanDisk Cruzer Micro.

I'm assuming it's formatted vfat, since I bought it from someone using Windows. And if it's not, that's what I need on it, because the purpose is to be able to transfer files to non-linux computers. I double-checked it by plugging it into my Windows 2000 desktop, and in My Computer it is seen as 512 MB, formatted Fat32. For kicks I dragged a small .txt file and copied it onto the thumb drive. Windows seemed to have no problem doing so, and the file now shows up on the drive in Windows Explorer.

Moving it back to the Linux computer, I tried sudo mount /dev/sda /media/thumbdrive and it said it wanted the filesystem type. So I read the man page and it seems I should insert "vfat" in between the dev and the mount point. But that doesn't work either -- all I get is the help messages with indication which feature I did wrong.

I also opened Krusader with sudo and tried to use its mount-man feature, but it can't see /dev/sda. Evidently mount-man can only mount stuff that is in fstab, and this is not in there because I'm not sure what to call it. There's already a /dev/sda in there, and it refers to my 60 GB pocket disk, which is not currently connected. I don't want to mess that up. I can't find any instructions on how to edit fstab.

At the moment the thumb drive is in a USB port on the Linux computer and all happily lit up emitting an eerie blue light. If I try to open the file I put on there (e.g., with gedit) I get the error message "Unable to mount the selected volume.:Error: given UDI is not a mountable volume."

I bet I'm just missing some little key point. :(

most usb storage devices contain a partition table and one or more partitions. You should check if you have a /dev/sda1 or similar partition device.

You can always verify that there is a partition table by doing a 'fdisk -l /dev/sda'. That should also show up any partitions on the drive. If the drive is unpartitioned (i.e. empty or unformatted) you might want to partition it and put a new filesystem on it - but that's assuming that there is nothing actually on the drive that you want to lose ;^)

Cheers

Auke

Disk /dev/sda: 512 MB, 512483328 bytes

John Jason Jordan wrote:
> But why did dmesg | tail said it was sda? 

The Thumb drive *is* /dev/sda.  That's all the kernel/hotplug was 
looking at when you plugged the thing in.  What got you was there is a 
partition on the thing.  Often thumb drives and the like don't use 
partitions, but rather just write a filesystem to the entire disk.

Rob

From aaron at madebyai.com  Fri Mar 17 14:18:59 2006
From: aaron at madebyai.com (Aaron Ten Clay)
Date: Fri, 17 Mar 2006 14:18:59 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Mounting Thumb Drive
In-Reply-To: <20060317130019.8f932756.johnxj@comcast.net>
References: <20060317122402.48e1eefa.johnxj@comcast.net>
	<Pine.LNX.4.64.0603171234340.29235@blackbox.fnordora.org>
	<20060317130019.8f932756.johnxj@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <200603171419.04615.aaron@madebyai.com>

On Fri March 17 2006 13:00, John Jason Jordan wrote:
> The -p option gave me:
> 
> Disk /dev/sda: 512 MB, 512483328 bytes
> 16 heads, 63 sectors/track, 993 cylinders
> Units = cylinders of 1008 * 512 = 516096 bytes
> 
>    Device Boot      Start         End      Blocks   Id  System
> /dev/sda1               1         992      499851+   b  W95 FAT32
> 
> So that means (aparently) that it is sda1. Acting on that supposition I tried:
> 
> [...] But why did dmesg | tail said it was sda? Or is -1 always appended? I'm just trying to figure out what syntax to use next time I want to mount it. Like, what if I want to mount it at a time when my pocket disk is already mounted on another USB port? Also, I copied the -t from some other command, but I don't know what it does or if it is necessary. And should I add it to fstab? This stuff is so confusing!

The reason there's a 1 is because the block device (sda) has a partition table (ms-dos format). There's much controversy around this scheme (and it's relative lack of flexibility in today's hotplug-world), where block devices are identified by the driver (usually h for IDE, s for scsi [including USB, Serial ATA, etc.]) and then d and the drive's ID, starting with a.

For example, a modern system might have the following:

/dev/hda <-- primary hard disk on the IDE controller
/dev/hda1 <-- first partition on the primary hard disk
/dev/hda2 <-- second partition on the primary hard disk

/dev/hdc <-- CD-rom on the IDE controller channel 2
Note that there will be no /dev/hdc1 in this case because CD-ROMs do not (usually) get disklabels or partition tables. I don't know if it'd even be possible to write one -- probably not.

When you add a new SCSI device (whether it's using usb_scsi emulation such as your flash drive or a real SCSI controller) you'll get devices like

/dev/sda <-- Some scsi disk somewhere
/dev/sda1 <-- first partition on this disk
/dev/sda2 <-- second partition on this disk

And so on. Additional scsi drives will be /dev/sdb, /dev/sdc etc.

Basically to answer your question, the number at the end of the block device identifies a partition, which is recognized seperately because partitions usually have their own filesystems. It is possible with linux to have an entire block device used as one filesystem, say for example formatting /dev/hda as reiserfs. No reason not to, but no reason not to partition either.

As far as using fstab, I find it more convenient (since I don't use an automounter) to use Labels for removable media. Example, I have a USB harddrive labelled "OUTERSEAGATE" which is specified as follows in fstab:

LABEL=OUTERSEAGATE	/mnt/data	reiserfs	defaults	0 0

But that won't work for fat filesystems as far as I know. If you only have one removable device, you can certainly modify your fstab, although it'd be possible to corrupt another device if the system tries to mount a non-vfat filesystem as vfat. Mount should avoid that, however.

HTH,
Aaron

PS, the -t shouldn't be necessary for the mount command as long as you specify the correct partition:

mount /dev/sda1 /mnt/thumbdrive

Aside from the popular sayings related to dHell, keep in mind that a boxed system is less likely to have "decent" hardware. I.e. soft-DSP and winmodems.

Especially for Linux guys, building your own system is the way to go to assure compatibility. But as posted previously on the list, if you can give us an idea of requirements we can make better recommendations. (Personally I've never trusted sales people at any computer or high-tech store)

If you don't need wireless, and you don't use dialup, chances are any box out there would work. Even a dHell. But if it's going to be a big performance machine, you definitely want to care about chipsets running the IDE and memory, there are quite a few that Linux works with but only just. (Windows is no better.)

I can be of additional help off-list, if you have more specific questions.

HTH,
Aaron

I hear ya, dude. 

When I bought my first Compaq laptop a year ago I researched for over a
month, and was finally convinced that I could run Linux on it. And then
27 days after it arrived, I shipped it back because I couldn't get the
ATI video to work. (And the Ubuntu forums are still populated with
posts from people trying to get ATI chipsets to work.)

It took me a month of research -- and the research ended up being
faulty -- because I had to run all over the web trying to find out
stuff. And I had to post queries on e-lists and bug people who had more
important things to do than put up with stupid questions from a n00b.
In the end I had to make my decision based on half a fact from here and
half an opinion from there.

Right now I am considering building myself a new desktop that will use
that Dell 30" widescreen LCD monitor at 2560 x 1200. Think I can find
out anything about it on Linux? Hah! Lots of people point me to what
kind of video card it needs, but there are several different ones. So
then I get to try to figure out which card has the features I want --
difficult enough just because I don't have any idea what the various
features do. And then I have to stumble around elsewhere trying to find
out if there are Linux drivers for the card. And if there are, then I
have to figure out if "yes there's a driver" also means "and everything
works."

 What the Linux world needs is a total, comprehensive, all-in-one-place
database of every component that has ever been used in a computer, and
a mandatory requirement that everything be posted on it.

CICADA VSC 8201 Gigabit LAN PHY chip; 
Realtek ALC880 Audio Codec.

>From what I've been able to find, all of that should be okay with a
relatively recent kernel (not a stock Debian Sarge kernel, though -- too
old).  On-board audio should be fine, it's all I've ever had.  On-board
video, though?  Supposedly, it's a good budget line chipset, so maybe
the on-board video would be fine.  I guess I could always get a video
card later, if the performance isn't very good.  It's never been clear
to me how important a video card is for something like watching on-line
video or a DVD ... every review I ever come across only talks about
gaming.  The last PC (as opposed to PPC) I had had a mid-range Nvidia
card.  When I started using Linux, at first I used the proprietary
driver that provided 3D acceleration; but after awhile, I used the
open-source nv driver.  I never noticed a difference.  This leads me to
think it's not that important.

I've also never had an AMD machine, and I've read conflicting things
about AMD vs. Intel as well.  Some give the impression that AMD is more
of a gamer's platform and Intel Pentium 4s are better at office-type
applications because of hyperthreading.  Others don't make that
distinction.  And then there's the whole 64-bit thing, which I don't
know much about, except that there's not a lot that actually takes
advantage of it.  I guess that's changing, though.

For someone who has a hard time remembering what watt light bulb to buy,
this is all rather confusing.

-- 
Michael M. -- Portland, OR -- USA

From aaron at madebyai.com  Fri Mar 17 17:51:51 2006
From: aaron at madebyai.com (Aaron Ten Clay)
Date: Fri, 17 Mar 2006 17:51:51 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] local hardware

On Fri March 17 2006 15:41, Michael M wrote:
> PC Club has a nice-looking AMD Athlon 64 2.4GHz with 512MB DDR and a
> Gigabyte motherboard with this chipset:
>  
> NVIDIA? GeForce? 6100 and NVIDIA nForce? 430; 
> Super I/O: Winbond W83627 chip; 
> Integrated peripherals; 
> VIA VT 6307 IEEE1394 controller; 
> CICADA VSC 8201 Gigabit LAN PHY chip; 
> Realtek ALC880 Audio Codec.
> 

Well, over the years my experience has generally been more comfortable using Linux on Intel-centric platforms. Intel's drivers are in the kernel for their NICs, and their P/S ATA controllers are some of the best-supported under Linux. AFAIK Intel is the only company who writes drivers that are actually distributed with the kernel. I like that, for reliability and guaranteed workingness (as much as it can be).

I've never heard of CICADA, and I configure on average 2 Linux kernels a day (I've never seen support either hacked in the kernel or natively), so that's the first red flag I notice. Also, I've had issues with realtek codecs under Linux recently, maybe the hacked drivers haven't caught up (I've never gotten their binaries to work at all)

Lately I've been recommending Intel D865GHZ boards with 3GHz Celeron Ds. The pair can be had for $120, then all you need is a hard disk drive, ram, case, and optical drive. (That board has audio, gigabit LAN, and video). And the 3GHz celeron Ds are very snappy, even without hyperthreading.

--
Aaron

This is my basic troubleshoot-DSL recipe:

1. power-cycle DSL modem
2. reboot PC

That cures most DSL silliness. If that doesn't work, did you test DNS like 
Mike Neal suggested?  Or the IPv4/6 test that Michael M. said? What does 
your /etc/resolv.conf say? Maybe you have some leftover static entries that 
don't work anymore?

To get a new DHCP lease, just run 'dhclient' or whatever DHCP client FC uses. 

You really don't need to guess, run Ethereal and you'll see exactly what is 
happening.

From debian at writemoore.net  Fri Mar 17 21:37:23 2006
From: debian at writemoore.net (Michael M)
Date: Fri, 17 Mar 2006 21:37:23 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Browser Blues - ALMOST Resolved
In-Reply-To: <016d01c64a42$4b4d1e40$6d01a8c0@RAMA>
References: <016d01c64a42$4b4d1e40$6d01a8c0@RAMA>
Message-ID: <1142660244.1983.83.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Fri, 2006-03-17 at 20:13 -0800, William A Morita wrote:
> I was too hasty with my prior posting.
> I would appear that Konquorer is operational.
> Firefox is only able retrieve pages that Konquorer had fetched.
> This is getting stranger and stranger.
> 
> Anyone, any guesses as to the root cause here?

Sounds like exactly the problem I had.  Basically, as was explained in a
previous thread a few weeks ago (when I had mentioned my problem),
there's a bug in the kernel that doesn't handle the absence of IPv6
properly.  Presumably, your ISP is not providing IPv6 yet (mine -- Qwest
-- is not).  What should happen is that when IPv6 requests go out and
don't receive a reply, the network should default to IPv4.  Or something
like that.  Instead, it just waits for a reply over IPv6.  Konqueror
works because it isn't IPv6-enabled yet, so it's only using IPv4 from
the get-go (doesn't send anything out over IPv6).  The same with w3m if
you invoke it with "-4".  Gecko-based browsers (Mozilla, Firefox,
Epiphany), however, are IPv6 enabled, so they just hang, because the
network is waiting for a reply over IPv6 that will never arrive.

I had the same thing happen with Gecko browsers you describe -- if I
browsed to any website with Konqueror or w3m -4 first, then Firefox etc.
would load the page.  Otherwise, they wouldn't load anything.  I don't
completely understand why this is the case, but my grasp of all of this
is pretty tenuous.

I don't know how you address the problem in Fedora.  In Debian, I
commented out "alias net-pf-10 ipv6" and added "alias net-pf-10 off"
in /etc/modprobe.d/aliases.  That shuts down network support of IPv6
altogether, and the problem goes away.  It's not exactly a fix, but it's
a workaround.  Fedora might be different, though.

Oh, I read that a reboot was required after
editing /etc/modprobe.d/aliases.  Apparently, just stopping and
restarting the network won't do the trick.

On Fri, 2006-03-17 at 15:12 -0800, John Jason Jordan wrote:

>  What the Linux world needs is a total, comprehensive, all-in-one-place
> database of every component that has ever been used in a computer, and
> a mandatory requirement that everything be posted on it.

I would settle for a solidly researched site that broke out components
by type and level and just focused on what is widely supported across
distributions -- i.e., here are the 10 best high-end motherboards, here
are the 10 best mid-range motherboards, 10 best low-end graphics cards,
etc.

Some distros have some specifics about hardware compatibility (Debian
does not).  Linspire actually has a decent listing, but just because
something works under Linspire doesn't mean it'll work across the board.
I can't tell you how many message board posts and like I've come across
in the past few days where someone says, "SuSe has no problem with this
xxx, but Mandrake won't detect it" or some such, even with the same
kernel version.

Linux's greatest strength -- its diversity -- is also its greatest
weakness.  The lack of standardization makes it very flexible and makes
it very difficult for the techno-semi-literate to figure out the
landscape.  Every distro has slightly different strengths, slightly
different quirks, slightly to wildly different ways of system
administration, software installation, etc.  Windows and OS X work one
way; Linuxes work any number of ways.  Of course, there are some distros
that, if they were the only choices, would drive me back to Windows or
OS X.  So I'm glad there's choice, but it creates problems that get very
frustrating at times.

One thing I'm planning on doing when I finally figure out what hardware
to buy is try FreeBSD.  It has the benefit of a centralized management
structure -- it's not just a kernel.  Even if I don't like it any
better, it'll be interesting to check out.  Plus, philosophically, I
admire the BSD license more than the GPL.

I don't know if what you're requesting is exists, but what I do when I
want a quick view of some notes somewhere is just cat the file.  If you
keep a cheat sheet of commands in a text file in your home drive, it's a

hungrier than xterm or aterm, is tabs.  Inevitably, I end up with three
or four tabs open in almost any instance.  It's like tabbed browsing ...
once you get used to it, it's hard to live without it.  I usually keep
any files I know I'm going to want to refer to and possibly edit open in
a tab.

Michael M wrote:

> Crap, maybe I should just by a Dell and be done with it.

Late reply here, but if you're considering a boxed solution, I would 
recommend Gateway or an eMachine.  For those that don't know, Gateway 
bought them out a little while ago.  Any eMachine that is black and 
solver is a Gateway.  The best part about these brands (though not true 
for all older beige models) is that they are built with off the shelf 
commodity parts.  If a power supply goes, or even a motherboard, it can 
be replaced with something you buy from Fry's or Newegg.  The new 
eMachines are not the same ball of crap they used to be.

If you're going to get a custom built machine, and you know how to swap 
out memory or upgrade a video card, then maybe you should just build it 
yourself.  It's really not that hard, and there is little tweaking if at 
all you need to do to the computer to run it optimally.  There is 
probably nothing you can do that will make any noticeable difference in 
performance.

It's echoed here many times that Freegeek will train you on building a 
machine.  The building part hasn't changed much with the new stuff. 
Maybe a couple different cables, or 'now-it's-on-the-other-side' stuff, 
but the knowledge will transfer just fine.

That being said, I recommend Newegg.  They rock, their cheap, and any 
part you get locally that has to be ordered by the store means you will 
have to wait on a part anyway.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sat Mar 18 08:28:03 2006
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sat, 18 Mar 2006 08:28:03 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Browser Blues - Continued
In-Reply-To: <015701c64a31$078d46f0$6d01a8c0@RAMA>
References: <441B0E9A.5090406@verizon.net>
	<015701c64a31$078d46f0$6d01a8c0@RAMA>
Message-ID: <20060318162803.GA7517@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Fri, Mar 17, 2006 at 06:09:45PM -0800, William A Morita wrote:
> 
> I have an Actiontec GT701-WT DSL Modem/Router with Qwest DSL service.
> I tried power cycling the DSL Modem/Router.  No Help.
> I tried plugging the network cable into the second network interface.  
> The idea being that a new MAC address would force the DHCP to generate
> a new IP.
> New IP address, but this did not change the problem, so it is likely
> not the DHCP.
> I am out of things to try,
> I am open to suggestions

Bill:

In general, you seem to be "trying things" and not "gathering data".
There are too many things that can be misconfigured, and chances are
you will be taking a random walk that diverges from a solution.  There
is not enough time in the universe to try all the different possible
combinations.

I do not use the later Fedora Cores - they are far too experimental
and much too unsupported to work with for people with my limited
experience and limited available time.  A better time investment
might be made in Ubuntu, or SUSE, or one of the many RHEL4 clones,
so that you are not dealing with a science project.  I won't go
into the differences between the three alternatives I suggest (and
there are many more good alternatives besides) but they are all
rather different but competent ways to approach the "Linux Problem",
and they are all much more finished products than Fedora Core.

That said, you are now trying to follow the "Fedora" path, and since
that shares some history with the Fedora Cores 1 and 2, Redhat 9,
and RHEL4 systems I am used to, so I will try to steer you from that
perspective.  

First, /var/log/messages is your friend.  Just about everything you
are doing will leave traces there.  You should be using "ifconfig"
to see what interfaces you are using, and what the net masks and
gateways are.  "route -n" will tell you other things about your
connection.  /etc/resolv will tell you what the "ifup" and dhcp
processes decided your name servers are.  iptables -L will tell
you about what is firewalled off.  You should be using something
like tcpdump or ethereal if the aforementioned tools don't tell
you enough, though debugging at the packet level is painful.

And of course the outputs of all of these diagnostics (and many
others) from *working* systems in similar circumstances, compared
to your outputs, will be instructive.

One good source of "working" would be a Knoppix or an Ubuntu Live
CD.  These are pretty good at connecting to a network, and they
can be started without a firewall because there is nothing for the
bad guys to rewrite.  You are not doing this as a "try something",
you are doing this to gather data about a working connection. 
Unfortunately, since both of those are Debian based, you will need
to do a lot more abstracting of data from a different set of
configuration files than the Redhat family, and since they are
live CDs not all the logging will be in place.  

The key to debugging a problem is to start with a working system and
change one thing and see what it does.  Once you understand all the
aspects of your change, you are ready to change another thing.  Changing
two or more things at once is a recipe for confusion and failure.  And
while it is working, write down important observations ( network 
configuration, DNS server addresses, a few numeric IP addresses of
test targets) so that you have something to work with when things
go wrong - and they will.

There are so many things that can go wrong with a network connection,
and with a bleeding-edge experimental distro, and with buttheaded
windoze-tunnel-vision service providers and hardware designs, that
you are very unlikely to land on top of an island of working solutions
if you dive randomly into the ocean.  You will have to do some 
navigation, and more importantly you will have to first prove to
yourself that an island actually exists.  That is what the rest of us,
and Google, can help you with;  duplicate the coordinates of somebody
elses dry land, and strike out from there.  That may involve a
different distro, cable modem, DSL provider, etc.  It may even involve
starting with a borrowed windoze system on your DSL line to see
whether that can connect properly.  At least you will be able to talk
to the windoze-addled service reps at your DSL service if the windoze
box doesn't work.

One last note about internet services;  I don't know how it works for
the various DSL providers, but Comcast wants to talk to a specific
MAC address on the other side of the cable modem.  In my case, they
talk to a particular PCMCIA ethernet card on my laptop router.  If 
I get the cards mixed up, Comcast won't talk to me any more.  The
same could be true for you.

Try bringing your box into the Linux Clinic at Free Geek tomorrow. 
If the network connection is running, we can see if your box works
with your ISP and your DSL modem out of the equation, and compare 
log files with a working RH-style system, such as my laptop.

Keith

On Friday 17 March 2006 22:15, Michael M wrote:
> On Fri, 2006-03-17 at 15:12 -0800, John Jason Jordan wrote:
> > ?What the Linux world needs is a total, comprehensive, all-in-one-place
> > database of every component that has ever been used in a computer, and
> > a mandatory requirement that everything be posted on it.
>
> I would settle for a solidly researched site that broke out components
> by type and level and just focused on what is widely supported across
> distributions -- i.e., here are the 10 best high-end motherboards, here
> are the 10 best mid-range motherboards, 10 best low-end graphics cards,
> etc.

Sooo, what's stopping you from doing this yourselves? 

Linux hardware support really isn't a big deal anymore. The two trouble spots 
are high-end video cards and wireless a/g adapters. Video is easily solved by 
sticking with NVidia, though that is a problem for folks who would rather 
support cards that use 3D FOSS drivers. ATI also makes Linux drivers, and 
they are somewhat "open", but ATI quality is not very good.

Wireless b adapters are easy, lots of them work fine on Linux. Wireless a/g 
adapters are a pain because vendors don't like to make it easy to find which 
chipsets are in them. But once you know the chipset, you're golden. Atheros 
is the friendliest to Linux, and is good quality. Netgate.com is a good place 
to buy Linux-friendly wireless gear.

Printers can be troublesome, but we've been down that road on the list many 
times, with many good answers. 

Mainboards, SATA, PATA, SCSI, USB devices, sound cards, monitors, PCI-E, 
hotplug, CD/DVD writers, etc etc all work fine. No worries.

Don't even bother with Tier 1 vendors like Dell, Gateway, and so forth. If 
you're serious about supporting Linux and want genuine Linux expertise, 
support the shops who have genuine Linux support, and have for years, like 
Penguin Computing, Monarch, Linux Certified, and Emperor Linux, to name a 
few. Or support the good local shops like people have named here. 

It's really not a big deal.

From scratchcomputing at gmail.com  Sat Mar 18 09:38:15 2006
From: scratchcomputing at gmail.com (Eric Wilhelm)
Date: Sat, 18 Mar 2006 09:38:15 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] remembering often-used commands
In-Reply-To: <441BBE80.4650.80C90296@localhost>
References: <20060317151927.1998f0d3.johnxj@comcast.net>
	<441BBE80.4650.80C90296@localhost>
Message-ID: <200603180938.15748.ewilhelm@cpan.org>

# from John Jordan
# on Saturday 18 March 2006 08:02 am:

>I'd still like something where I could just point and click to select
>often-used commands. Something like bookmarks in Firefox. As
>efficient as Linux users have made the command line, surely
>there's something out there. Maybe a "terminal" is not what I
>should be looking for.

In my experience, you really don't want much more than a text editor for 
collecting snippets of commands.  Consider what a "click to run" 
interface would imply:

  o  You must be in the right working directory or else enter absolute 
paths to all filenames.  Some commands (e.g. ps2pdf) expect to write 
output into the working directory unless explicitly told otherwise.

  o  You always want to run the command with the same filename 
arguments.  Otherwise, such a system would have to prompt you for one 
or more filenames and would either do this with a plain text-entry 
dialog or a file-chooser (both of which (depending on the GUI toolkit) 
can have tab complete, at the expense of some extra code.)

If the commands of which you speak really are repetitive and predictable 
enough such that the above two points are non-issues, then it is best 
to either make them into cron jobs or scripts.  Cron jobs run on a 
timer, scripts run when you say "name_of_my_script".

As for the rest...  Given that the shell has tab-complete, typing most 
commands and filenames usually reduces to a series of 2-3 letter groups 
joined by tabs for me.  I realize that doesn't help if you don't 
remember the first couple letters.  My own memory is also less than 
perfect, so I have a few directories full of snippets in various 
languages for just this reason.  Grep does a great job of digging up 
history that no amount of head-scratching would ever manage to 
correctly retrieve.

--Eric

Turns out the optimal technique is to put it in reverse and gun it.

On Sat, 18 Mar 2006 09:38:15 -0800
Eric Wilhelm <scratchcomputing at gmail.com> dijo:
> # from John Jordan
> # on Saturday 18 March 2006 08:02 am:
> 
> >I'd still like something where I could just point and click to select
> >often-used commands.

> In my experience, you really don't want much more than a text editor for 
> collecting snippets of commands.  Consider what a "click to run" 
> interface would imply:
> 
>   o  You must be in the right working directory or else enter absolute 
> paths to all filenames.  Some commands (e.g. ps2pdf) expect to write 
> output into the working directory unless explicitly told otherwise.
> 
>   o  You always want to run the command with the same filename 
> arguments.  Otherwise, such a system would have to prompt you for one 
> or more filenames and would either do this with a plain text-entry 
> dialog or a file-chooser (both of which (depending on the GUI toolkit) 
> can have tab complete, at the expense of some extra code.)

Those are excellent points that I hadn't thought of. 

> If the commands of which you speak really are repetitive and predictable 
> enough such that the above two points are non-issues, then it is best 
> to either make them into cron jobs or scripts.  Cron jobs run on a 
> timer, scripts run when you say "name_of_my_script".

No, they are like:

sudo ln -f /chroot/breezy/32bits/resolv.conf /etc/resolv.conf

I already went through trying to get that into a script and ended up with a half-solution (see previous discussion here). Scripts are too complicated for desktop users like me. Yes, I realize I am not supposed to be using Linux. It ought to be illegal for someone without a CompSci degree and programming experience to use Linux. I've gotten that attitude from a lot of Linux people. It's never stated overtly, but I can read between the lines. Well, too bad. I just want something that a dummy can use. I'm a dummy. I'm here. And I intend to stay.

But your points above are very good. Nevertheless, I think a simple bookmark-like click-and-select feature would be useful. If the command needs to be run in a specific folder, then the user can type the whole path before saving it. I don't see why such a feature has to handle everything that a script could do. Its purpose is just to pop in one command. Consider it like a super-tab feature. Maybe it could just be a plugin or extension for gnome-terminal.

By the way, I just tried doing the above link command using tab. It took six tabs to get it all, and after each tab I had to type more letters to get tab to go to the next stop. It would have been faster just to type it and forget about tabs. The problem with tab is that you try it, it doesn't work, and you have to type some more, back and forth, back and forth. I'm not saying it's useless, just that it sometimes isn't much help.

On 3/17/06, Michael M debian-at-writemoore.net wrote:

> I would settle for a solidly researched site that broke out components
> by type and level and just focused on what is widely supported across
> distributions -- i.e., here are the 10 best high-end motherboards, here
> are the 10 best mid-range motherboards, 10 best low-end graphics cards,
> etc.

Unfortunately, not only is it impossible to define "best" for everyone
but components change so often that by the time the reviews were done
that equipment would be different or simply no longer be available.

I'll second the recommendation for NewEgg.  I have a new
CPU/memory/motherboard combo on its way from them to replace my aging
dual-Pentium III 850 linux server.  In the interest of giving you some
ideas, here's what I bought-- keep in mind that this is not yet
assembled so there may be some lingering compatibility problems I'm
unaware of.

Motherboard: TYAN S2865G2NR

Tyan makes server-grade motherboards which cost about twice as much as
chipset-equivalent boards but their Linux compatibility has been good.
 Surprisingly, I've even heard that the on-board LAN and video both
work with Linux!  The downside is this board requires an EPS12V power
supply.  Just when I was getting over the horrors of the AT-to-ATX
conversion...

Power Supply: Antec TruePower 2.0 TP2-550 EPS12V

Required for the above board, there goes an extra $100.  Ow!

CPU: AMD Athlon 64 x2 3800+

This server/high-end desktop runs a lot of stuff at once-- hey, that's
why Linux is so nice, right?  Having that second CPU (or core) really
smooths out system response even when it's getting abused.  The 4200
is about 10% faster than the 3800 based on benchmarks and clock speed
(2.2GHz vs. 2.0GHz) yet costs 20% more.  I plan to run this system for
a long time and 3 years from now I'm not going to care about that 10%
since it'll be slower than anything else around anyway.  I can take
that $150 and do something fun-- like buy a power supply. :-(

Memory: Kingston KVR400X64C3AK2/2G

I would have preferred ECC memory since this board supports it but I'm
going to be "borrowing" some additional memory from a board that
doesn't so I had to go this route.  I've found that higher-end
motherboards tend to be pickier about their memory than cheaper ones
so I go name-brand.  I've also used Crucial memory, but for some
reason they now cost more than Kingston, so Kingston wins.

Video: onboard

This won't be used for games so I'm not too worried about the video. 
If I were, I'd get the lowest clock speed of Nvidia's highest-end
chipset at the time of purchase.  This has generally been a good
price/performance point and runs around $200.  The above board does
NOT support SLI, but Tyan makes an equivalent that does.

Video tends to be a compatibility nightmare, but I've had good luck
with Nvidia's stuff.

Summary:

Remember, I haven't assembled this yet so there may be some issues,
but I hope this gives you some ideas.

  -- Steve

John Jordan <johnxj at comcast.net> wrote:

> Thanks for that info. I tried cat and it does work great. However, I 
> still have to type "cat CheatSheet" and then copy and paste from 
> it. Still, cat is faster than opening gedit.

Are you familiar with the 'less' command?  If not, you should be.  less
allows you to quickly view a file.  You can do all sorts of things with
it, but here's a quick starter course.

h	help
j	scroll down one line
space	page down
k	scroll up one line
b	page up
G	jump to end of file
g	jump to beginning of file
q	quit


galen

Aaron,

The only time I have seen a clock lose time is when the battery is low. 
The weird thing is that your system is losing time when it is ON.... 
that doesn't make much sense. Even if it is dependent on the system 
clock it should not lose time when it is on, only when it is off.... and 
that normally would restart your system clock to an old time such as 
1999 or 2002 or something as such. Still, if you have a battery laying 
around throw it in there and see if it helps.

christian
