On Sat, 2006-03-18 at 08:02 -0800, John Jordan wrote: 
> And thanks for reminding me about tabs. I've known that gnome-
> terminal had tabs for a long time, but I never bothered to figure out 
> how to use them. I've just been opening a new terminal window 
> each time. So now I took the time to explore gnome-terminal and 
> I'll be using tabs. Much more efficient.
> 
Speaking of tabs, the bash shell has a feature called "tab completion",
where you can start a command, then hit tab (multiple times if needed)
to complete the command.  I just found out about it, but from what I
read, it is a bit limited.

For Debian based systems, copy the contents of /etc/bash_completion into
your .bashrc file; don't replace it, just copy the contents.  From the
command line, run:

echo '. /etc/bash_completion' >> ~/.bashrc


> I'd still like something where I could just point and click to select 
> often-used commands. Something like bookmarks in Firefox. As 
> efficient as Linux users have made the command line, surely 
> there's something out there. Maybe a "terminal" is not what I 
> should be looking for.

Of course you can.  I know that in gnome, you can add an application runner to a panel.  This applet has a drop down that buffers commands, and a check box for running in xterm.  I imagine that KDE has something similar.

Good Luck,

I've had computers with lousy clocks before, but nothing as bad as what Aaron is describing, except for my experience with my first Linux computer. This was the Compaq R4000 that I ended up returning to HP because I could never get the ATI video to work with Linux. On that machine the clock ran exactly double speed. It was otherwise perfectly accurate. :)

I never got around to fixing it, but there was some discussion of it on Suse's site, and someone also posted there an rpm file which was supposedly a fix. I remember that the cause had something to do with the kernel, and that there were other CPUs where problems cropped up occasionally also.

I know that's not much help, but I just wanted to say that it may be a Linux problem, not a hardware problem, and there may be a fix out there somewhere.

>

Thanks, I was pretty sure I've heard of issues with Linux's clock before. I believe the kernel keeps it's own idea of time, that's why most distros set the HW clock via the 'system clock' on shutdown. I'm sure the hardware clock is fine.

I've had a system be fast about time before, and gotten messages in the system log about the kernel "losing too many ticks". I googled a bit for information and to the best I can interpret what comes back, if the system is too overloaded the kernel might 'push forward' it's internal clock to compensate for losing interrupts, but that would make it skip forward, not back. And mine's definitely losing time.

I think I'll stop all the services and see if the system loses time with nothing running. I suspect it's java causing the problem somehow.

-Aaron

I thought it would be a good day to do a backup of what I think is
important on my system.  It has been a while, maybe 4 months.

So I try to remember the secret incantation to produce non-coaster DVDs
on my Fedora Release Candidate 4 system.  I remember it's cdrecord as
the command line.  But since I do have some DVD's and a writer, why not
use them?  So I start with dvdrecord.  Hmmm, what device is it?  

>dvdrecord -scanbus
[root at atlas ~]# dvdrecord -scanbus
INFO: dvdrecord's functionality is now replaced by cdrecord
Cdrecord-Clone 2.01-dvd (i686-pc-linux-gnu) Copyright (C) 1995-2004 J?rg
Schilling
Note: This version is an unofficial (modified) version with DVD support
Note: and therefore may have bugs that are not present in the original.
Note: Please send bug reports or support requests to
http://bugzilla.redhat.com/bugzilla
Note: The author of cdrecord should not be bothered with problems in
this version.
scsidev: 'ATA'
devname: 'ATA'
scsibus: -2 target: -2 lun: -2
Linux sg driver version: 3.5.27
Using libscg version 'schily-0.8'.
cdrecord: Warning: using inofficial libscg transport code version
(schily - Red Hat-scsi-linux-sg.c-1.83-RH '@(#)scsi-linux-sg.c   1.83
04/05/20 Copyright 1997 J. Schilling').
scsibus0:
        0,0,0     0) 'TOSHIBA ' 'DVD-ROM SD-M1712' '1004' Removable
CD-ROM
        0,1,0     1) 'LITE-ON ' 'DVDRW LDW-411S  ' 'FS0F' Removable
CD-ROM
        0,2,0     2) *
        0,3,0     3) *
        0,4,0     4) *
        0,5,0     5) *
        0,6,0     6) *
        0,7,0     7) *
You have mail in /var/spool/mail/kens

OK,  we are cooking, now.

But, first I need to make an iso file of the data I need to backup. Now,
let's see how much data.

>du -sh /stuff
6.9G /stuff

Wow! That's not going to fit on a DVD that only takes 4.7G.

I pare it down to Just one directory that is 4.1G.

mkisofs -o /tmp/cd.iso /lessStuff

It does it thing.

Now I can create my DVD.

dvdrecord -dao -data -v speed=4 dev=0,1,0 /tmp/lessStuff

Can't open device.  Google, Gooooooogle, and some more Goooooooogling.

Then in the back of I don't know when and a few readings of the man
cdrecord on my system, I find it.  Need to add a device name to the dev
option.

dvdrecord -dao -data -v  speed=4 dev=ATA:0,1,0 /tmp/lessStuff

Viola, a Data DVD.

HTH,
Ken Stephens
CAD 2 CAM

Ah. Well, as it turns out X-CD-Roast was already installed. Ubuntu 
must've done that, because I don't remember installing it. In any 
event, I tried running it, only to be greeted with an announcement 
that the first time it is run it must be configured by root. So I sudo-
launched it from a command line. But that's about as far as I got. I 
tried several times to get it configured, but to no avail. Plus, it 
couldn't find the DVD-RW drive. How lame is that? And to top it all, 
it uses that sucky-ugly GTK 1.2 interface that I can't change 
because the right librares aren't available in Synaptic.

Moving on, I tried K3b. As soon as I installed it I realized I had 
already used it once before a long time ago when I was still futzing 
around with that R4000 laptop. I also had it for a while under 
Ubuntu. I had uninstalled it only because it's one of those annoying 
KDE apps that screw up Gnome. These apps work just fine, and 
then later the user needs to log in again, only to be told that the 
user's last session lasted less than 10 seconds, so the system 
isn't going to let him log in any more. Problem is with 
.ICEauthority, and the solution is just to delete .ICEauthority, as a 
new .ICEauthority will be created as soon as the user logs in. It's a 
known and frequently yelled about bug.

Anyway, K3b works just fine and I burned two each of the Install 
and Live Ubuntu-32 CDs. In fact, I really think I like K3b better than 
Gnomebaker, in spite of its clownish KDE interface. Did I mention 
that I don't like KDE? :):)

Thanks for the suggestions.

From barryb at proaxis.com  Sat Mar 18 22:08:38 2006
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Sat, 18 Mar 2006 22:08:38 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Thunderbird
In-Reply-To: <441CF118.9000601@verizon.net>
References: <441CF118.9000601@verizon.net>
Message-ID: <af070b010603182208g7d4653f2ic9fdef1fa710ca07@mail.gmail.com>

On 3/18/06, Bruce Kilpatrick <bakilpatrick at verizon.net> wrote:
> Is it possible to have multiple identities using Thunderbird (ver 1.0.7)?
> My wife would like to use this program.  We share a computer at this
> point and have very different methods of keeping emails sorted.  I
> wonder if I could have Thunderbird running on separate virtual desktops
> with a his and hers distinction.  Evolution has some limitations I
> haven't figured out how to conquer and she likes what she sees on my
> desktop.

Thunderbird can certainly do this.  What you are calling identities
Thunderbird calls profiles.  Instead of directly starting Thunderbird,
use the Thunderbird Profile Manager.  There is probably a profile
already there called default, that is your profile. Now you just have
to create a new profile for your wife   On one virtual desktop start
Thunderbird with your profile, and on the other virtual desktop start
Thunderbird with your wifes profile.
Here is more information about profiles
http://www.mozilla.org/support/thunderbird/profile


Bill Barry

> So after I toss Gnomebaker in the bin, what do y'all suggest I replace it
> with?

I haven't done it in quite awhile, but you can use Nautilus, at least 
for simple CD-R burning.  I would think it could manage to create a 
bootable CD-R from an ISO.

It's a fairly simple interface, not unlike burning from Explorer under 
Windows or Finder under OS X.  That is to say, you're not going to get 
all the fancy options you'd get from a dedicated app like k3b or from 
the command-line.  But you don't need them if you're just burning an 
ISO.  It's brain-dead simple to create a bootable CD-R from Finder -- I 
have several Debian, Ubuntu, Gentoo, and OpenBSD PPC install discs to 
prove it!  I don't remember it being much more complicated using Nautilus.

This may not be the problem, but I had similar issue with a box that
continually ran fast (or slow) -- in spite of NTP running, etc.

If your BIOS supports Spread Spectrum frequency, try the following:  Go to
the "Advanced Chipset Features" menu. Set the options "FSB *Spread* *
Spectrum*" and "AGP *Spread* *Spectrum*" to DISABLED.

>

> j	scroll down one line
> space	page down

> b	page up
> G	jump to end of file
> g	jump to beginning of file

Bill Barry wrote:

>On 3/18/06, Bruce Kilpatrick <bakilpatrick at verizon.net> wrote:
>  
>
>>Is it possible to have multiple identities using Thunderbird (ver 1.0.7)?
>>My wife would like to use this program.  We share a computer at this
>>point and have very different methods of keeping emails sorted.  I
>>wonder if I could have Thunderbird running on separate virtual desktops
>>with a his and hers distinction.  Evolution has some limitations I
>>haven't figured out how to conquer and she likes what she sees on my
>>desktop.
>>    
>>
>
>Thunderbird can certainly do this.  What you are calling identities
>Thunderbird calls profiles.  Instead of directly starting Thunderbird,
>use the Thunderbird Profile Manager.  There is probably a profile
>already there called default, that is your profile. Now you just have
>to create a new profile for your wife   On one virtual desktop start
>Thunderbird with your profile, and on the other virtual desktop start
>Thunderbird with your wifes profile.
>Here is more information about profiles
>http://www.mozilla.org/support/thunderbird/profile
>

if some of them don't work for me right now.  Regarding building my own

Geek's build program, so I know it's not that hard.  Unfortunately, I've 
had to stop for awhile because I came down with pneumonia.  But I'm 
starting to feel better and hope I'll be able to resume in a week or 
two.  The hard thing is not so much the mechanics of it, but knowing 
what you want and what makes sense and what works together.  That takes 
a lot of research, if you're not fairly conversant with the options.  I 
think it's easy for people who are to forget how much more daunting a 
task seems to someone who isn't.  And this is especially true when you 
find wildly conflicting information about what's supported, by whom, and 
under what circumstances.  Searching Google/Linux for a particular piece 
of hardware turns up data that's sometimes two or three years 
out-of-date and might not be relevant anymore.  Sifting through that 
plus through the mountain of completely irrelevant stuff that turns up 
is a chore, not to mention sorting out the information that's accurate 
from someone's misdiagnoses of a problem.  I just don't think it's 
something you can do in the course of a week and come to completely 
satisfactory conclusions, unless you're already starting with a good 
baseline of foreknowledge about what you're interested in.  It strikes 
me from the comments many of you made that these are things you've been 
doing or thinking about for quite sometime.  Plus, it would be nice to 
see some of this stuff I've been reading about and I really don't have 
the energy right now to make a field trip.  So, for me, assembling the 
parts to build a box is more of a long-term project than something I can 
accomplish while I'm recovering.  Maybe I'm making it more difficult 
than it needs to be, but I have a tendency to do that sometimes anyway. 
  So there you are.

So I know you're all waiting with baited breath to know what I've 
decided.  :-)

The prices are decent if not exceptional, the machines are sufficiently 
configurable that I could get a couple of things I knew I wanted and 
trust that they know what they're doing with the rest.  They seem to use 
good parts, and obviously everything should be compatible because they 
load Ubuntu.  It's kinda nice to be supporting a company that's trying 
to make a go of supporting Linux for home use.  Even if it has a dumb 
name.  (Groovix?  WTF?)  It'll be interesting to get a machine with 
Linux that someone else has installed.  And it'll be my first AMD 
machine.  So I'm psyched.

Now if it would just get here already!

At 08:28 AM 3/18/06 , you wrote:
>On Fri, Mar 17, 2006 at 06:09:45PM -0800, William A Morita wrote:
> >
> > I have an Actiontec GT701-WT DSL Modem/Router with Qwest DSL service.
> > I tried power cycling the DSL Modem/Router.  No Help.
> > I tried plugging the network cable into the second network interface.
> > The idea being that a new MAC address would force the DHCP to generate
> > a new IP.
> > New IP address, but this did not change the problem, so it is likely
> > not the DHCP.
> > I am out of things to try,
> > I am open to suggestions
>
>Bill:
>
>In general, you seem to be "trying things" and not "gathering data".
>There are too many things that can be misconfigured, and chances are
>you will be taking a random walk that diverges from a solution.  There
>is not enough time in the universe to try all the different possible
>combinations.
>
>I do not use the later Fedora Cores - they are far too experimental
>and much too unsupported to work with for people with my limited
>experience and limited available time.  A better time investment
>might be made in Ubuntu, or SUSE, or one of the many RHEL4 clones,
>so that you are not dealing with a science project.  I won't go
>into the differences between the three alternatives I suggest (and
>there are many more good alternatives besides) but they are all
>rather different but competent ways to approach the "Linux Problem",
>and they are all much more finished products than Fedora Core.
>
>That said, you are now trying to follow the "Fedora" path, and since
>that shares some history with the Fedora Cores 1 and 2, Redhat 9,
>and RHEL4 systems I am used to, so I will try to steer you from that
>perspective.
>
>First, /var/log/messages is your friend.  Just about everything you
>are doing will leave traces there.  You should be using "ifconfig"
>to see what interfaces you are using, and what the net masks and
>gateways are.  "route -n" will tell you other things about your
>connection.  /etc/resolv will tell you what the "ifup" and dhcp
>processes decided your name servers are.  iptables -L will tell
>you about what is firewalled off.  You should be using something
>like tcpdump or ethereal if the aforementioned tools don't tell
>you enough, though debugging at the packet level is painful.
>
>And of course the outputs of all of these diagnostics (and many
>others) from *working* systems in similar circumstances, compared
>to your outputs, will be instructive.
>
>One good source of "working" would be a Knoppix or an Ubuntu Live
>CD.  These are pretty good at connecting to a network, and they
>can be started without a firewall because there is nothing for the
>bad guys to rewrite.  You are not doing this as a "try something",
>you are doing this to gather data about a working connection.
>Unfortunately, since both of those are Debian based, you will need
>to do a lot more abstracting of data from a different set of
>configuration files than the Redhat family, and since they are
>live CDs not all the logging will be in place.
>
>The key to debugging a problem is to start with a working system and
>change one thing and see what it does.  Once you understand all the
>aspects of your change, you are ready to change another thing.  Changing
>two or more things at once is a recipe for confusion and failure.  And
>while it is working, write down important observations ( network
>configuration, DNS server addresses, a few numeric IP addresses of
>test targets) so that you have something to work with when things
>go wrong - and they will.
>
>There are so many things that can go wrong with a network connection,
>and with a bleeding-edge experimental distro, and with buttheaded
>windoze-tunnel-vision service providers and hardware designs, that
>you are very unlikely to land on top of an island of working solutions
>if you dive randomly into the ocean.  You will have to do some
>navigation, and more importantly you will have to first prove to
>yourself that an island actually exists.  That is what the rest of us,
>and Google, can help you with;  duplicate the coordinates of somebody
>elses dry land, and strike out from there.  That may involve a
>different distro, cable modem, DSL provider, etc.  It may even involve
>starting with a borrowed windoze system on your DSL line to see
>whether that can connect properly.  At least you will be able to talk
>to the windoze-addled service reps at your DSL service if the windoze
>box doesn't work.
>
>One last note about internet services;  I don't know how it works for
>the various DSL providers, but Comcast wants to talk to a specific
>MAC address on the other side of the cable modem.  In my case, they
>talk to a particular PCMCIA ethernet card on my laptop router.  If
>I get the cards mixed up, Comcast won't talk to me any more.  The
>same could be true for you.
>
>Try bringing your box into the Linux Clinic at Free Geek tomorrow.
>If the network connection is running, we can see if your box works
>with your ISP and your DSL modem out of the equation, and compare
>log files with a working RH-style system, such as my laptop.
>
>Keith

From danh at f2it.com  Sun Mar 19 10:27:10 2006
From: danh at f2it.com (Dan Haskell)
Date: Sun, 19 Mar 2006 10:27:10 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] remembering often-used commands
In-Reply-To: <20060318102034.ba5cfa5c.johnxj@comcast.net>
References: <20060317151927.1998f0d3.johnxj@comcast.net>
	<441BBE80.4650.80C90296@localhost>
	<200603180938.15748.ewilhelm@cpan.org>
	<20060318102034.ba5cfa5c.johnxj@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.62.0603191019590.13878@f2it.com>


On Sat, 18 Mar 2006, John Jason Jordan wrote:
[bigsnip]
> By the way, I just tried doing the above link command using tab. It took 
> six tabs to get it all, and after each tab I had to type more letters to 
> get tab to go to the next stop.

How about control-r? If you're comfortable using the tab-key expansion, 
then it's probably not to big a jump to searching your command history. At 
a command prompt, hold the control key, press the "r" key, and type in the 
text you're searching for.

So, in the case you mentioned, hit control-r and type "resolv" (sans 
quotes). *If* you've issued the command recently, it should appear. If it 
doesn't, hit control-r again - which should take you to a prior match (if 
there is one).

Dan

From creswick at gmail.com  Sun Mar 19 19:35:33 2006
From: creswick at gmail.com (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Sun, 19 Mar 2006 19:35:33 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] remembering often-used commands
In-Reply-To: <20060318102034.ba5cfa5c.johnxj@comcast.net>
References: <20060317151927.1998f0d3.johnxj@comcast.net>
	<441BBE80.4650.80C90296@localhost>
	<200603180938.15748.ewilhelm@cpan.org>
	<20060318102034.ba5cfa5c.johnxj@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <c834ec80603191935u5c78978dn916addef893266f9@mail.gmail.com>

On 3/18/06, John Jason Jordan <johnxj at comcast.net> wrote:
> But your points above are very good. Nevertheless, I think a simple bookmark-like
> click-and-select feature would be useful. If the command needs to be run in a specific folder,
>then the user can type the whole path before saving it. I don't see
why such a feature has to
> handle everything that a script could do. Its purpose is just to pop in one command.
>Consider it like a super-tab feature. Maybe it could just be a plugin
or extension for
>gnome-terminal.

You could use aliases for some of this.  Take the command you want to
use later, copy it verbatim, then make a line like this in your
.bashrc file (at the end, to be safe )

    alias chrootResolv="sudo ln -f /chroot/breezy/32bits/resolv.conf
/etc/resolv.conf"

(where chrootResolv is the name of your "new" command)
load the new .bashrc with

    source ~/.bashrc

(or open a new terminal)
and run chrootResolv to build your link...

You can also use the .bash_history file for a lot of what you want. 
Dan Haskell already mentioned using ctrl-r (which I *strongly*
recommend also -- you can just keep hitting ctrl-r to get to what you
want, at which point hit enter to run it, or use the arrow keys to
move the cursor and make modifications).  There are other tricks also,
though:  command history (up/down keys scroll through recent
commands), and you can grep the .bash_history file directly, if you
want (or cat, tail, less, etc...)

At one point I put it in cvs, and added the ci/update commands to my
.bash_login / logout files, but that became problematic..

>
> By the way, I just tried doing the above link command using tab. It took six tabs to get it
> all, and after each tab I had to type more letters to get tab to go to the next stop. It would
> have been faster just to type it and forget about tabs. The problem with tab is that you try
> it, it doesn't work, and you have to type some more, back and forth, back and forth. I'm
> not saying it's useless, just that it sometimes isn't much help.
>

If you hit tab twice (eg: /etc/ <tab><tab> ) you get a list of all the
possible completions, from which you can narrow the search.


--Rogan

From debian at writemoore.net  Sun Mar 19 20:08:31 2006

Subject: [PLUG] Browser Blues - Continued
In-Reply-To: <4.2.2.20060319021322.02a39780@mail.earthlink.net>
References: <015701c64a31$078d46f0$6d01a8c0@RAMA>	<441B0E9A.5090406@verizon.net>	<015701c64a31$078d46f0$6d01a8c0@RAMA>

Jim Karlock wrote:
> I have tried four Linux's on a Qwest DSL line. The only one that was 
> able to browse the web "out of the box" was Knoppix. Ubuntu, FC3 and FC4 
> didn't work. (Knoppix was the only one without FireFox.) I downloaded 
> the Debian single CD version and installed it. It couldn't find two 
> different mirrors to begin installing. Presumably another victim of the 
> Qwest DSL line.
> 
> FC3 & FC4 both worked after changing the primary DNS from the local 
> modem to the Qwest one:  205.171.3.65 and changing the secondary DNS to: 
> 205.171.2.65. Unfortunately these revert back after a reset (or perhaps 
> it was a power cycle).
> 
> FC4 also seems to have lost my ML-2010 Samsung printer after it was 
> working when I left the computer and printer at a friend's place for use 
> on their Qwest DSL.
> 
> Needless to say it is highly embarrassing to leave a working computer 
> for a friend to use, only to find that it can't serf or print the next 
> day. Is there a less troublesome distribution around and where do I get it?

One thing I was wondering is whether Gentoo would work best with this 
issue.  One of the USE flag options in Gentoo is IPv6 support, meaning 
that you can strip it out of the kernel and every app that is IPv6 aware 
by compiling with the IPv6 USE flag turned off globally.  I would think 
that might take care of the problem until Qwest starts supporting IPv6, 
but that's just a guess on my part.  You might ask in a Gentoo forum if 
you think it's worth investigating.

Of course, technically, you could recompile everything in any distro 
with customizations, including removing IPv6 support, but Gentoo is the 
only distro I know of that is set up to make that kind of thing easy. 
It would be a PITA on Debian, maybe less of one on Slackware.

This is another reason I'm going to investigate FreeBSD when I get my 
new computer.  I do not have this issue under OS X, it works fine.  OS X 
uses a BSD-variant subsystem (it rides on top of a Darwin kernel), so my 
bet is that FreeBSD would not have this problem either.  I seriously 
doubt that Windows has this issue either, or I imagine we all would have 
heard much more about it.  From what I've read, Microsoft lifts some of 
the Windows network stack from BSD, which is another reason to suspect 
that the BSDs don't have this problem.  I'm kind of dismayed at the fact 
that this has been a Linux issue since at least 2004 and still has not 
been fixed.  Far be it from me to question the priorities of the Linux 
kernel developers, but I would think this is an issue that should get 
higher priority than it has.  There's a thread in the Ubuntu developers' 
forum that discusses this problem in which one of the contributers said 
some people have told him "I tried Ubuntu, but the internet didn't 
work."  So they went back to Windows.  This isn't a good strategy for 
spreading Linux adoption.

From rmannon at comcast.net  Mon Mar 20 08:57:46 2006
From: rmannon at comcast.net (Ryan)
Date: Mon, 20 Mar 2006 08:57:46 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] mplayer and SuSE
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0603192020400.5620@grond.sourballs.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0603192020400.5620@grond.sourballs.org>
Message-ID: <1142873866.7547.20.camel@localhost>

Finally something I might know a bit about!  kaffeine is just a gui for
mplayer.  Just issue the command "mplayer" on the command line.
naturally some thing like this 

# mplayer path/to/the/file/you/want/to/play.avi,mpg,mov,ect,ect

you should get something like this after issueing the command

MPlayer dev-CVS-051220-04:08-4.0.1 (C) 2000-2005 MPlayer Team
CPU: Advanced Micro Devices  (Family: 15, Stepping: 2)
CPUflags:  MMX: 1 MMX2: 1 3DNow: 1 3DNow2: 1 SSE: 1 SSE2: 1
Compiled with runtime CPU detection - WARNING - this is not optimal!
To get best performance, recompile MPlayer with
--disable-runtime-cpudetection.


89 audio & 203 video codecs
Usage:   mplayer [options] [url|path/]filename

and then a list of all the options available.  


If you get some kind of error then there is a problem somewhere.  But
mplayer on the command line should give you a pretty exact error. 

Do you know if you have all the win32 codecs installed?  

If you do compile by hand, you will have to find the mplayer plugins
folder and just extract the codecs there and make sure all users have
permissions to use the codecs.  I really dont know where Suse puts this
folder as I'm a lazy Mandriva user.

Does Suse have repositories for programs they cannot include because of
copyright issues?  That might be what you need.   


I hope that helps...

-ryan

Subject: [PLUG] A wiki for plug
Message-ID: <20060320170035.GA9369@gate.kl-ic.com>


Is it possible/practical for PLUG to have a wiki?  There is content
(such as the times and locations of Advanced Topics and of the Linux
clinic) that may change with time, and that needs to reach a wider
audience than the users of the mailing lists.  

I could set up a PLUG wiki at my site, with pointers from the main
PLUG site, but that would be a little confusing.  

Here are four options (out of hundreds) for wiki software:

MediaWiki - the software behind Wikipedia, also used at Free Geek.  PHP.
PMwiki    - another user friendly PHP wiki.
MoinMoin  - a Python wiki, Personaltelco uses this.
Kwiki     - a Perl wiki, which I use because I like Perl.

I don't know how difficult it is to set up the first three, and of
course the decision of which Wiki (if any) to use will depend on 
what is easy for Wil (or whoever) to set up.  It would be handy to
have a Wiki that can export the database to new Wiki formats as the
technology improves.

Keith

> Sent: Sunday, March 19, 2006 7:36 PM
> To: General Linux/UNIX discussion and help,civil and on-topic
> Subject: Re: [PLUG] remembering often-used commands
> 
> You could use aliases for some of this.  Take the command you 

Yes, the alias command can be a very good friend.  If you just type 'alias',
it will list all of your aliases, which may suffice as your menu of
commands.

Plus they work with tab completion in bash.  I like to add a hyphen to
standard commands and then some descriptive text, for aliases that add my
favorite options.  So I have an alias for CVS updates, for example:

	cvs -q update -Pd

And the alias is "cvs-update".  So I can type "cvs-" and hit tab a couple
times, and I get a list of all my aliases for using cvs.

--Jason V. C.


From ianburrell at gmail.com  Mon Mar 20 11:45:10 2006
From: ianburrell at gmail.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Mon, 20 Mar 2006 11:45:10 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Linux box losing time
In-Reply-To: <200603181344.02409.aaron@madebyai.com>
References: <200603181344.02409.aaron@madebyai.com>
Message-ID: <d91f09cd0603201145u233d225duc373fc0ca45547ff@mail.gmail.com>

On 3/18/06, Aaron Ten Clay <aaron at madebyai.com> wrote:
> Hey all,
>
> I have this problem on one of my Linux boxes. It seems to lose about a minute of time for every 5 minutes it's on. I've never seen such severe clock skew. Opennptd adjusts the clock by about a minute every 5, so it keeps generally correct time as long s the 'net is up, but I'd like to know why this occurs if anyone might have some suggestions. The box is identical to three other ones I have, running a 2.8GHz prescott with hyperthreading. (Same kernels [built myself] and hardware in every regard). The only big difference is that this box runs a bunch of CPU intensive java proceses. But there's a pretty heavy load on the samba box as well (not as constant though) and it doesn't have problems.
>
> Any ideas or pointers for where to start?
>

What kernel version are you running?  I have seen serious clock skew
problems with Opteron dual-core processors.  The problem was a kernel
bug which selected an unstable clock source for the dual-core
processors.  I wouldn't be too surprised is a similar problem affected
Intel SMP processors.  It is also possible to force the kernel to use
a more stable (but slower) clock source.

 - Ian

From ianburrell at gmail.com  Mon Mar 20 11:50:12 2006
From: ianburrell at gmail.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Mon, 20 Mar 2006 11:50:12 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Thunderbird
In-Reply-To: <441CF118.9000601@verizon.net>
References: <441CF118.9000601@verizon.net>
Message-ID: <d91f09cd0603201150k7bed2945xde41174ad3fda6ee@mail.gmail.com>

On 3/18/06, Bruce Kilpatrick <bakilpatrick at verizon.net> wrote:
> Is it possible to have multiple identities using Thunderbird (ver 1.0.7)?
> My wife would like to use this program.  We share a computer at this
> point and have very different methods of keeping emails sorted.  I
> wonder if I could have Thunderbird running on separate virtual desktops
> with a his and hers distinction.  Evolution has some limitations I
> haven't figured out how to conquer and she likes what she sees on my
> desktop.
>

In addition to separate profiles, Thunderbird does support multiple
accounts in one profile.  And multiple identities (name and email
address) for a single account.  For example, at home I have work,
home, etc accounts.  And my home account has two different email
addresses associated with it.  There is a dropdown while composing
email which allows selecting the identity.

If you share an email account, then multiple identities is the way to
select the name on outgoing email.  If you don't share email accounts,
I would suggest having separate profiles.  Even better, have separate
Linux users.

 - Ian

From bakilpatrick at verizon.net  Mon Mar 20 12:55:05 2006
From: bakilpatrick at verizon.net (Bruce Kilpatrick)
Date: Mon, 20 Mar 2006 12:55:05 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Browser Blues - ALMOST Resolved
In-Reply-To: <1142660244.1983.83.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <016d01c64a42$4b4d1e40$6d01a8c0@RAMA>
	<1142660244.1983.83.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <441F16A9.30107@verizon.net>

Does Verizon use IPv6?


Michael M wrote:

>On Fri, 2006-03-17 at 20:13 -0800, William A Morita wrote:
>  
>
>>I was too hasty with my prior posting.
>>I would appear that Konquorer is operational.
>>Firefox is only able retrieve pages that Konquorer had fetched.
>>This is getting stranger and stranger.
>>
>>Anyone, any guesses as to the root cause here?
>>    
>>
>
>Sounds like exactly the problem I had.  Basically, as was explained in a
>previous thread a few weeks ago (when I had mentioned my problem),
>there's a bug in the kernel that doesn't handle the absence of IPv6
>properly.  Presumably, your ISP is not providing IPv6 yet (mine -- Qwest
>-- is not).  What should happen is that when IPv6 requests go out and
>don't receive a reply, the network should default to IPv4.  Or something
>like that.  Instead, it just waits for a reply over IPv6.  Konqueror
>works because it isn't IPv6-enabled yet, so it's only using IPv4 from
>the get-go (doesn't send anything out over IPv6).  The same with w3m if
>you invoke it with "-4".  Gecko-based browsers (Mozilla, Firefox,
>Epiphany), however, are IPv6 enabled, so they just hang, because the
>network is waiting for a reply over IPv6 that will never arrive.
>
>I had the same thing happen with Gecko browsers you describe -- if I
>browsed to any website with Konqueror or w3m -4 first, then Firefox etc.
>would load the page.  Otherwise, they wouldn't load anything.  I don't
>completely understand why this is the case, but my grasp of all of this
>is pretty tenuous.
>
>I don't know how you address the problem in Fedora.  In Debian, I
>commented out "alias net-pf-10 ipv6" and added "alias net-pf-10 off"
>in /etc/modprobe.d/aliases.  That shuts down network support of IPv6
>altogether, and the problem goes away.  It's not exactly a fix, but it's
>a workaround.  Fedora might be different, though.
>
>Oh, I read that a reboot was required after
>editing /etc/modprobe.d/aliases.  Apparently, just stopping and
>restarting the network won't do the trick.
>
>  
>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Mar 20 13:24:23 2006
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 20 Mar 2006 13:24:23 -0800 (PST)

In-Reply-To: <441F0BA1.7010104@verizon.net>
References: <441CF118.9000601@verizon.net>

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0603201319310.28002@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 20 Mar 2006, Bruce Kilpatrick wrote:

> I think I will do some research into separate users...the old win box
> required a log out and log in as a different user. I wasn't aware that
> Linux did the something similar...most likely because I hadn't run into
> this problem yet.

Bruce,

   Winduhs is inherently a single-user, single-tasking OS; linux (as are all
unices) is an inherently multi-tasking and multi-user OS. That's why you can
log into your linux box six or more times, by yourself. If you are running
the X Window System, press alt-ctrl-F2 and you'll have a new login prompt on
the console. You can log in again there. It takes a bit more to run two
separate X Window System sessions, but it can be done.

   Read 'man adduser' for your distribution. It lets you have multiple users
(you add them as root). Then you and your wife can log in individually and
have your own data files while sharing applications. However, unless you have
a separate workstation for her, only one of you can control the monitor and
keyboard at any given time.

Rich

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich> [...] If you are running the X Window System,
Rich> press alt-ctrl-F2 and you'll have a new login prompt on the
Rich> console. You can log in again there. It takes a bit more to run
Rich> two separate X Window System sessions, but it can be done.

FWIW, it's trivial to run more than one X session (my wife and I share
terminals this way).  If startx works for you, just log in to a
virtual console and type the command:

  $ startx -- :1

or
 
  $ startx -- :<n>

Switch back to the first X session with ctrl-alt-F7, and to the new
one with ctrl-alt-F8.  Additional sessions land on F9, F10, etc.

From aaron at madebyai.com  Mon Mar 20 15:23:06 2006
From: aaron at madebyai.com (Aaron Ten Clay)
Date: Mon, 20 Mar 2006 15:23:06 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Mailing list SPF issues
In-Reply-To: <mailman.7.1142874853.7794.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
References: <mailman.7.1142874853.7794.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200603201523.11548.aaron@madebyai.com>

I've noticed in particular messages from Keith Lofstrom are being rejected by my mailserver when sent through the PLUG list, because he's got SPF for his domain configured properly. I also have SPF configured for my domain, so I'd guess that he's not getting my messages (and possibly other people's).

Obviously the entire idea behind SPF is to work this way, so my question is, why does mailman set the sender to the post submitter when forwarding to each subscriber? It seems like a better way would be to leave the sender as PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org and note the originator of the message in reply-to or something. And since I doubt anyone wants to change how it works, what's the best way to deal with this issue on my end and anyone else who's using SPF?

Should we all add SPF records allowing the PLUG mailserver to send on our behalf? That seems like a cheap hack to me.

Comments appreciated,
Aaron

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Mon Mar 20 17:01:58 2006
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Mon, 20 Mar 2006 17:01:58 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Question about apache2 virtual name server configuration.
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0603201654460.2141@PPC.DavidMandel.com>


Suppose I'm configuring apache2 to run the web site, DavidMandel.com
and I want users to be able to get to it by pointing to:

           http://DavidMandel.com
      or
           http://www.DavidMandel.com

Assume that I already have an A record in my DNS for both addresses.

Do I need to build two separate files in my vhost.d directory:
              DavidMandel.com with "ServerName DavidMandel.com"
          www.DavidMandel.com with "ServerName www.DavidMandel.com"
or is there is better, more elegant way of handling the problem?

From ehem at m5p.com  Mon Mar 20 16:57:29 2006
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Mon, 20 Mar 2006 16:57:29 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Browser Blues - Continued
In-Reply-To: <20060320132801.B54CD44DA@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <200603210057.k2L0vT0K004514@m5p.com>

>From: "Michael M." <debian at writemoore.net>
> One thing I was wondering is whether Gentoo would work best with this 
> issue.  One of the USE flag options in Gentoo is IPv6 support, meaning 
> that you can strip it out of the kernel and every app that is IPv6 aware 
> by compiling with the IPv6 USE flag turned off globally.  I would think 
> that might take care of the problem until Qwest starts supporting IPv6, 
> but that's just a guess on my part.  You might ask in a Gentoo forum if 
> you think it's worth investigating.
> 
> Of course, technically, you could recompile everything in any distro 
> with customizations, including removing IPv6 support, but Gentoo is the 
> only distro I know of that is set up to make that kind of thing easy. 
> It would be a PITA on Debian, maybe less of one on Slackware.

But the thing is, doing this is wrong, because some folks do have access
to IPv6 tunnels. What I have to wonder is, how are the modules getting
loaded in the first place? I've yet to see an installer that installs
IPv6 support by default. Are these ISPs perhaps sending broken packets
that are triggering the installers to detect the presence of native IPv6?

> This is another reason I'm going to investigate FreeBSD when I get my 
> new computer.  I do not have this issue under OS X, it works fine.  OS X 
> uses a BSD-variant subsystem (it rides on top of a Darwin kernel), so my 
> bet is that FreeBSD would not have this problem either.  I seriously 
> doubt that Windows has this issue either, or I imagine we all would have 
> heard much more about it.  From what I've read, Microsoft lifts some of 
> the Windows network stack from BSD, which is another reason to suspect 
> that the BSDs don't have this problem.  I'm kind of dismayed at the fact 
> that this has been a Linux issue since at least 2004 and still has not 
> been fixed.  Far be it from me to question the priorities of the Linux 
> kernel developers, but I would think this is an issue that should get 
> higher priority than it has.  There's a thread in the Ubuntu developers' 
> forum that discusses this problem in which one of the contributers said 
> some people have told him "I tried Ubuntu, but the internet didn't 
> work."  So they went back to Windows.  This isn't a good strategy for 
> spreading Linux adoption.

Didn't the previously mentioned bug report on Debian say 2.6.15 fixed it?
For a while the USAGI project (http://www.linux-ipv6.org/) had been
working on IPv6 conformance, while the kernel fell behind on actual
support. I think the kernel got its first infusion from USAGI in 2.6.11,
after a lot of work to get the maintainers to accept patches.

> question is, why does mailman set the sender to the post submitter
> when forwarding to each subscriber? It seems like a better way would
> be to leave the sender as PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org and note the
> originator of the message in reply-to or something. And since I
> doubt anyone wants to change how it works, what's the best way to
> deal with this issue on my end and anyone else who's using SPF?
> 
> Should we all add SPF records allowing the PLUG mailserver to send
> on our behalf? That seems like a cheap hack to me.

Keith replies:
1)  I was told I should set up SPF, and I followed a cookbook formula
to set it up, but frankly I did not take the time to understand what
I was doing, and I may have made a mistake.  I am encouraged that you
(Aaron) say I did it right.

2)  I get the PLUG list as a digest, so I do see your messages to the
list that way.  

3)  I have not received any messages from you directly.  If you or
anyone else is expecting some response from a mail you sent to me,
then perhaps I do *not* have SPF set up correctly.  Or perhaps I am
a lazy weasel and ignoring your mail.

4)  I have postgrey set up on my incoming mail server.  Some ISPs
are broken and can't handle the retries required.  That might be
another reason I am not getting mail from you.  I have not seen
any log messages regarding madebyai.com , though, and I log all
the failed attempts (about 11,000 per day). 

Keith

From scratchcomputing at gmail.com  Mon Mar 20 18:05:49 2006
From: scratchcomputing at gmail.com (Eric Wilhelm)
Date: Mon, 20 Mar 2006 18:05:49 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Question about apache2 virtual name server configuration.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0603201654460.2141@PPC.DavidMandel.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0603201654460.2141@PPC.DavidMandel.com>
Message-ID: <200603201805.49617.ewilhelm@cpan.org>

# from David Mandel
# on Monday 20 March 2006 05:01 pm:

>Do I need to build two separate files in my vhost.d directory:

David,

If I'm not mistaken, it doesn't really matter what you name the files, 
it is just a directory from which all files are included my some 
typeglob in the main apache config.  Naming the configs after the 
domain is just a convention to make it easier to find.  Most (all?) of 
the newer styles of apache config layout are just convention rather 
than hard-and-fast rules.

To slightly elaborate on what Charlie said:  Best to just add a 
ServerAlias entry to your existing VirtualHost section.

--Eric

From linux at frankhunt.com  Mon Mar 20 19:23:15 2006

Subject: [PLUG] Question About Linux Behavior

I run ~10 KDE workspaces each with several windows open - mostly 
browsers and mail clients and terminals.  The system is also my mail 
server and listserv server.  After a period of no user activity, it 
seems that there is nothing in memory except the disk cache.  When I get 
back from $tarbuck$ and user activity resumes, there is significant 
latency while the disk beats it's brains out reloading everything back 
into memory (like 20-30 seconds for thunderbird to get it's brains back, 
for instance).  Is there any way to keep the applications from being 
swapped out in favor of (what I am assuming is) the disk cache?

A particular type of vandal, mainly spammers, should be the number one
concern. Yes, there are active spambots out there that add tons of spammy
links onto Wikis. Any new and upcoming Internet thing needs to be
prepared to handle Spammers. Yes, they really are dirty enough to spam
*anything*. Just an issue of how large a target you need to be before
they start writing bots to attack.

On Mon, 2006-03-20 at 13:24 -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:

>    Read 'man adduser' for your distribution. It lets you have multiple users
> (you add them as root). Then you and your wife can log in individually and
> have your own data files while sharing applications. However, unless you have
> a separate workstation for her, only one of you can control the monitor and
> keyboard at any given time.
> 
> Rich
> 

One thing I thought was interesting about Groovix's
( http://groovix.com/solutions.html ) options is that they make a point
of stressing the multi-user capabilities in Linux.  They set-up their
buying configuration options so that it is easy for you to buy one
computer (CPU) with multiple terminals, which of course is less
expensive than buying multiple workstations.  And they will
pre-configure the OS for as many users as you want.  They point out how
easy it is to play multi-player games from the same computer with each
player getting their own terminal.  Semi-savvy Linux users know all this
already, but they seem to be aiming as much or more at Windows users who
wouldn't have thought of it.  It's a selling point I had not noticed any
consumer-oriented Linux vendors emphasizing before.

Terror.  Well at least concern.  I've seen this happen as a disk started 
to fail.  My first moves have been to restart the system; sometimes by 
hitting the power or rest button; forcing it to see an unclean shutdown 
and allowing you to check the partitions.  ( I'm sure there is some 
really-cool/total-sysadmin method to do this but I like low-hanging 
fruit and it has worked on almost every distribution I've tried. )
   If this fixes the problem I breathe a sigh relief and think of 
budgeting a replacement/backup drive.  If this fixes the problem for a 
while then I get _really_ concerned and start looking for a new drive.

Last time this happened ( a month or so ago ) it was the swap partition 
kept _going away_.  Since the system was going to be re-purposed I just 
did a clean install including a repartition of the drive(s).  The system 
is still very lightly loaded -- processing-wise and diskusage -- so I 
don't know if this was some file system corruption or a bad disk.  This 
reminds me I need to stress that system a bit. :-)


Other more knowledgable should be following up on your post s owe might 
get a better answer.


Rod

From jonscully at gmail.com  Tue Mar 21 07:49:39 2006
From: jonscully at gmail.com (Jon Scully)
Date: Tue, 21 Mar 2006 08:49:39 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Backup Error: Need Advice
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0603210610220.20616@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0603210610220.20616@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <53107f6e0603210749q2663a7b1n8822420accb78f3c@mail.gmail.com>

On 3/21/06, Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> wrote:
>
>    After running for years without problems I've hit what may be a
> hardware
> (RAM) problem that's affecting my backups. I'd greatly appreciate some
> help
> in figuring out the source of this error.
>

Try the following:
* Reboot into a Knoppix Live CD (or other live CD)
* Mount the hard drive partition READ ONLY:
1) In Knoppix, just right-click the drive-like icon and choose one of the
mount options
2) From a command prompt, enter: /bin/mount -n -o remount,ro /
* From a command prompt, enter: /sbin/fsck -T -C -a /

>From the way you describe things, you should see complaints from fsck.

Good idea, having backups ;-)

--

Sr. Embedded Software Engineer

From jonscully at gmail.com  Tue Mar 21 07:57:05 2006
From: jonscully at gmail.com (Jon Scully)
Date: Tue, 21 Mar 2006 08:57:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Backup Error: Need Advice
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0603210610220.20616@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On 3/21/06, Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> wrote:
>
>    After running for years without problems I've hit what may be a
> hardware
> (RAM) problem that's affecting my backups. I'd greatly appreciate some
> help
> in figuring out the source of this error.
>

Forgot to add: One of the best ways to check main memory is to adjust your
BIOS to do a "complete" memory check.

It's convenient because it's one of the few ways to do a check without also
using some of the memory being checked (e.g. real tough to do when there's
an operating system running) and it's always available -- i.e. no need to
hunt down your diagnostics Floppy.

(You'll probably want to put the BIOS back to "quick" check mode, or each
reboot will be painfully slow.)

--
Jon Scully
Sr. Embedded Software Engineer
877-461-7580 Toll-free

Message-ID: <20060321162746.8BCF78F14@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Roderick A. Anderson <raanders at acm.org> wrote:

> 
> Terror.  Well at least concern.  I've seen this happen as a disk
> started to fail.  My first moves have been to restart the system;
> sometimes by hitting the power or rest button; forcing it to see an
> unclean shutdown and allowing you to check the partitions.  ( I'm sure
> there is some really-cool/total-sysadmin method to do this but I like
> low-hanging fruit and it has worked on almost every distribution I've
> tried. )

I think I prefer Jon's suggestion of running fsck from a CD, but here's
a way to run fsck on an idle system.  I don't think an unclean shutdown
is a good idea.  The only exception I can think of is if you just
entered something liked rm -f /.

Logout from any X11 session.
Login as root on a vt.
#telinit s               #go to single user mode
run fsck


galen



From johnxj at comcast.net  Tue Mar 21 09:21:46 2006
From: johnxj at comcast.net (John Jason Jordan)
Date: Tue, 21 Mar 2006 09:21:46 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] DNS Weirditudes
Message-ID: <20060321092146.e00e7ca9.johnxj@comcast.net>

Does anyone know how to tell the addresses that a Windows 2000 computer gets from Comcast cable? 

So I spent almost all day yesterday at PSU and had no problems. I just left the computer sitting when I got home because it was late. This morning I plugged it into the ethernet, which goes through the hub to the router to the cable modem, and always just "works." Then I turned on the power and waited for it to boot, First thing I did was to run the link command to copy the DNS addresses from /etc/resolv.conf to the copy in chroot, because otherwise I wouldn't able to go anywhere with Firefox. Then I launched Sylpheed to check e-mail, using the "Get All" button on the toolbar (I have three accounts set up in Sylpheed). It happily went to two of the servers, but said that the connection failed on one of them. Note that Sylpheed is running in 64-bit world, so it should not need the link command to go anywhere. Puzzled, I swiveled my chair around and tried it with Pegasus on the Windows desktop. No problem getting to that account.

Then I launched Firefox (in chroot) and tried to go places. It would go some places, but not others. I re-ran the link command, but it made no difference. I opened System > Administration > Networking and disabled eth0, then restarted it. Still no go. All my internet apps would go to some places but not others. Using the Windows computer I pinged some of the places that the laptop couldn't find, then pinged the IP address from the laptop, and the laptop could find the server. So it's a DNS issue. And throughout, the Windows desktop could go anywhere. I don't get this. Somehow the laptop is not getting the DNS server entries from the network, but I know little about how these things work. It just seems to me that it should work 100% or not at all. It's acting like my house wiring when one side of the incoming lines is down -- half the circuits work and the other half are dead.

Eventually I shut down the laptop and restarted it. That finally resolved the issue. However, this is not the first time this has happened. And I seriously need this computer for at least another day and a half until finals are over, 'cause it's got everything on it. It's all backed up, but I don't have time to rebuild things until Friday. Someone please tell me the problem is simple!

that will tell you your ip info

if you need to release and restart it do this... You may or may not need

From christian at rocksolidservice.com  Tue Mar 21 09:31:53 2006
From: christian at rocksolidservice.com (Christian)
Date: Tue, 21 Mar 2006 09:31:53 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] DNS Weirditudes
In-Reply-To: <20060321092146.e00e7ca9.johnxj@comcast.net>
References: <20060321092146.e00e7ca9.johnxj@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <44203889.1000805@rocksolidservice.com>

You pc doesn't get info from comcast.
Comcast gives to modem
Modem gives to PC or router
Router gives to PC

Unplug your modem for a minute and restart it. turn off your system, 
turn off the router.
after a minute turn on your modem
then after it is completely linked to the network
restart your router
once it is up
restart your pc

that should fix any of your connection issues, if it doesn't then call 
comcast... they may have a line down.


christian

> and capture the session to see all the information that changes hands.

Nothing fancy going on here, just a javascript in the page that reads your system clock via the browser. Starts at about line 414 in the source for me, if you're interested.

There is a standard HTTP "Date" header, but user agents rarely, if ever, send it. Usually it's for the server to tell the UA what timezone they're in.

-Aaron

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Tue Mar 21 10:19:02 2006
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Tue, 21 Mar 2006 10:19:02 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Linux box losing time
In-Reply-To: <200603181723.46494.aaron@madebyai.com>
References: <200603181344.02409.aaron@madebyai.com>
	<441C931C.9050105@rocksolidservice.com>
	<20060318171920.63f9e8ac.johnxj@comcast.net>
	<200603181723.46494.aaron@madebyai.com>
Message-ID: <1142965142.14535.30.camel@willow.odshp.com>

On Sat, 2006-03-18 at 17:23 -0800, Aaron Ten Clay wrote:

> Thanks, I was pretty sure I've heard of issues with Linux's clock
> before. I believe the kernel keeps it's own idea of time, that's why
> most distros set the HW clock via the 'system clock' on shutdown. I'm
> sure the hardware clock is fine.

There can be problems if the CPU clock rate that the kernel discovers by
probing is different than that it really is (by, say, several hundred
MHz--don't be confused if your 3GHz CPU is reported as 2992.626GHz--the
3GHz is just rounding).  You can use the 'hwclock' program to see query
the hardware clock directly to verify that it's the kernel and not the
system clock.  You might want to check that your motherboard has the
current BIOS/firmware version.  'dmidecode' can be useful to compare
your systems.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley <wcooley at nakedape.cc>
Naked Ape Consulting, Ltd

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Tue Mar 21 10:36:58 2006
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Tue, 21 Mar 2006 10:36:58 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Mailing list SPF issues
In-Reply-To: <200603201523.11548.aaron@madebyai.com>
References: <mailman.7.1142874853.7794.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
	<200603201523.11548.aaron@madebyai.com>
Message-ID: <1142966218.14535.36.camel@willow.odshp.com>

On Mon, 2006-03-20 at 15:23 -0800, Aaron Ten Clay wrote:
> I've noticed in particular messages from Keith Lofstrom are being
> rejected by my mailserver when sent through the PLUG list, because
> he's got SPF for his domain configured properly. I also have SPF
> configured for my domain, so I'd guess that he's not getting my
> messages (and possibly other people's).

Don't reject messages with conflicting SPF records wholesale.
Generally, don't reject messages based on only a single test--you'll
wind up with too many false positives (unless it's a really good, really
reliable test).  That's why I prefer the scoring mechanism SpamAssassin
uses.

> Obviously the entire idea behind SPF is to work this way, so my
> question is, why does mailman set the sender to the post submitter
> when forwarding to each subscriber? It seems like a better way would
> be to leave the sender as PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org and note the
> originator of the message in reply-to or something. And since I doubt
> anyone wants to change how it works, what's the best way to deal with
> this issue on my end and anyone else who's using SPF?

But the sender /isn't/ the mailing list; the sender is... the sender.
The mailing list is just the forwarder.  Reply-to is something
altogether different.

> Should we all add SPF records allowing the PLUG mailserver to send on
> our behalf? That seems like a cheap hack to me.

Or just whitelist the list server itself, since yours is in the minority
of ones with problems.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley <wcooley at nakedape.cc>
Naked Ape Consulting, Ltd

In Mediawiki's LocalSettings.php

$wgUseRCPatrol = true; # use "patrolled edits"
$wgSpamRegex = "/overflow\s*:\s*auto/"; # customize this
$wgWhitelistEdit = true;   # true = user must login to edit.

and moderate manual blocking goes a long way.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Tue Mar 21 12:15:56 2006
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Tue, 21 Mar 2006 12:15:56 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Reading computer time stamp over internet
In-Reply-To: <200603210858.59900.alex@daniloff.com>
References: <200603210858.59900.alex@daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <25261-78457@sneakemail.com>

On 3/21/06, Alex Daniloff alex-at-daniloff.com wrote:

> I wonder, how they do this. Is it a part of TCP/IP protocol or
> environmental variable of my browser?

As others have noted, in this case it was just some javascript,
however there are a number of other ways to get your PC's time-- the
simplest is the TCP timestamp option which is enabled by default on
all modern distros of Linux that I've seen:

http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1323.txt

Another option would be the ICMP timestamp:

http://www.networksorcery.com/enp/protocol/icmp/msg13.htm

This is seldom used, but enabled by default on at least Red Hat
variants-- I can't remember if it's enabled on others.

I recall reading an article about "fingerprinting" PCs based on the
delay patterns between packets to reveal the PC's inherent clock
drift, but I can't find the URL.  However, I know of no current
vulnerabilities that could be exploited using your PC time.  I
generally don't worry too much about the fact that it's trivial to
deduce my current PC time.

  -- Steve

From ehem at m5p.com  Tue Mar 21 15:38:31 2006
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Tue, 21 Mar 2006 15:38:31 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Backup Error: Need Advice
In-Reply-To: <20060321162405.EAF2246B0@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <200603212338.k2LNcVpC014013@m5p.com>

>From: Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com>
>    The log file size is 18.3M, so there's no point in mailling it to anyone.
> Now the error message in the second e-mail from root was:
> 
> /bin/incbru: line 119: 18733 Segmentation fault      $BRUCMD >$LOGFILE 2>&1
> incbru: ERROR in BRU Backup

>    Both yesterday morning (when I went to log in after being gone for several
> days), and this morning when I went to log in, I saw the results of the seg
> fault dump on the console. Here is probably what I saw:
> 
> [root at salmo ~]# tail /var/log/messages
> Mar 21 06:02:27 salmo kernel: ds: 0018   es: 0018   ss: 0018
> Mar 21 06:02:27 salmo kernel: Process bru (pid: 18733, stackpage=e76eb000)
> Mar 21 06:02:27 salmo kernel: Stack: f3b54890 c19ac4d0 f6d62900 00000060
> 00000060 00000008 00000001 00000060 
> Mar 21 06:02:27 salmo kernel:        e76ea000 0807fa60 c0108a93 0807fa60
> 0807ddc0 00000000 0807fa60 0807ff40 
> Mar 21 06:02:27 salmo kernel:        bfffea54 000000c4 0000002b 0000002b
> 000000c4 400d9053 00000023 00000202 
> Mar 21 06:02:27 salmo kernel: Call Trace:    [<c0108a93>]
> Mar 21 06:02:27 salmo kernel: 
> Mar 21 06:02:27 salmo kernel: Code: 8b 40 34 85 c0 75 34 31 c0 85 c0 89 c3 74
> 14 56 e8 de 26 00 

Those two together tell the story. The immediate problem is some number
of pages of kernel memory have been corrupted. At a minimum you'll need
to restart the system, and forcing disk checks would be a good idea. The
next question is what is the origin?

This could be memory that is marginal. If this machine stays on
continuously, eventually even /slightly/ marginal memory will bite you.
This could be a processor that is a little too warm. This could be a
dying disk drive (doubt it, they tend to be more spectacular).

memtest is the conventional target for #1. #2 you look at lm-sensors. #3
you look at what smartctl (smartmontools) tells you.


>From: Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com>
>    No, that's not it. I tried this three times, the last time moving that file
> out of the directory. The backup halted on the next file.
> 
>    When I try to list the contents of that directory I also get a seg fault.
> Now, I can 'ls /usr/lib/qt-3.3.4/examples' just fine; I can even cd there.
> But, attempts to list the files in the textedit/ directory, or to cd there,
> produce a segmentation fault.
> 
>    What does that information add to your understanding?

Not much, the above already strongly pointed to corrupt kernel memory
and filesystem damage is a common result of that.


>From: Galen Seitz <galens at seitzassoc.com>
> I think I prefer Jon's suggestion of running fsck from a CD, but here's
> a way to run fsck on an idle system.  I don't think an unclean shutdown
> is a good idea.  The only exception I can think of is if you just
> entered something liked rm -f /.

There are several ways, but the handiest in this sort of situation is
`touch /forcefsck`, and reboot. If you look at the init scripts, there
are a number of little control functions managed by the presence/absence
of files in /. I imagine you can guess what the presence of a file named
"forcefsck" on root does (size of course doesn't matter, so typically
touch is used to make zero-sized ones).

From tim.thorpe at gmail.com  Tue Mar 21 16:08:54 2006
From: tim.thorpe at gmail.com (Tim Thorpe)
Date: Tue, 21 Mar 2006 16:08:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Ubuntu Dapper Drake Officially Delayed
Message-ID: <32c2f9130603211608r1a7a215ep38db75df91190fcc@mail.gmail.com>

Strait from Mark's mouth, Dapper Drake has been delayed until June 1st.

https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2006-March/000058.html
-----------------

Hi,

June 1st 2006 is the updated release date for Ubuntu Dapper, Desktop
and Server editions, a delay of 6 weeks over the previous release date
of April 20.

The Ubuntu Community Council and Technical Board discussed feedback on
the delay proposal received during two town hall meetings on the
#ubuntu-meeting public IRC channel. After conferring with an absent
colleague they have now unanimously approved the new release schedule,
published here:

  * https://wiki.ubuntu.com/DapperReleaseSchedule

The additional time will be used to:

  * devote an additional three weeks of bug-fix-only quality assurance
    time to the release for the core development team

  * integrate the work of the localisation sprint to ensure excellent
    out-of-the-box support for Asian languages as well as other
    languages for which we are receiving a stream of community
    contributions

  * devote additional developer time to UI polish that we believe will
    make Dapper stand out as a high-quality desktop operating system
    for large-scale deployment

  * bring the XFCE desktop environment, which has received substantial
    community-driven work during this cycle, into the main Ubuntu
    repository to improve the usefulness of Ubuntu on lightweight
    desktops

  * ensure that Dapper will be LSB certified at the time of release

  * provide for wider testing of the new Ubuntu server kernels and
    server features

  * ensure that the new graphical Live CD installer receives very
    widespread testing

This is not a general relaxation of the freeze process. While there
are some new features that are being integrated, the general
stabilisation and bug fixing freeze remains in place, with some
specific exceptions.

Progress towards the set of goals identified for Dapper has been truly
excellent, with almost all feature goals already implemented or
available for wide testing 5 weeks ahead of our previous release
date. The current status of all 82 new Dapper features (not counting
new upstream features in this cycle) is listed here:

  * https://launchpad.net/distros/ubuntu/dapper/+specs

The extra time will help ensure that Dapper is a robust and reliable
platform for organisations with long-term and large-scale free
software deployments.  This is the first release of Ubuntu that will
be supported for 5 years on the server and 3 years on the desktop, and
we believe that this release will help expand the reach of the Ubuntu
and Debian communities substantially.

While the release schedule of Dapper+1 is not finalised, the Technical
Board feels that it will be best to plan for a short release schedule
to return to our regular Gnome + 1 month cycle. This will likely
result in Dapper+1 being released in October 2006.

Thank you to all who participated in the discussion or sent in their
commentary directly to the Technical Board, Community Council and
SABDFL.

--
Mark

I think what you are asking for is NTP but I'm not sure, NTP stands for
Network Time Protocol. It's a dedicated protocol for clock syncing. beyond
that I haven't looked too much in to it I know I use it but I don't know the
nitty gritty details of how it works or how to configure it in linux. I do
know my linux box sets it's time via NTP every time it starts up, and I know
you can cron-job it somehow to update the clock at regular intervals to keep
it on time. but the how to do it escapes me. perhaps someone else on the
list can help us.


On 3/21/06, Alex Daniloff <alex at daniloff.com> wrote:

> On Tuesday March 21 2006 12:15, Steve Bonds wrote:
> > On 3/21/06, Alex Daniloff alex-at-daniloff.com wrote:
> > > I wonder, how they do this. Is it a part of TCP/IP protocol or
> > > environmental variable of my browser?
> >
> > As others have noted, in this case it was just some javascript,
> > however there are a number of other ways to get your PC's time-- the
> > simplest is the TCP timestamp option which is enabled by default on
> > all modern distros of Linux that I've seen:
> >
> > http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1323.txt
> >
> > Another option would be the ICMP timestamp:
> >
> > http://www.networksorcery.com/enp/protocol/icmp/msg13.htm
> >
> > This is seldom used, but enabled by default on at least Red Hat
> > variants-- I can't remember if it's enabled on others.
> >
> > I recall reading an article about "fingerprinting" PCs based on the
> > delay patterns between packets to reveal the PC's inherent clock
> > drift, but I can't find the URL.  However, I know of no current
> > vulnerabilities that could be exploited using your PC time.  I
> > generally don't worry too much about the fact that it's trivial to
> > deduce my current PC time.
> >

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Tue Mar 21 18:15:52 2006
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 21 Mar 2006 18:15:52 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Mailing list SPF issues
References: <mailman.7.1142874853.7794.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
	<200603201523.11548.aaron@madebyai.com>
	<1142966218.14535.36.camel@willow.odshp.com>
Message-ID: <863bhbns13.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Wil" == Wil Cooley <wcooley at nakedape.cc> writes:

>> Obviously the entire idea behind SPF is to work this way, so my
>> question is, why does mailman set the sender to the post submitter
>> when forwarding to each subscriber? It seems like a better way would
>> be to leave the sender as PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org and note the
>> originator of the message in reply-to or something. And since I doubt
>> anyone wants to change how it works, what's the best way to deal with
>> this issue on my end and anyone else who's using SPF?

Wil> But the sender /isn't/ the mailing list; the sender is... the sender.
Wil> The mailing list is just the forwarder.  Reply-to is something
Wil> altogether different.

This is "envelope from" we're talking about, not "header from".

If I send to PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org, it should look like:

        From plug at lists.pdxlinux.org (date)
        From: merlyn at stonehenge.com
        To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
        Date: (original date)

etc etc

Or, in SMTP terms:

        MAIL FROM: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
        RCPT TO: (each user)
        DATA
        From: merlyn at stonehenge.com
        To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org

etc etc.

If the mailing list software at pdxlinux.org is not doing the right thing,
then it needs to be fixed *or* it needs to not publish hard-fail SPF records.

If the recipient is hard-failing based on "From:", shame on him.  SPF is only
supposed to check envelope-from, not header-from.

Windows users think something is easier when often it is not.  They 
think something is difficult often because it isn't Windows-ish. 
Remember trying to learn Windows?  Bet it was a lot more complicated 
than trying to learn a "Linux" desktop such as Xfce.

I've found Xfce to be customizable enough to work quite well for me.  My 
computer using habits are such that X holds maybe six or seven graphical 
applications and twenty or more terminals (and I really need to find a 
nicer terminal...), so I map keys to launch these six or seven graphical 
applications and run all the oddball stuff from the Run dialog (which is 
also mapped to a hotkey) or a terminal (ditto).  I don't use a task bar 
(it wastes space) and have the panel set to auto-hide with a nice 
graphical pager on it (which acts very taskbar-esque for me)... with 
about ten desktops going most of the time.

So I pretty much go insane using Windows, and have found gnome to not be 
as quick-and-easy to get going as Xfce (this particular install took me 
about ten minutes to get in to shape)... and it's oh so bloated.

I wonder if people examined their computer usage habits if they'd find 
they really pretty much never need to use that whole start menu thing 
Microsoft "came up with" and KDE/gnome "copied" except as a reference 
when they just can't remember what that program was called...

The only difference is you'd have to take a little bit of time and learn 
how to effectively use your computer instead of assuming the way Bill 
Gates told you how to use it was how you should use it....

</rant>

As an aside - has anybody ever noticed people pretty much never maximize 
windows unless they're using Windows?  Windows users ALWAYS have the 
window they're in maximized... but others pretty much NEVER have the 
window they're in maximized.  I've found myself doing this - at work I 
generally have whatever I'm working in maximized while at home (in 
Linux) I like to have things laid out in such a way that I can see 
what's going on elsewhere.....

Alex Daniloff wrote:
> I'm not talking about NTP but plain browser and a server interaction.
> I'm asking about any mechanism which can be used on the server side to
> retrieve timestamp from the client browser without using javascript.

Tim Thorpe wrote:
> umm...I don't think there is without some type of client side script to send
> the data back to the server. AJAX might do it. what is wrong with
> javascript? what exactly are you trying to do? I'll read through the
> conversation real quick to see if I missed somthing, but I'm not sure as to
> the question I think.

"AJAX" uses javascript, that's what the "J" stands for..

By timestamp I assume you mean what time the client's clock is set to,
even if wrong.  Unless the client sends a date/timestamp header with a
request (and it doesn't appear to be in the HTTP spec so it seems likely
they won't) you might be out of luck.

A highly inaccurate method would be going a geo lookup on their ip
address and mapping that to a time zone, from that you could get their
actual time.. but those ip->geographic location things aren't exactly
foolproof.  And it wouldn't account for what time their computer was
actually set to if it was wrong or they were in Miami on their laptop
set to a Portland time.  Or you could ask the user to type it in and hit
 submit.

--Brent

From debian at writemoore.net  Tue Mar 21 20:49:04 2006
From: debian at writemoore.net (Michael M.)

Subject: The Linux Desktop (was Re: [PLUG] Ubuntu Dapper Drake
	Officially Delayed)
In-Reply-To: <4420B5B9.8000903@axpr.net>
References: <32c2f9130603211608r1a7a215ep38db75df91190fcc@mail.gmail.com>
	<44209C9D.5080902@axpr.net>

	<4420B5B9.8000903@axpr.net>

On Tue, 2006-03-21 at 18:26 -0800, AthlonRob wrote:

> I've found Xfce to be customizable enough to work quite well for me.  My 
> computer using habits are such that X holds maybe six or seven graphical 
> applications and twenty or more terminals (and I really need to find a 
> nicer terminal...), so I map keys to launch these six or seven graphical 
> applications and run all the oddball stuff from the Run dialog (which is 
> also mapped to a hotkey) or a terminal (ditto).  I don't use a task bar 
> (it wastes space) and have the panel set to auto-hide with a nice 
> graphical pager on it (which acts very taskbar-esque for me)... with 
> about ten desktops going most of the time.

I'm kinda curious as to why you use a DE at all, given the way you
describe how you like your set-up.  What's the advantage of using Xfce
over something simpler like Openbox?:

--no default toolbars/taskbars/panels that you'd need to hide or disable
--everything keymappable, including a highly configurable menu that can
be as comprehensive or skimpy as you want
--as many desktops as you want
--configurable window auto-arranging policy and configurable window
manipulation from the keyboard (nudging windows, auto resizing to fill
open space vertically or horizontally, moving windows to different
desktops, etc.)

And beyond Openbox and similar, there are the tiled WMs like wmii and
ion3, which you might find even more to your liking.  I think wmii is
pretty cool, except I couldn't really get with the "plan 9" aspect of
it, which seems to me to add unnecessary complexity.  And as for ion3 --
well, I don't want to have to learn a scripting language just to control
my desktop.  PekWM might be better than either of these, if development
continues.

> So I pretty much go insane using Windows, and have found gnome to not be 
> as quick-and-easy to get going as Xfce (this particular install took me 
> about ten minutes to get in to shape)... and it's oh so bloated.
> 
> I wonder if people examined their computer usage habits if they'd find 
> they really pretty much never need to use that whole start menu thing 
> Microsoft "came up with" and KDE/gnome "copied" except as a reference 
> when they just can't remember what that program was called...
> 
> The only difference is you'd have to take a little bit of time and learn 
> how to effectively use your computer instead of assuming the way Bill 
> Gates told you how to use it was how you should use it....
> 

Well, okay, it's a rant, and rants aren't *supposed* to be, um, fair ...
but c'mon.  Microsoft spent millions on usability studies to come up
with what they did.  Anyone can argue that they still didn't do a good
job, but it's hardly reasonable to attribute Windows's layout to the
whims of Bill Gates.  Sun and Ximian and other Gnome backers similarly
have invested enormous effort in researching and establishing HIG, and I
doubt that KDE simply copied Windows.  And that's to say nothing of all
the work Apple has done in these areas, which has had an impact on the
design of all these environments.  I would say that Gnome is at least as
influenced by OS X as Windows, and Xfce owes something to it as well.
None of this is to suggest that they must all be right just because they
spent a lot of money, but you're being awfully dismissive of the work
that's been done just because they don't happen to be right for you.

> As an aside - has anybody ever noticed people pretty much never maximize 
> windows unless they're using Windows?  Windows users ALWAYS have the 
> window they're in maximized... but others pretty much NEVER have the 
> window they're in maximized.  I've found myself doing this - at work I 
> generally have whatever I'm working in maximized while at home (in 
> Linux) I like to have things laid out in such a way that I can see 
> what's going on elsewhere.....
> 

Not really, but there might be something to that.  I think people tend
to like maximized windows or not, regardless of what environment they're
in.  One of the basic ideas behind tiled WMs (which are about as far
away from the MS/Apple paradigms as you can get) is that there is no
point in *not* having windows maximized.  After all, what is the space
that's not being occupied by a window doing for you?  Why not take full
advantage of the space available to you by filling it with actual work
space?  A WM like Openbox takes a kind of "middle road" in that it does
not, by default, fill your workspace like a tiled WM, but it makes it
easy for you to do that when it's appropriate.  It takes a little more
work in Openbox if you, say, have two xterms filling the screen and want
to add a third, than it does in wmii, which will auto-arrange the
addition of a third (or fourth, or fifth...) xterm.  But it can be done
in Openbox with a couple of keystrokes.

There is certainly an unstated element of "I like [insert DE/WM here]
best because it's what I'm used to" in people's assessments of all these
environments, but that's to be expected.  When I started using OS X, one
of the things that drove me crazy at first was the single-desktop
paradigm.  I had used multiple desktops in both Windows and Linux for a
long time, and I thought not having this feature available was a real
limitation.  But after getting with OS X, I realized that it provides
multi-desktop functionality without the multi-desktop paradigm.  The
ways you can move, arrange, control and switch between windows in OS X
is no less featureful than the ways you can do those things in
Gnome/KDE/Windows XP or other environments with multiple desktops, it
just provides a different conceptutalization of window management.  And
yet, some people still use third-party tools to provide multiple
desktops in OS X -- probably only because that's what they've been used
to coming from other environments.  It's silly, but it's human nature.

-- 
Michael M. -- Portland, OR -- USA
"No live organism can continue for long to exist sanely under conditions
of absolute reality; even larks and katydids are supposed, by some, to
dream." -S. Jackson
