From ehem at m5p.com  Thu Mar 30 13:38:32 2006
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Thu, 30 Mar 2006 13:38:32 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] One Broken File Utility
In-Reply-To: <20060330200007.937C94607@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <200603302138.k2ULcW4I018174@m5p.com>

>From: Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com>
>    While the CPU swap seems to have solved the problem of system lockups, the
> fileutil 'df' still seg faults. All other fileutils (e.g., ls, dir, du,
> mkdir, cp, mv) work just fine. Google turns up 80K hits, but I don't see
> anything that seems to apply to my situation.

Two causes come to mind:

First, the optimistic guess is you've simply got filesystem damage. `df`
simply gets misloaded and this results in something that cannot run.
`touch /forcefsck` will do the job, or you can also manually force `fsck`
on all your filesystems if you know how (remount read-only, `fsck -f`,
there are subtlties here). Given that you had a flaky processor, in all
probability, you've got *some* filesystem damage, so this is the first
test no matter what.

Second, alas more probable from the symptoms, you've got filesystem
damage in the data areas. Grab distribution packages from a clean source
and reinstall.

Jon LeVitre wrote:
> I agree with most of what Carla said.  
> 
> One more thing to consider.  Different distros have different userid
> numbering schemes and different program versions.
> 
> I'm dual-booting fedora and ubuntu.  Fedora wants to start the userid
> numbers at 500, ubuntu starts then at 1000.  You may need to override
> the default.

I have been wrestling with this today.  I have three large partitions on 
my second hard drive I want to share between all OS'es, but the my UID 
in Ubuntu is 1001 and my UID in Debian is 1000, so I couldn't write to 
the partitions from Debian with my user account.  I chowned the 
partitions by username, rather than UID, since I have the same username 
in both OSes.  I haven't yet booted back into Ubuntu to see if I still 
have full access, so I don't know if this method will work.

> There also seems to be a minor compatibility issue between the versions
> of gnome (for example: ubuntu can't find the icon to use for the
> trashcan on the desktop).  Next time I'm planning to create a shared
> /data partition instead of a shared /home partition, and set up links.

Ubuntu puts the Gnome trashcan on the bottom panel, so perhaps it
doesn't include a desktop icon for the trashcan.  Seems odd to me that 
they'd have left it out altogether, though.  With Debian's default Gnome 
install, the trashcan's on the desktop, but you still have the option of 
putting it on the panel.  I'm getting a little frustrated with Ubuntu; 
it seems to limit choices and options more than necessary, at least as 
compared with plain ol' Debian.  But I'll wait for Dapper to decide 
whether to keep it around or delete it off my computer; meantime, I 
don't know if I'll be using it much.

I've never shared /home partitions, that sounds like living dangerously!
I've made small 2GB home partitions for each OS, mostly for 
configuration files and whatever else might be useful for one but not 
the other(s).  But I keep the bulk of my own data on separate shared 
partitions.

> number of very small files, and it's taking forever, as in 2 hours 
> and counting.  Is there a "fast" way to do this?

It'd be helpful to know what technique you're currently using. :-)

Me, I'm a sucker for tar and pipes:

# the traditional way
tar cf - dirA dirB | ( cd /dest/dir && tar xf - )

# the gnu way
tar c dirA dirB | tar xC /dest/dir

In-Reply-To: <442B0CDE.15755.BC9322A1@localhost>
References: <4429876A.22970.B6A1D5EF@localhost>
	<442B0CDE.15755.BC9322A1@localhost>
Message-ID: <442C5EE6.6070109@writemoore.net>

John Jordan wrote:
<snip>
> 
> A more important point is the philosophical perspective. The only 
> thing that never changes is that everything changes. That includes 
> Linux. It seems abundantly clear to me that, in spite of the desires 
> of a few old Linux hands, Linux will get to the desktop. And to do 
> so, it will become more user friendly. The Linux we will be using 10 
> years from now will bear little resemblance to what we use today. 
> For example, the terminal will be all but obsolete. It will still be 
> there for the old hands, just as the command line ("DOS prompt") 
> still exists in Windows. But few Windows users even know it is 
> there, let alone what to do with it. Linux will arrive at the same point.

Once again, I feel compelled to point out that "Linux" isn't a 
monolithic entity like Windows.  I've little doubt you're right that 
Linux -- some Linux, some form of Linux -- will make it to the desktop 
in a bigger way that it has yet.  But that doesn't mean we'll still call 
it "Linux," nor does it mean the "Linux" we know today becomes obsolete. 
  You could say that "BSD has made it to the desktop" because OS X rides 
on a Darwin subsystem and Darwin is a modified BSD.  Yet there is still 
FreeBSD, NetBSD, etc. -- OS X doesn't preclude them.  It seems possible 
to me that something like that will happen with Linux, an OS or two or 
three featuring a mix of proprietary userlands and a Linux (or something 
very similar) core.  That is, unless Stallman manages to prevent it.  It 
doesn't seem like Linus Torvalds has the same agenda as Stallman, so I 
don't think the latter will be able to.

<more snippage>

> To arrive at this future shangri-la is essential for the future of Linux. 
> If we do not strive toward it, we are doomed. The reason is the 
> economics of market share. We have to be big enough to matter, 
> else we will never be big enough to matter. Why does Broadcom 
> ignore us? We all know the answer. But if our market share was 
> 25% instead of 5%, would they provide drivers. Damn right, they 
> would. 

I think what Congress, WIPO, and the cartels do will have a much bigger 
impact on the future of home computing than what Broadcom supports or 
doesn't support.  Either the future opens up and Linux gains or the 
future is locked down and the only thing for sale is "trusted" hardware 
that will refuse to run anything not MPAA-RIAA-BSA approved.  And even 
then, Linux might not go away entirely -- TiVo runs on Linux, after all.

-- 
"No live organism can continue for long to exist sanely under conditions 
of absolute reality; even larks and katydids are supposed, by some, to 
dream."  --S. Jackson

From heinlein at madboa.com  Thu Mar 30 14:56:19 2006
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 30 Mar 2006 14:56:19 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] copying large numbers of files
In-Reply-To: <442C57DC.5060400@spek.org>
References: <442C4928.9040708@spek.org>
	<Pine.OSX.4.64.0603301357470.3152@arrowhead.galois.com>
	<442C57DC.5060400@spek.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.OSX.4.64.0603301437310.3152@arrowhead.galois.com>

On Thu, 30 Mar 2006, Brent Rieck wrote:

> Paul Heinlein wrote:
>> It'd be helpful to know what technique you're currently using. :-)
>
> the cp way.. like I normally copy files.
>
> will the piped tar way be faster?

Often it is, because the reads and writes can happen independently of 
one another. I think cp has to do all of its operations atomically, 
which can really slow stuff down over a network connection.

Here are some test averages, where /usr/share is a local drive 
and ~/timetest/ is NFS-mounted:

[heinlein]$ cd /usr/share/doc

[heinlein]$ time cp -a [abcde]* ~/timetest/

real    0m11.854s
user    0m0.078s
sys     0m1.824s

[heinlein]$ time tar c [abcde]* | tar xC ~/timetest/

real    0m9.043s
user    0m0.148s
sys     0m1.364s

The timings will vary depending on network traffic and load on the 
file server, but in general tar is 20% faster. My hunch is that gobs 
of small files would tilt the equation even further in tar's 
direction.

-- 
Paul Heinlein <> heinlein at madboa.com <> www.madboa.com

On Thu, 30 Mar 2006, Rich Shepard wrote:

> Error executing formatting or display command. System command (cd
> /usr/local/man && (echo ".pl 1100i"; /bin/cat
> '/usr/local/man/man1/ps2pdf.1'; echo ".\\\""; echo ".pl \n(nlu+10") |
> /usr/bin/gtbl | /usr/bin/nroff -Tlatin1 -mandoc | /bin/bzip2 >
> /usr/local/man/cat1/ps2pdf.1.bz2) exited with status 768.

   More experimentation shows this happens on a bunch of man pages, not just
gs related ones. What's happening is that bzip2 is trying to make a
compressed version of the existing page, and failing.

   Why is bzip2 trying to make a compressed copy in ../cat1/ from ../man1/?
And, what could make it fail?

Rich

really clean up the font mess for Linux.  I can make good looking
documents Linux-to-Linux, or Linux-to-Printer, but this looks like it
will be a good open source framework for text anything-to-anything,

documents to Those Other Applications and retain the look of the
document.  The article suggests M$ may not play along, or at least
lag, but their cooperation is not necessary.

Open Source
---------------------
***Secure Your Linux Server
Linux is a powerful and popular operating system kernel. That popularity
means you might be running it even if you're not a dedicated Unix
administrator or high-powered programmer. That doesn't mean that
rock-solid security is out of your reach, though. Aaron Brazell shows
how to make Red Hat 9 (and other Linux distributions) much more secure
in a few easy steps.
<http://www.linuxdevcenter.com/pub/a/linux/2006/03/23/secure-your-server.html>


***Autofilled PHP Forms
PHP makes handling interactive web pages easy--but when you have large
forms to fill out, errors to handle, and lots of data to pass back and
forth, you can make your life easier by making PHP fill in all the form
values for you. Gavin Andresen shows how to make forms autopopulate from
PHP arrays.
<http://www.onlamp.com/pub/a/php/2006/03/16/autofill-forms.html>


***What Corporate Projects Should Learn from Open Source
Many corporate projects fail to produce quality software, yet many
large-scale open source projects succeed, and under much more difficult
conditions: no budget, a geographically distributed team, and a
volunteer workforce, to name a few. So how do open source project teams
ensure success? Andrew Stellman and Jennifer Greene introduce five basic
principles in their new book, "Applied Software Project Management," that
will help any project succeed, open source or proprietary. The authors
detail these principles in this article. 
<http://www.onlamp.com/pub/a/onlamp/2006/02/27/what-corp-projects-learn-from-open-source.html>

Java

***Zero Configuration Networking: Using the Java APIs, Part 1
Zeroconf, also known as Bonjour and previously known as Rendezvous,
offers a robust system for self-networking that has been adopted by many
applications. With a provided Java API, now it's easy to make "Zeroconf
applications hop platforms. In this excerpt from Zero Configuration
Networking: The Definitive Guide," Stuart Cheshire and Daniel H.
Steinberg show how to register a service with Zeroconf.
<http://www.onjava.com/pub/a/onjava/excerpt/bonjour_ch08/index.html>


***What Is Java
Everyone knows what Java is, right? Interpreted code, applets,
proprietary, and slow. Wrong, wrong, wrong, and wrong. In its second
decade, it's time to re-evaluate Java: the language and the virtual
machine are going their own ways, its open source sub-community is
vibrant and independent, and developers are taking the best ideas from
other languages and frameworks and bringing them to Java. In this
article, ONJava editor Chris Adamson tries to reset old assumptions
about Java to fit modern realities.
<http://www.onjava.com/pub/a/onjava/2006/03/08/what-is-java.html>

From ianburrell at gmail.com  Thu Mar 30 16:28:07 2006
From: ianburrell at gmail.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Thu, 30 Mar 2006 16:28:07 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] copying large numbers of files
In-Reply-To: <442C5782.5010604@spek.org>
References: <442C4928.9040708@spek.org> <861wwjr5id.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<442C5782.5010604@spek.org>
Message-ID: <d91f09cd0603301628u63fe8934ha63042db71c3158@mail.gmail.com>

On 3/30/06, Brent Rieck <bsr at spek.org> wrote:
> Russell Senior wrote:
> > Out of curiosity, which file system(s) are these going from/to?
>
> >From a NFS mounted ext3 partition  to a local reiserfs partition - the
> network appears to be saturated too.  But yay! it just finished copying.
>

You might want to see if you can get on the file server and transfer
directly from there.  My guess is that the slowness is caused by
latency in requesting each file.  I am pretty sure NFS requires a
round-trip message for each file; this adds up for a million files. 
Reading lots of small files is faster on a local disk because Linux
does caching of file metadata and blocks.

 - Ian

From ehem at m5p.com  Thu Mar 30 16:49:16 2006
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Thu, 30 Mar 2006 16:49:16 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Booting mulitple Linuxes
In-Reply-To: <20060330221748.6FB0A4775@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <200603310049.k2V0nGkl001486@m5p.com>

>From: "Michael M." <nixlists at writemoore.net>
> I have been wrestling with this today.  I have three large partitions on 
> my second hard drive I want to share between all OS'es, but the my UID 
> in Ubuntu is 1001 and my UID in Debian is 1000, so I couldn't write to 
> the partitions from Debian with my user account.  I chowned the 
> partitions by username, rather than UID, since I have the same username 
> in both OSes.  I haven't yet booted back into Ubuntu to see if I still 
> have full access, so I don't know if this method will work.

You'll need to run `usermod -u 1000 <username>` on your Ubuntu
installation to get Ubuntu's passwd file synchronized. You can do a
blanket change of the behavior by changing UID_MIN in /etc/login.defs
(odd location, likely historic).

> I've never shared /home partitions, that sounds like living dangerously!
> I've made small 2GB home partitions for each OS, mostly for 
> configuration files and whatever else might be useful for one but not 
> the other(s).  But I keep the bulk of my own data on separate shared 
> partitions.

Why does that sound like living dangerously? The distribution shouldn't
ever write there. You can generate config files that one doesn't like,
but the distribution tools /shouldn't/ do anything nasty without asking
you (since those are *your* files, and you're free to modify them).

From deanm at sharplabs.com  Thu Mar 30 17:36:09 2006
From: deanm at sharplabs.com (Dean S. Messing)
Date: Thu, 30 Mar 2006 17:36:09 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Q: how to prevent jpeg compression of images when going
	from PS to PDF  (solved)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0603301424520.14762@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	(message from Rich Shepard on Thu, 30 Mar 2006 14:39:13 -0800 (PST))
References: <20060330031642.04C601023B1@medulla.enet.sharplabs.com>
	<442B56D9.6090605@rocksolidservice.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.63.0603292000540.3722@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<20060330221738.310B61023B6@medulla.enet.sharplabs.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.63.0603301424520.14762@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20060331013609.BFF431023BC@medulla.enet.sharplabs.com>


Thanks to some off-list help from Rich Shepard I discovered a solution:


ps2pdf14  -dEncodeColorImages=false -dEncodeGrayImages=false   <file.ps>

This prevents all encoding (compression) of images.  This is
acceptable.  I'd still like to _losslessly_ compress them w/in the .pdf.
But this, at least, solved the problem.

Thanks Rich.

Dean

> You ask a lot of questions. Here are answers to a few of them.
 
> You can make a private mirror with rsync. Just check the mirror list
> at http://fedora.redhat.com/download/mirrors.html and find a mirror
> near you that supports rsync. Then just mirror the mirror.
 
> The source code is on the mirrors as well in the form of source-rpm
> (SRPM), but in a different subdirectory.
 
> If you use the yum utility to do the updates, it won't delete the
> downloaded RPMS unless you tell it to. I assume the Gnome update
> utility is a wrapper around yum, and it probably tells yum to delete
> the files.
 
> The main update servers never go off-line. They just stop getting new
> updates. Some of the mirrors may eventually delete the updates for
> FC3.
 
> If you're not ready to upgrade the consider getting future updates
> from the fedora-legacy project. You just have to set up new yum
> config files to point to their update servers, and you can continue
> on as before.
> 
> If you are ready to update, consider FC5 instead of FC4. But if you
> are an inexperienced user you might wait a couple more weeks so that
> the experienced users can work out some of the installation issues.

With the distribution diversion that is occuring, there seem to be a lot
of distributions now, how is anyone supposed to compare them?  What is
being done to keep all these distributions reasonably standardized?

A lot of people are pro Debian and yet others are pro CentOS. I'm not 
intending to start an annoyingly long thread here, but why?  If anyone
can explain why Ubuntu is popular, that interests me as well.
  
Is 300 the number of Linux distros these days, or are there more?
If the Linux community continues to fragment, will development stall?
With an average of at least 3 to 5 distros in use on this list, to
what degree can we all be talk about the same thing?



Aside:

A HOWTO that annoyed me on NFS root claims that rc.sysinit is adequately

links to killall, not documented.  Don't know why that script doesn't work

Core 1 without any updates applied to it.  What is the best way to learn
how to read Redhat and Fedora init scripts so that I can look into replacing

Guess I need to learn more about rsync and go for it ;-)  I've never used
rsync.

From ehem at m5p.com  Thu Mar 30 22:32:48 2006

>From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com
> Is 300 the number of Linux distros these days, or are there more?
> If the Linux community continues to fragment, will development stall?
> With an average of at least 3 to 5 distros in use on this list, to
> what degree can we all be talk about the same thing?

Long term, very much a danger. At the moment though there are lots of
distributions, they're tightly clustered in 2 groups. There are a number
of outliers, such as SuSE, and Slackware, but not many of those. Pretty
well all the recent new ones are varients of Debian or RedHat/Fedora;
while SuSE and Slackware split off more than 5 years ago. Though the
scripts are pretty varied, they're still running off the same core code.
I'd say we're safe for the next 5 years, at which point another
reassessment will be needed.

> Aside:
> 
> A HOWTO that annoyed me on NFS root claims that rc.sysinit is adequately
> documented for someone to modify it correctly.  WRONG!  I halt to cut the
> links to killall, not documented.  Don't know why that script doesn't work 
> right when root is nfs mounted.  The system that I'm nfsrooting is Fedora 
> Core 1 without any updates applied to it.  What is the best way to learn
> how to read Redhat and Fedora init scripts so that I can look into replacing
> them with ones that are more intelligible?

So, you're doing this on a dare, to show it will take more than 5 minutes
to get cracked?

Directly to the question, I'd guess the writer is assuming more knowledge
of scripting than you've got. The complexity isn't there to make it hard,
it is there because it is a complex task. I doubt you'll be able to make
them more intelligible, without a major rewrite exclusively for you. I
doubt you'll find it worth the effort.

From nixlists at writemoore.net  Fri Mar 31 06:14:31 2006
From: nixlists at writemoore.net (Michael M.)
Date: Fri, 31 Mar 2006 06:14:31 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Booting mulitple Linuxes
In-Reply-To: <200603310049.k2V0nGkl001486@m5p.com>
References: <200603310049.k2V0nGkl001486@m5p.com>
Message-ID: <442D3947.8030709@writemoore.net>

Elliott Mitchell wrote:
> 
> You'll need to run `usermod -u 1000 <username>` on your Ubuntu
> installation to get Ubuntu's passwd file synchronized. You can do a
> blanket change of the behavior by changing UID_MIN in /etc/login.defs
> (odd location, likely historic).

Good to know, for current and future reference.

> Why does that sound like living dangerously? The distribution shouldn't
> ever write there. You can generate config files that one doesn't like,
> but the distribution tools /shouldn't/ do anything nasty without asking
> you (since those are *your* files, and you're free to modify them).

Ok, dangerously is too strong a word.  It's just that sharing a home 
partition opens up the possiblility of incompatible config files, and 
yes I'm sure there are more-or-less straightforward workarounds or fixes 
for issues that arise.  It seems simpler to me just to give each distro 
its own small home partition.  I've seen this advice time and again on 
newbie-oriented message boards and mailing lists, always in response to 
people who were having problems because they were sharing a home 
partition between distros.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Mar 31 07:18:41 2006

   My new MSI K7N2 Delta2 motherboard is built around the nVidia nForce2
Gigabit MCP/RAID MCP. It includes, "integrated hardware Sound Blaster/Direct
Sound AC97 audio." /sbin/lspci reports: "Multimedia audio controller: nVidia

Please clarify.

Dual what resolution monitors? LCD?

Dual single-link DVI ports to run two monitors?

A dual-link DVI to run large resolution 21, 24, 30 inch, high resolutin 
LCD's?

I strongly recomemend the nVidia cards. 

I have had good luck running dual VGA and dual DVI on GeForce 5700, 
5900, 6200, and 7800 based boards.
If you are, or might in the future, run higher resolution (1600x1200, 
1920x1200, 2560x1600) LCD monitors
I would recommend jumping to the newer 7800 or 7900 cards.  Note most 
7800 cards are dual DVI but most
are only some support dual-link DVI and almost all the second DVI is 
single-link.  Also true for the lower end 7900 cards.
Some, but not all, of the 7900GTX cards appear to support 2 dual-link 
DVI (that is dual Dell 30" 2560x1600 monitors :) )

From RParr at TemporalArts.COM  Fri Mar 31 08:39:19 2006
From: RParr at TemporalArts.COM (RParr)
Date: Fri, 31 Mar 2006 16:39:19 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] copying large numbers of files
In-Reply-To: <442C4928.9040708@spek.org>
References: <442C4928.9040708@spek.org>
Message-ID: <442D5B37.3010108@TemporalArts.com>

Brent Rieck wrote:

>Hello,
>  I'm trying to make a copy of a directory tree containing a large
>number of very small files, and it's taking forever, as in 2 hours and
>counting.  Is there a "fast" way to do this?
>
>  I estimate that there is about 6 million files (I'm still waiting for
>the file count to come back), most files are < 1KB, some directories
>contain maybe 60K files.  I need to make a copy of it so I can "thin"
>the files by several orders of magnitude, and I want to make sure I
>don't "over thin" the original.
>
>  
>

I typically use cpio pass-through

$ mkdir destdir
$ cd srcdir
$ find * | cpio -pvdmu srcdir

If you are going to repeatedly make this same copy to archive or mirror 
the original source,
I would strongly recommend using rsync.  I'd use cpio for the initial 
copy, then update the destdir
from the srcdir thereafter using rsync

R.Parr, RHCE, Temporal Arts

seen it in a fibre channel array.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Fri Mar 31 09:22:44 2006
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Fri, 31 Mar 2006 09:22:44 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] SCSI verses SATA RAID
In-Reply-To: <442D6249.6030707@acm.org>
References: <442D6249.6030707@acm.org>
Message-ID: <1749-63308@sneakemail.com>

On 3/31/06, Roderick A. Anderson raanders-at-acm.org wrote:

> What are your thoughts on SCSI verses SATA RAID?

I'm a SCSI bigot from way back, but the price point on SATA is just
too compelling these days.  A while back SATA crossed the "costs half
as much for the same capacity" mark, which is important since it means
you can now own a mirrored pair of SATA drives for about the same
price as a single SCSI drive.

A quick Pricewatch search on 5-year warranty drives (Seagate) at 300GB
shows this today:

SCSI: $500
SATA: $120

Based on this approximation, I could own *four* SATA drives for the
price of a single SCSI drive, under the same warranty.  The SCSI drive
is 10,000RPM, and the SATA 7200RPM, but with four drives I can now run
a striped/mirror arrangement ("RAID-10") and those two pairs of
7200RPM drives will outperform the 10,000RPM drive due to the RAID
involved.

I frequently hear RAID rebuild time as a reason the individual drives
need to be more reliable.  The probability of having a second drive
fail during the 2-3 hours (at most) it might take to rebuild onto a
hot spare (hey, you can afford one now!) is very low.  Far lower than
the probability of a second SCSI drive failure during the 3-5 days it
will take to order a new drive, since you couldn't afford a hot spare.

As painful as it is for a "quality-conscious" person such as myself to
think about, once RAID comes into play, the "I" (inexpensive) is the
important part.  Unless the failure rate is truly ridiculous (and the
warranty prevents that) the cheaper, the better.

  -- Steve

From m0gely at telestream.com  Fri Mar 31 10:09:01 2006
From: m0gely at telestream.com (m0gely)
Date: Fri, 31 Mar 2006 10:09:01 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] SCSI verses SATA RAID
In-Reply-To: <442D6249.6030707@acm.org>
References: <442D6249.6030707@acm.org>
Message-ID: <442D703D.5000701@telestream.com>

Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
> Get your cans of fuel and matches ready.
> 
> ...
> 
> What are your thoughts on SCSI verses SATA RAID?
> 
> Assume RAID cards not software RAID.
> 
> Cost is not the biggest issue though the cost savings of SATA mean 
> more/bigger drives.
> 
> SCSI typically has a longer warranty ( 5 years ).
> 
> 
> So let the flames begin!  :-)

Why RAID vs. non-RAID?  Your question should really just be SATA vs. 
SCSI, as RAID changes the answer.  Many good SATA RAID cards can be as 
expensive as some SCSI RAID cards.  The same can be said for some drives 
too.  Though it's very easy to go through the roof on SCSI components.

My suggestion is this:
   Seagate SATA 7200.9's w/ 5 year warranty for the budget
   Western Dig SATA Raptor's for the serious SATA attempt (5yr wnty. too)
   Seagate Barracuda's for the low end SCSI
   Seagate Cheetah's for the high ($$$)

I don't have time to get into RAID cards but Promise would be the 
consumer (low end) brand.  Most decent SATA RAID cards start at around 
$400 ~ $500.  The Promise SX4 I used a while back didn't even support 
running more than one card in the same system, this may not be the case 
with more recent cards.

- m0gely

Paul Heinlein wrote:
> Often it is, because the reads and writes can happen independently of
> one another. I think cp has to do all of its operations atomically,
> which can really slow stuff down over a network connection.

As it turns out I managed to "corrupt" part of the dirtree when working
on it by resetting a bunch of timestamps on files by forgetting to use
the -a option on cp..

Which means I was able to try the tar method, and it does seems quite a
bit faster.  I didn't actually time it though, I always think it
would've been cool to start timing something 30 minutes into some
non-interruptable process.  This time, instead of going to my
local-network copy of the directory tree I decided to goto the one true
master that lies across the country and downloaded that over a SSH
tunnel with tar which was definably faster than scp'ing it.

thanks,
Brent


From nsxfreddy at gmail.com  Fri Mar 31 10:36:30 2006
From: nsxfreddy at gmail.com (Jason R. Martin)
Date: Fri, 31 Mar 2006 10:36:30 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] SCSI verses SATA RAID
In-Reply-To: <1749-63308@sneakemail.com>
References: <442D6249.6030707@acm.org> <1749-63308@sneakemail.com>
Message-ID: <c29537840603311036u4332897mdea71f0f8004a154@mail.gmail.com>

On 3/31/06, Steve Bonds <1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com> wrote:
> On 3/31/06, Roderick A. Anderson raanders-at-acm.org wrote:
>
> > What are your thoughts on SCSI verses SATA RAID?
>
> I'm a SCSI bigot from way back, but the price point on SATA is just
> too compelling these days.  A while back SATA crossed the "costs half
> as much for the same capacity" mark, which is important since it means
> you can now own a mirrored pair of SATA drives for about the same
> price as a single SCSI drive.
>
> A quick Pricewatch search on 5-year warranty drives (Seagate) at 300GB
> shows this today:
>
> SCSI: $500
> SATA: $120
>
> Based on this approximation, I could own *four* SATA drives for the
> price of a single SCSI drive, under the same warranty.  The SCSI drive
> is 10,000RPM, and the SATA 7200RPM, but with four drives I can now run
> a striped/mirror arrangement ("RAID-10") and those two pairs of
> 7200RPM drives will outperform the 10,000RPM drive due to the RAID
> involved.
>
> I frequently hear RAID rebuild time as a reason the individual drives
> need to be more reliable.  The probability of having a second drive
> fail during the 2-3 hours (at most) it might take to rebuild onto a
> hot spare (hey, you can afford one now!) is very low.  Far lower than
> the probability of a second SCSI drive failure during the 3-5 days it
> will take to order a new drive, since you couldn't afford a hot spare.
>
> As painful as it is for a "quality-conscious" person such as myself to
> think about, once RAID comes into play, the "I" (inexpensive) is the
> important part.  Unless the failure rate is truly ridiculous (and the
> warranty prevents that) the cheaper, the better.

Aren't a lot of the cheaper/low-end SATA "RAID" controllers actually
software raid and/or RAID 0 and 1 only?

Jason

From heinlein at madboa.com  Fri Mar 31 11:02:42 2006
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 31 Mar 2006 11:02:42 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Checking out CentOS...
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0603310949210.28422@blackbox.fnordora.org>
References: <1143531507.4428e7f33e5a2@xerxes.robinson-west.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.64.0603310949210.28422@blackbox.fnordora.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.OSX.4.64.0603311056290.3495@arrowhead.galois.com>

On Fri, 31 Mar 2006, alan wrote:

> On Mon, 27 Mar 2006, plug_0 at robinson-west.com wrote:
>
>>  Now that I know it's a clone of Redhat Enterprise 4, I'm going
>>  after the ISO's to try it.
>
> It is interesting that if you compare the spec files between 
> CentOS/RHEL and Fedora, they are almost exactly the same for most 
> critical apps. Sometimes there is a version difference, but not 
> always.

Any given RHEL release these days is usually based strongly on a 
certain Fedora release. RHEL 4 is a trimmed and buttoned-down version 
of Fedora Core 3. RHEL 5 will probably be based on FC 5.

Fedora, with a more frequent release schedule, will usually leap ahead 
of RHEL early in the latter's lifecycle. Right now, for instance, FC 5 
includes some cool new SELinux config options that RHEL users won't 
see until RHEL 5 comes out.

The other fairly obvious difference is that Fedora Core contains a 
*lot* more packages than RHEL. Sure, there are third-party 
repositories for some of it, but RHEL is limited so Red Hat can make a 
reasonable stab at supporting the entire package set for its paying 
customers.

-- 
Paul Heinlein <> heinlein at madboa.com <> www.madboa.com

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Fri Mar 31 11:56:15 2006

Subject: [PLUG] Hosting recommendation
In-Reply-To: <BAY108-F36AFDCB31765F2931BACFFB8D60@phx.gbl>
References: <BAY108-F36AFDCB31765F2931BACFFB8D60@phx.gbl>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0603311145050.3593@PPC.DavidMandel.com>


Please tell us a bit about the project.
The best hosting solution depends on your needs and your
project's qualifications.

Is it Open Source or otherwise not-for-profit?
A lot of people will give these projects free hosting - sometimes with 
significant bandwidth and lots of freedom  - even root passwords.

Will the project require significant resources?  bandwidth? disk? CPU?

Is reasonable uptime good enough or does it have to be up all the time?

Are there backup issues?  How secret is any of the data?

All of this and more affects your server choice.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri Mar 31 12:15:43 2006
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Fri, 31 Mar 2006 12:15:43 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Hosting recommendation
In-Reply-To: <BAY108-F36AFDCB31765F2931BACFFB8D60@phx.gbl>

On Fri, Mar 31, 2006 at 02:47:27PM +0000, Vincent Yau wrote:
> I am looking for a hosting solution for a project and preferably
> I have shell access (Linux based of course) and also MySQL 
> capability with the ISP.
> 
> Any recommendation on local ISP that you have good experience with?

You can buy a virtual Linux machine with root access for $20/month .
That may be more power than you need, but it permits you to do all
sorts of things that a user account does not.

I used pdxcolo.net for a year, and was happy with them until they got
caught in an interface upgrade struggle.  The struggle is over now,
the new interface looks pretty good.  They are now vcolo.com .

During the struggle, I switched to rimuhosting.com .  They are located
in New Zealand, host out of Dallas TX, and have a service center in 
Cambridge UK.  They are more fussy about what they let you do, but they
are also quicker to respond to service requests.  They are not "local",
but the round trip ping time to Dallas is only 37 milliseconds longer
(gotta love that speed'o'light!), so they are both fairly quick.

Both offer many different distros.  I used Fedora Core at pdxcolo,
and now I am using Centos 4 (a clone of Redhat Enterprise 4, sorta
like Fedora Core 3) at rimuhosting.

I will be talking about Offsite Virtual Colocation Servers at the 
Advanced Topics meeting on Monday April 17 at Jax, so that is a good
time to find out how a person can manage an offsite virtual server
with little knowledge (Moi?).

If you choose either one, tell them I sent you.  It earns me brownie
points (which I use up with lame-ass experiments).

Keith

From ehem at m5p.com  Fri Mar 31 12:28:15 2006
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Fri, 31 Mar 2006 12:28:15 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] dual DVI video card
In-Reply-To: <20060331172145.C1E3A47A7@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <200603312028.k2VKSFOi011005@m5p.com>

>From: "Lancashire, Pete" <plancashire at ci.portland.or.us>
> Before asking PLUG I had never heard of dual-link, single-link.
> Up to now just a serial port is all I have ever looked for, since
> until now I've done all my GUI stuff via a dedicated Xterm.

A favored pointer:
http://www.pacificcable.com/DVI_Tutorial.htm

One interesting factor is you can drive very high resolution displays
with single-link DVI, you just push the refresh rate through the floor.
The trick of course, that with LCDs a lower refresh rate isn't a major
problem. With CRTs refresh rate is very much an issue, but there you're
likely using the analog path, not the digital path.

Now one issue is, "who the heck is the idiot who thought not supporting
high resolutions such as 1920x1536?" Why oh why did they design a digital
system that couldn't drive *existing* monitors?  :'-(

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Fri Mar 31 17:58:19 2006
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Fri, 31 Mar 2006 17:58:19 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] SCSI verses SATA RAID
In-Reply-To: <442D9C64.8010109@acm.org>
References: <442D6249.6030707@acm.org> <442D703D.5000701@telestream.com>
	<Pine.OSX.4.64.0603311105270.3495@arrowhead.galois.com>
	<442D9C64.8010109@acm.org>
Message-ID: <15471-12457@sneakemail.com>

On 3/31/06, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:

> The software we'll be running on it is limited by I/O and sort-of RAM.

As others have noted, if you're looking for I/O speed, stay away from
the low end hardware "RAID" cards.

It may be worth looking at Linux software RAID since it's quite
snappy-- at least run a quick test on your planned hardware with
software RAID before spending big $$$$ on good RAID cards.

You may also be able to extract some additional performance out of
your hardware RAID card(s) by running software RAID-0 (striping)
across the top of them.

  -- Steve
